Title: Do we still need Crile or Hayes Martin approach for cervical lymphadenectomy? A retrospective study of 56 patients with minimal access neck dissection
Author: Sayan, Anna; Ganesarajah, Thirilosanan; Baheerathan, Nall; Ilankovan, Velupillai
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: The concept of neck dissection was introduced by Crile more than a century ago. Since then, multiple modifications have been adopted to ensure the preservation of vital structures. With the new era of minimal access surgery, the incorporation of laparoscopic, endoscopic, and robotic surgery is becoming the new normal. Over the years we have carried out neck dissections using minimal access incisions. Although there is no definitive answer about the average nodal yield required in selective or modified neck dissections, it has been reported that the average nodal yield of more than 18 is associated with better survival rate. In this publication we share the results of our three-year retrospective study of 56 patients who underwent minimal access neck dissection. We look at the nodal yield, assess operating duration, complications, outcome with a three-year follow up from a single unit. Our results demonstrate that minimal access neck dissection should be considered in head and neck lymphadenectomies.
Body:
Introduction
Crile introduced the concept of neck dissection in 1906.1 The molecular basis of tumour metastasis depends on cell proteolytic enzymes, expression of adhesion molecules, and degradation of the extracellular matrix interactions, which will give the ability to penetrate lymphatics. Furthermore, CD44 expression was also queried as a molecular base factor in head and neck tumour metastasis.2
In the 1950s, Hayes Martin popularised what Crile started at the beginning of the 20th century.3 Bocca, however, in 1967 introduced modifications of the lymphadenectomy process by preventing avulsion of vital anatomical structures;4 however, surgical approaches remained unaltered since Crile and Martin times with only minimal modification.
In modern surgery, minimal access surgical approaches are promoted. New techniques have been developed such as laparoscopic, endoscopic, and robotic surgery. For cervical lymphadenectomy in the last 12 years, varied minimal access and scarless surgery has been reported with its own difficulties and complications.5â€“7
We have published papers on minimal access surgery with an endoscope for cervical lymphadenectomy in managing thyroid, oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancers and simultaneous free flap anastomosis.8,9 Over the last ten years with experience, we have modified our technique to harvest nodes at level I to IV and V using only minimal access without the use of an endoscope. This has been proven to show satisfactory surgical outcome.
We retrospectively reviewed a series with a three-year follow up for surgical access, duration of surgery, nodal yield, motor and sensory nerve complications, aesthetic outcome, recurrence rate and incidence of external nodal extension. The aim of this retrospective study was to look at the nodal yield, duration time, and outcome of minimal access neck dissection.
Patients and methods
We retrospectively collected a conservative series of patients who underwent selective neck dissection by a single surgeon. There were 56 patients with a mean (range) age of 67 (47â€“91) years. The male (M) to female (F) ratio was 32:24 (57% M; 43% F). The inclusion criteria included patients who underwent selective neck dissection for oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (oSCC) and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) malignancies requiring selective neck dissection. The exclusion criteria were simultaneous parotidectomy, patients undergoing neck dissections for malignant melanomas, adenocarcinomas, and bilateral neck dissections where one side involved a standard access neck dissection. Although no formal statistical testing has been done, we used Excel data analysis to calculate the average, mean, standard deviations, etc. Table 1 illustrates data of all 56 patients who underwent minimal access neck dissections with details on the nodal yield, negative nodes (N0) positive nodes (N+) and level of neck dissections. Table 2 describes the patientsâ€™ demographics.

Surgical technique for minimal access neck dissection (MAND)
In addition to the usual head and neck instruments the extra additions were a head light (Toffeln UltraView Extreme), 3.5 loupe magnification, Harmonic scalpel (Ethicon) and a long monopolar blade (Gold Vacâ„¢ push button, Conmed Corporation).
The patientâ€™s head is extended by placing a sandbag under the shoulders. A 3â€“4 cm transverse incision is made along the neck crease ending along the anterior border of the sternomastoid muscle. The incision of the platsyma and deep fascia is followed by subfacial dissection. This is carried out superiorly to the lower border of the mandible extending to the angle of the mandible. The next step is to create dissection on the same plane anteriorly, up to the genial tubercle passing the anterior belly of digastric. The third pocket is to create access up to the level IV. For level V nodal harvesting dissection is carried out to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The external jugular vein (EJV) and great auricular nerve are preserved. Differential retraction is the secret of this dissection. Once the superior, anterior, inferior, and posterior pockets are created the next step is to identify the accessory nerve. Then the posterior belly of digastric muscle and the internal jugular vein are identified, followed by delivery of level Ila and IIb nodes separately. The next step is to dissect the level Ib followed by Ia and deliver the submandibular triangle contents, preserving the lingual and hypoglossal nerves. Following that, we dissect around the internal jugular vein right down to the omolohyoid and beyond. The vagus nerve and common carotid artery are identified and preserved. This follows removal of the level III and level IV lymph nodes.
Dissection of the level V requires localisation of the accessory nerve, which is followed until it enters the anterior border of the trapezius muscle. The level Vb is removed, followed by the Va. Absolute haemostasis is ensured using the Valsalva manoeuvre and a suitable drain is inserted, followed by a layered repair.
Table 3 illustrates levels of neck dissection for 56 patients with detailed analysis of nodal yield and postoperative sequalae. Types of neck dissection varied from Level Iâ€“III to level Iâ€“V. Level Iâ€“IV was the most common neck dissection that was performed in the unit with average nodal yield of 44.2. Furthermore, 8% of cases had bilateral neck dissections and the average nodal yield was around 33. A total of 37.5% of patients had positive lymph nodes with extranodal extension in 15.8% of cases. Mean surgical time for neck dissection was 90 minutes and, in most cases, (41 patients) drains were removed with five days. There was minimal reported loss of sensation or motor neural deficit. Regional neck recurrence was reported in eight patients within the three-year period.

Discussion
Lymphadenectomy remains the keystone in the management of neck metastases. Despite the advances in surgical technique that were introduced by Crile, Hayes Martin etc, extensive incisions remain a common practice. Kang et al first demonstrated neck dissection through the transaxillary approach for lateral neck dissection.10,11 Kim et al introduced the transaxillary and retroauricular approach for lateral neck dissection.7,11 Lee et al presented their findings using robot assisted supraomohyoid neck dissection, the modified face lift, or the retroauricular approach.7 Recently, there have been many modifications and publications on hidden approaches. Retroauricular and robotic assisted approaches do have benefits but are costly, require a longer duration, and result in more complications, although they have provided invisible scars.12â€“15
In our series, a small transverse incision, on average 4 cm, which probably produced a better cosmetic outcome in comparison with most sentinel node biopsy access approaches. The patientâ€™s perception of a cosmetic outcome in our series was measured with a visual analogue scale, with an average score of 8â€“10, during the first three months follow up.
Arora et al investigated patient perception, although they found no correlation between the scar length and patient score satisfaction, but the quality of life in patients with visible scars was poorer compared with those in whom the scar was concealed.16 Our technique gave a balanced benefit where the scar is not hidden but small and there were no concerns about quality of life.
Liang et al reported the feasibility of lymphadenectomy of levels II to IV in 29 patients using an endoscope via a small natural neck incision in the management of early stage (T1 â€“ 2 N0 M0) head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.17 The mean (SD) number of harvested lymph nodes was 19.1 (4.1) with an operating time of 68.4 (10.3) minutes.
Kathar et al reported a series of 28 patients using robotic/endoscopy assisted neck dissection with the mean (SD) duration of surgical time was excessive of 231.79 (54.9) minutes in patients with levels I to IV.5 They report this for the learning curve in this surgical practice.
Raj et al published minimal invasive supraomohyoid neck dissection by endoscopic technique with mean (SD) duration of 53.7 (29.8) minutes, however, their technique used CO2 insufflation with associated complications.18
In publications mainly from South Korea, robotic assisted techniques were presented for various neck dissections, however, the drawbacks are the added expenditure, prolonged operative time, and more invasive dissection.19 In our series, the operating duration ranged from 70 to 110 minutes with a mean of 90 and required no additional dissection with minimal associated complications. In our previous publications we used a small incision approach with the assisted use of zero-degree endoscope. With experience, the endoscope in our series had become an unnecessary tool.8,9
It is well known fact that lymph node ratio plays an important prognosticator in survival rate for head and neck oncological patients.20 Although there is no discrete lymph node ratio defining neck dissection; over the years it has been reported that lymph node yield of 18 is associated with a better survival rate.21â€“23 In our series we had eight patients with a nodal yield of less than 18 with two patients of N+ neck. All these patients had postoperative radiotherapy and/or neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy and had no recurrence within three years follow up period. Our nodal yield was higher than the recommended numbers for Iâ€“III, Iâ€“IV, Iâ€“V (Table 3). The extranodal extension was 15.79%.
The dissection in a subfascial plane to create the superior pocket in our series not only prevented injury of the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve but gave direct access to the levels Ia and Ib and reduced the operative time compared to the standard subplatysmal approach. Although one person experienced traction weakness of marginal mandibular nerve initially, a complete resolution occurred within three months.
We wait for the drainage collection to be less than 10 ml in twenty-four hours before removing the drain. For patients who underwent neck dissection only, the drains were removed in 2â€“5 days in the majority with an average of three days.
None of our patients experienced complete accessory nerve weakness on discharge. This remained the same for 50% of our patients who did not have any adjuvant treatment. In those patients who had postoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy, shoulder stiffness, despite normal accessory nerve function postoperatively, was observed. This is possibly attributed to chemoradiotherapy effect rather than surgical trauma. We did not have any trauma to the vagus nerve, phrenic nerve, or the cervical plexus in our series.
Seven oSCC and one cSCC patient had regional recurrence amounting to 14.29%. All eight patients had positive neck node (N+) in their neck dissection. Four out of eight patients had a poorly differentiated SCC. Furthermore, three out of eight patients presented with lymphadenopathy in the contralateral neck. Four of these eight patients had simultaneous distant metastases.
In summary, small incision neck dissection in our hands works well in carrying out cervical lymphadenectomy. Sensory and motor nerve deficit as a result of surgery was negligible in our series. The nodal yield is equal or better than comparable publications. No and N+ neck in our series did not prove any difference in the identification of lymph nodes. There is no comparable surgical procedure to our knowledge, and our surgical time is better than previous published figures. Drain removal and patient stay is somewhat prolonged due to other comorbidities and factors. Motor and sensory nerve deficit is negligent in our series. We therefore recommend colleagues to consider this approach with minimal morbidity and considering lymphadenectomy of level I to IV and level I to V in managing oropharyngeal and cutaneous malignancy neck dissections.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Ethical Approval was not required for this study. Patient permission was not required for this publication

This research project evaluates a minimally invasive technique for performing neck dissections in patients with head and neck cancers, building on historical methods pioneered by Crile and refined by Hayes Martin and Bocca. The study focuses on a minimal access neck dissection (MAND) method using a small 3â€“4 cm transverse incision along the neck crease. This approach allows surgeons to access lymph node levels Iâ€“V through subfascial dissection while preserving vital structures such as the accessory nerve, external jugular vein, and great auricular nerve. The technique employs standard head and neck instruments augmented by a headlight, 3.5Ã— loupe magnification, a harmonic scalpel, and a specialized monopolar blade.

In a retrospective review spanning three years, 56 patients (mean age 67.1 years, 57% male) with oral squamous cell carcinoma (oSCC) or cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) underwent selective neck dissection using this method. The majority of procedures were performed at levels Iâ€“IV, achieving an average nodal yield of approximately 44 nodes, with a mean operative time of 90 minutes. The study reports minimal postoperative complications, including negligible motor and sensory nerve deficits, and an acceptable rate of regional recurrence (14.3%), primarily in patients with positive nodal involvement and poorer differentiation. Cosmetic outcomes were favorable, with patients rating their scars highly on visual analogue scales.

Overall, the findings suggest that MAND provides comparable oncologic efficacy to traditional open techniques while offering the advantages of reduced incision size, shorter surgical times, and minimal morbidity. The authors recommend considering this approach for the management of oropharyngeal and cutaneous malignancy-related neck dissections, especially when balancing effective cancer control with enhanced aesthetic outcomes.

This retrospective study investigates the efficacy of minimal access neck dissection (MAND) for oral and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It reviews data from 56 patients who underwent selective neck dissection via a 3-4 cm transverse incision, using specific instruments but without an endoscope, focusing on levels I-V. The study analyzes surgical access, duration, nodal yield, complications, aesthetics, and recurrence.

Results showed an average surgical time of 90 minutes, with varying nodal yields depending on the neck levels dissected. Postoperative complications like sensory loss were generally minimal, and nerve damage was rare. Regional neck recurrence occurred in 14.3% of patients, all of whom had positive nodes. The authors suggest the procedure is well-tolerated, provides adequate nodal yield, minimizes morbidity, and offers acceptable aesthetic outcomes compared to traditional approaches or more complex minimally invasive techniques. The study advocates for MAND in managing oropharyngeal and cutaneous malignancies, deeming it a balanced and effective approach to cervical lymphadenectomy.

Title: Does distraction osteogenesis improve the airway volume and quality of life of obstructive sleep apnoea patients secondary to temporomandibular joint ankylosis?
Author: Chaudhary, Ganesh; Bhutia, Ongkila; Roychoudhury, Ajoy; Mandal, Jeetendra; Yadav, Rahul
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) ankylosis leads to mandibular micrognathia that severely collapses the upper airway causing obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA), resulting in deterioration and compromise in the quality of life (QoL) of patients. In this study, we aimed to calculate airway volume changes, apnoea-hypopnoea index (AHI), and improvement in quality of life before and after distraction osteogenesis (DO). Fourteen Patients with OSA secondary to TMJ ankylosis at a mean (SD) age of 17.5 (5.43) years were enrolled in this prospective study. Multivector mandibular distractors were used in all patients following the standard Ilizarov distraction protocol with a mean (SD) anteroposterior distraction of 16.21 (4.37) mm and a consolidation period of 116.92 (14.35) days. The patients were followed up for six months. A polysomnography test (PSG) was done to quantify AHI and a low-dose computed tomographic scan was done to calculate airway volume using Dolphin medical imaging software pre and post-DO. The QoL of the patients was calculated using the OSA-18 questionnaire. Results analysis depicted that the mean (SD) preoperative AHI was 51.44 (37.99)/h which was improved to 9.57 (9.74)/h (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.001) after DO. Airway volume was calculated on Dolphin software before and after DO showed a significant improvement in airway volume by 121.12% (98.30)%. Similarly, the OSA-18 questionnaire showed significant improvement in QoL from severe to normal. This study suggested that DO increases the corpus length of the mandible, leading to an increment in airway volume, which improves the QoL.
Body:
Introduction
Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) ankylosis leads to an acquired deformity of the mandible. This results in reduced mobility, retrognathia, and deranged occlusion leading to the narrowing of oropharyngeal space, which compresses during respiration due to a reduction in space for the tongue,1 results in physical obstruction during respiration, and ultimately causes obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA).2 Features are daytime somnolence, decreased concentration, headache, snoring, cessation of breathing while sleeping, and decreased oxygen saturation level.3,4
Polysomnography (PSG) is the gold standard diagnostic tool for OSA. It measures different variables such as the apnoea-hypopnoea index (AHI). Thus, daytime sleepiness along with deranged AHI >5, is considered pathognomonic for OSA diagnosis.5 An AHI of 5â€“15 is considered mild OSA, 15â€“30 is moderate OSA and >30 is severe OSA.2,6 The condition can be managed by different surgical means such as distraction osteogenesis (DO) and orthognathic surgery. DO of the mandible is considered a successful technique for expanding the oropharyngeal airways of paediatric and adult patients.7 It can lead to significant improvement in airway space and volume with an improvement of the AHI because obstruction of upper airway space is mostly at the level of the tongue base.6,8,9
Chronic deprivation of sleep may result in neuropsychiatric, cardiac, and vascular sequelae. Neuropsychiatric effects cause depression and intellectual dysfunction, which ultimately leads to disturbance in the personal, professional, and social well-being of patients. Cardiac and vascular sequelae consist of systemic hypertension, arrhythmia, myocardial infarction, heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and stroke.10 Thus, such effects of OSA on the patientâ€™s general health degrade the overall quality of life. Numerous generic and specific instruments are formulated to measure the QoL of patients. Amongst these, the OSA-18 questionnaire is the one that is most patient-friendly and unique.11 The analysis of OSA patients without TMJ ankylosis has been done previously using either quantitative or qualitative methods but the literature is scarce on the evidence that uses both of these methods for assessing pre- and post-treatment results in OSA patients with TMJ ankylosis. Thus, the present study was proposed to evaluate the changes in upper airway volume and QoL of patients before and after DO.
Material and methods
Study design
To address the purpose of the research, a prospective study was designed and conducted in the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery in collaboration with the Department of Neurology, All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS, New Delhi) from January 2018 to July 2019 after getting ethical approval from the Institution Ethics Committee (Ref No-IECPG-5/6/29.11.2017, RT-14/20.12.2017). Fourteen patients fulfilling the inclusion and exclusion criteria were included in the study.
Inclusion criteria:
â€¢        
Patients having an acquired retrognathia with unilateral/bilateral TMJ ankylosis with PSG-proven OSA
â€¢        
Ages >7 years
Exclusion criteria:
â€¢        
Patientâ€™s unwillingness to give consent
â€¢        
Medically compromised patients
â€¢        
Immunocompromised patients
â€¢        
Patients with metabolic disorders of bone
Study variables
Baseline parameters were age, sex, aetiology, type of ankylosis, AHI, airway volume changes, and QoL determined using the OSA-18 questionnaire.
Surgical procedure
All patients were operated on under general anaesthesia using nasotracheal intubation. A standard submandibular approach was used. After exposure of the angle of the mandible, an osteotomy line was planned according to the desired vector. Incomplete osteotomy was done with a piezotome, leaving a bridge of bone at the region of the inferior alveolar nerve canal.
A distractor was placed at the desired site and osteotomy was completed using a chisel and mallet (Supplemental figure, online only). After a distractor was placed, it was activated to check the function. The closure was done in layers with 3/0 Vicryl and 4/0 nylon sutures. A standard protocol for distraction12 with a latency period of 5â€“7 days and a distraction rate of 1mm/day (0.5mm twice daily) was followed. An average distraction distance of 15â€“20mm and a consolidation period of 3â€“4 months was maintained. After 3â€“4 months of the consolidation period, bone formation at the distraction gap was confirmed with OPG and PA cephalogram. The distractor was removed after observing the callus formation before the release of ankylosis.
Outcomes
Airway volume
A preoperative low dose computed tomographic scan (LDCT) was done for the evaluation of upper airway volume with the help of medical image processing software â€˜Dolphinâ€™ (Version 11.7; Dolphin Imaging and Management Solutions). The following landmarks were plotted in the software â€“ (Supplemental Figure, online only):
â€¢        
Cephalad -hard palate plane
â€¢        
Caudal -glottis
â€¢        
Ventral -junction of superior adenoid tissue and nasopharynx
â€¢        
Dorsal-posterior pharyngeal wall
â€¢        
Lateral -right and left lateral pharyngeal wall
LDCT was done again after distractor removal for the calculation of upper airway volume postoperatively and was calculated in the software Dolphin using the same landmarks (Supplemental figure, online only). Both preoperative and postoperative data were calculated twice by the same examiner after one week for intra-rater reliability and the average of the two values was taken for the final evaluation.
Apnoea-hypopnoea index
Preoperative AHI was calculated using PSG data and compared with postoperative AHI data after distractor removal (Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Line diagram showing preoperative and postoperative apnoea-hypopnoea index.
Quality of life of patients
Evaluation of the quality of life of patients was done by assessing pre and post-operative OSA-18 questionnaires.11 This included 18 items, grouped into five domains where items are scored in ordinal seven-point classification.11 (Table 1)
Domains        Never        Almost never        A few times        Sometimes        Many times        Most of the times        Every time
         1        2        3        4        5        6        7

Interfered with your ability to perform daily activities?                                                               
Made you frustrated?                                                               
Total Score OSA (18â€“126)

2.

Statistical analysis
Stata 14.0 (StataCorp LP, College Station) statistical software was used for data analysis. Categorical variables were summarised by frequency (%). Quantitative variables were summarised by mean/SD/median (min-max) as appropriate. Various variables such as AHI, airway volume (pre and post), % change in airway volume, sleep disorder, physical disorder, emotional distress, daily problems, the concern of the caretaker, and total OSA had been calculated and summarised. The Wilcoxon signed rank test was done to compare the change in parameters over a period.
A paired t-test was used to test preoperative and postoperative sleep disorder, physical disorder, emotional distress, daily problems, concern of caretaker, and total OSA. The intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) was calculated to define intra-rater reliability. A p-value â‰¤0.05 was considered statistically significant.
Results
A total of 14 patients (six bilateral and eight unilateral) of TMJ ankylosis with OSA were enrolled. All patients were followed up for six months. Mean (SD) [range] age was found to be 17.5 (5.43) [10â€“30] years with gender predilection of 10 males and four females (Male: Female = 5:2). The distractors used were multivector in 12 patients and linear in two patients. The mean (SD) [range] anteroposterior distraction of 16.21 (4.37) [9â€“25] mm and consolidation period of 116.92 (14.35) [96â€“152] days were considered. After DO, 11 patients developed an open bite, which was corrected by callus moulding with intermaxillary fixation and elastic traction.
Preoperative AHI was 51.44 (37.99) [6.4â€“113.6] which improved to AHI 9.57 (9.74) [0.5â€“28.6] (p = 0.001) (Fig. 1). This depicted that there was a significant improvement in OSA post-distraction treatment. Similarly, preoperative airway volume was 3836.14 (2244.63) [1709â€“9453] mm3 and postoperative airway volume was 7527.42 (3564.24) [3034â€“16752] mm3 (p = 0.001) (Fig. 2) with improvement in airway volume by the amount of 3691.28 (2190.12) [570â€“7299] post-DO. This showed substantial progress in airway volume by 121.12 (98.30) % [15.78â€“352] %. For intra-rater reliability, ICC values varied from 0.999 to 1.00 depicting almost perfect agreement in preoperative and postoperative volume readings, respectively.

Fig. 2 Line diagram showing preoperative and postoperative airway volume.
Similarly, the preoperative and postoperative quality of life of the patients was calculated using an OSA-18 questionnaire which contained five domains (sleep disorder, physical distress, emotional distress, daily problems, and concern of caretakers). Each domain was given a number and calculated accordingly (Table 2). Subjective preoperative total OSA was 73.85 (10.58) [62â€“93] (p < 0.001) and postoperative total OSA was 8.81 (13.75) [18 â€“ 35] (p< 0.001) (Fig. 3). This also signified the improvement in OSA from severe to normal after DO.

Fig. 3 Line diagram showing preoperative and postoperative obstructive sleep apnoea (subjective).
Discussion
Retrognathia leading to the narrowing of pharyngeal airway space and collapse of the airway during respiration due to reduced muscle tone while sleeping is a major pathogenesis of OSA (Fig. 4). TMJ ankylosis is one of the conditions that produce a severe degree of retrogenia and micrognathia leading to airway compromise (Supplemental figures, online only). Numerous treatment modalities are available for the management of OSA secondary to TMJ ankylosis, DO being one of them.

Fig. 4 Virtual reality tool preoperative image showing reduced chin, severe overjet and osteotomy line at angle of mandible region.
OSA secondary to TMJ ankylosis can be seen in any age group ranging from child to adult irrespective of gender. The mean (SD) age of the patients in this study was 17.5 (5.43) years and the most common cause of TMJ ankylosis was trauma, which occurred mostly in the younger age group and the male population. The present study was in accordance with the above theory as it also included younger age group patients. The males had higher predilection than the females. Young age and male predilection were observed since these groups are more prone to trauma and post-traumatic TMJ ankylosis. The study by Wang Xing et al13 included the mean age group of 21.2 years, and Manikandan et al14 included the age group of 12â€“23 years correlating with the present study. The mean (SD) amount of anteroposterior distraction was 16.21 (4.37) mm, which depended mostly upon preoperative overjet (range, 8â€“19 mm) and edge-to-edge bite obtained after distraction (Fig. 5), elongating the linear dimension of the mandible to accommodate the space for the tongue (Supplemental figures, online only).

Fig. 5 Virtual reality tool postoperative image showing distraction regenerate formation at angle region of mandible with edge-to-edge bite and mandibular advancement.
All patients had undergone preoperative and postoperative overnight PSG for calculation of the AHI index. Before surgery, eight patients showed severe OSA, three patients had moderate OSA, and the remaining three patients had mild OSA after distractor removal; while four patients improved to moderate OSA, three patients to mild OSA, and seven patients were normal. None of the patients was in the severe OSA group after distractor removal showing significant clinical improvement in AHI (Fig. 1). More than 57% of cases had severe OSA before distraction which became normal in 50% of cases and mild in more than 21% of cases after distraction indicating the noticeable improvement in OSA and its symptoms. Wang Xing et al,13 Yadav et al,15 Manikandan et al,14 Abdulfattah et al16 showed improvement in AHI from severe to mild whereas Rachmiel et al,17 and Looby et al18 showed improvement from moderate to normal. In the present study, AHI was improved from severe to mild or normal and was in accordance with the above studies, the reason being that OSA was primarily due to retrogenia, which was corrected by distraction leading to an increase in corpus length and airway volume.
The airway volume was calculated on digital LDCT face data in Dolphin medical imaging software and was analysed (Fig. 2) showing <50% improvement in the airway in two cases, 50%â€“100% improvement in the airway in six cases, 100% improvement in the airway in six cases and overall improvement in airway up to 121.12 (98.30) % (p = 0.001). This noticeable progress in AHI and airway volume with improvement in symptoms of OSA was correlated with other studies (Arlen Denny et al), showed an increase in airway volume up to 67.5 %,19 Rachmiel et al showed improvement in airway volume up to 71.92%,17 Ahmed Mahrous et al showed the increase in airway volume up to 37%,9 Manikandhan et al showed improvement in airway volume up to 19.3%. Abdelfatteh et al showed improvement in airway volume up to 70.5%,16 Anantanarayanan et al showed improvement in airway volume up to 31.33%,20 Zachary et al showed improvement in airway volume up to 76%,21 and Valerio Ramieri et al discovered increase in airway volume up to 169%.22 The airway volume was markedly increased in the present study with a mean (SD) of 121.12 (98.30) % as compared to the above studies presented, because the patients enrolled were mostly young adults, had adequate consolidation periods, and the volume calculated was before the ankylosis release that provided more stability.
The progress in symptoms of OSA post-distraction markedly enhanced and boosted the QoL of patients which was analysed based on the OSA-18 questionnaire.23 The results of the questionnaire were subjective based on the patientâ€™s answers and were analysed accordingly. A qualitative study showed a significantly severe form of OSA before surgery which after distraction, improved to a minor form of OSA (Fig. 3). The most affected domains were caregiver concern followed by daily problems, sleep disorder, emotional distress, and the least was physical distress.11 However, clinically significant improvements were present in all domains of the OSA-18 questionnaire (Table 2) after surgery (p = 0.0001). Amaury et al,24 in accordance with the present study, showed the affected domain with respect to caregiver concerns followed by daily problems such as daytime sleepiness and difficulty waking up in the morning followed by sleep disorders such as snoring, as reported by the patient and their attendant/parents. An exceptional result was shown for severe OSA cases regarding retrogenia correction and improving airway volume with symptoms while mild OSA cases also showed improvement regarding all the parameters but less than severe cases.
Despite the clinical relevance of the present study, the results must be interpreted with caution. This is because airway volume was manually calculated on the software, which used arbitrary landmarks, and so created a chance of iatrogenic errors in denotation and led to some calculation errors. Long-term follow up of the study should be done also to check airway volume change after the release of ankylosis.
Conclusion
Quantitative as well as qualitative analysis of OSA depicts substantial improvement and both of their results correlate with each other. Thus, it provides strong evidence that DO significantly increases airway volume, improves AHI, and QoL.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/patient permission
Ref No-IECPG-5/6/29.11.2017, RT-14/20.12.2017. Written informed consent was obtained from all patients.
ChatGPT o3 mini: This prospective study evaluated the efficacy of distraction osteogenesis (DO) in improving airway volume, apnoea-hypopnoea index (AHI), and quality of life (QoL) in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) secondary to temporomandibular joint (TMJ) ankylosis. TMJ ankylosis, a condition that leads to mandibular deformity including retrognathia and deranged occlusion, significantly reduces oropharyngeal space and predisposes patients to OSA. OSA manifests with symptoms such as daytime somnolence, snoring, headaches, and oxygen desaturation, and is diagnosed via polysomnography with an AHI >5. The study enrolled fourteen patients (mean age 17.5 years, predominantly male) meeting criteria of acquired retrognathia with PSG-proven OSA. Using a standard submandibular approach, patients underwent mandibular osteotomy followed by placement of distractors with a latency period of 5â€“7 days and a distraction rate of 1 mm/day, achieving an average advancement of 16.21 mm. Preoperative and postoperative assessments included low dose computed tomography (LDCT) for airway volume analysis, PSG for AHI measurements, and the OSA-18 questionnaire to gauge QoL. Results demonstrated significant improvement, with AHI decreasing from 51.44 to 9.57, airway volume increasing by approximately 121%, and QoL scores showing marked reduction in sleep disorder, physical distress, emotional distress, daily problems, and caregiver concerns. These findings suggest that DO effectively restores airway patency, alleviates OSA symptoms, and enhances overall QoL in TMJ ankylosis patients. Limitations include manual calculation variability and short-term follow-up, warranting further long-term studies to validate sustained benefits. Overall, these results confirm DO as a reliable treatment option, improving airway dimensions and sleep quality in TMJ ankylosis patients.

The prospective study, conducted on 14 patients with PSG-proven OSA, aimed to evaluate changes in upper airway volume and quality of life (QoL) pre- and post-DO.

Title: Effect of tranexamic acid on postoperative blood loss
Author: Wu, Benxing; Lv, Kun
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: The aim of this article was to evaluate the efficacy of tranexamic acid (TXA) to reduce blood loss after maxillofacial fracture surgery. Clinical data were collected retrospectively on patients with unilateral fractures of the zygomaticomaxillary complex (ZMC) or mandibular condyle. Patients were then further divided into TXA and control groups according to whether or not TXA was used after surgery. The amount of postoperative blood loss was evaluated by negative pressure drainage volume. Data were statistically analysed. In patients with unilateral ZMC fractures, total postoperative blood loss in the TXA group was about 30 ml less than that in the control group (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.006). It was significantly less on the first and second postoperative days. However, in patients with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures, there was no significant difference between the TXA and control groups (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.917). TXA can reduce postoperative bleeding in patients with ZMC fractures, and the optimal usage time is on the first and second postoperative days. For patients with mandibular condylar fractures, TXA may not be used.
Body:
Introduction
Tranexamic acid (TXA) is a synthetic derivative of the amino acid lysine, which inhibits fibrinolysis by competitively binding to the lysine receptor domains of plasmin and plasminogen.1,2 TXA is used in the early stage of haemorrhagic trauma to reduce the risk of death,3,4 and also to reduce intraoperative blood loss.5â€“8 However, few studies have focused on the its postoperative effects in patients with maxillofacial fractures. This study aims to explore the haemostatic effect and optimal usage time of TXA after different maxillofacial fracture surgeries.
Material and methods
Patient selection and grouping
Clinical data were collected from patients admitted to the School and Hospital of Stomatology, Wuhan University from September 2020 to August 2022. A total of 131 patients with zygomaticomaxillary complex (ZMC) fractures were investigated of whom 87 were excluded (Table 1). A total of 118 patients with mandibular condylar fractures were investigated of whom 72 were excluded (Table 2). Forty-four patients with unilateral ZMC fractures and 46 with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures were included in the study. The unilateral ZMC fractures were divided into tetropod and comminuted tetropod fractures (Table 3). The unilateral mandibular condylar fractures were divided into condylar head, condylar neck, and condylar base fractures (Table 4). The use of TXA in patients with unilateral ZMC fractures ranged from the day of surgery to the fourth postoperative day. It was used in seven cases until the second postoperative day, in 10 cases until the third postoperative day, and in three until the fourth postoperative day. In patients with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures its use ranged from the day of surgery to the fourth postoperative day. It was used in only one case on the day of surgery, in two until the first postoperative day, in eight until the second postoperative day, four until the third postoperative day, and in one until the fourth postoperative day.

Dosage of TXA
Among the patients in the unilateral ZMC group, 18 received 0.5 g twice a day, and two received 0.5 g once a day. Among the patients in the unilateral mandibular condylar fracture group, 15 received 0.5 g twice a day, and one received 0.5 g once a day.
Inclusion criteria
Male and female patients aged between 18 and 77 years who presented with a unilateral ZMC fracture or unilateral mandibular condylar fracture were included. For unilateral ZMC patients, those who had both hemicoronal and intraoral maxillary sulcus incisions were included. Patients with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures who had a preauricular incision were included, as were those treated with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) and application of closed negative pressure drainage.
Exclusion criteria
Patients who had other incisions, those with coagulation disorders or those on long-term anticoagulants, and patients who had received blood transfusions, were excluded, as were those with pathological fractures, or who had had bone grafts, old fractures (fractures > 3 weeks old), and infection at the fracture area.
Patients in both fracture groups were divided into TXA and control groups according to whether or not TXA was used postoperatively. For patients with unilateral ZMC fractures, 20 were given TXA postoperatively, while the other 24 were not. For patients with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures, 16 were given TXA postoperatively and the other 30 were not. The amount of postoperative blood loss was evaluated by daily negative pressure drainage volume. Clinical data were collected on gender, age, negative pressure drainage volume, and complications.
Data processing
IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows version 20.0 (IBM Corp) was used for data analysis. Quantitative data were examined by the Shapiro-Wilk test and the homogeneity of variance test. Data satisfying the conditions were expressed as mean (standard deviation). The independent samples t-test was used for comparison between the TXA and control groups. Data that did not meet the conditions were expressed as median (interquartile range), and the Mann-Whitney U test was used for comparison. The chi-squared test or Fisher's exact test was used to compare qualitative data. Differences were considered statistically significant when p < 0.05 (two-sided test).
Results
There was no statistically significant difference in gender and age between patients in the TXA and control groups. No patients experienced deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No patients with unilateral ZMC fractures experienced orbital compartment syndrome or retrobulbar haemorrhage.
TXA reduced postoperative blood loss in patients with ZMC fractures
In patients with unilateral ZMC fractures, the total volume of blood loss in the TXA group was reduced by approximately 30 ml compared with the control group (TXA group: 78.64 (24.10) ml; control group: 108.71 (43.37) ml, p = 0.006). On the first and second postoperative days separately, blood loss in the TXA group was significantly less than it was in the control group (first postoperative day p = 0.015, second postoperative day p = 0.021). However, on the third postoperative day, there was no statistical difference in blood loss between the two groups (p = 0.461) (Table 5).

TXA did not significantly reduce postoperative blood loss in patients with mandibular condylar fractures
In patients with unilateral mandibular condylar fractures, there was no significant difference in total blood loss between the TXA and control groups (p = 0.917). Daily blood loss in the first three days after surgery was also not significantly different between the groups (Table 6).

Discussion
TXA is beneficial for patients with ZMC fractures
In our study, it was shown that the postoperative application of TXA effectively reduced blood loss in patients with ZMC fractures. Our results are consistent with research on other parts of the body.9â€“12 However, for patients with mandibular condylar fractures, there seemed to be no such significant haemostatic effect. We speculate that this may be related to the surgical approach. For complex ZMC fractures, a hemicoronal incision combined with an intraoral maxillary sulcus incision is often required. As is well known, scalp tissue is the skin tissue with the most abundant blood supply, and there are multiple anastomotic branches between arteries and between veins.13 Even with electrocoagulation, scalp bleeding cannot be completely stopped. Bleeding can be severe and often requires Raney clips to stop it.14,15 It seems that TXA is more suitable for patients with complex ZMC fractures.
However, the haemostatic effect of TXA on shorter preauricular incisions was not significant. We speculate that this was related to the low amount of bleeding from the preauricular incision. Its skin and subcutaneous layer do not have as many blood vessels, nor do they have numerous hair follicles.16 The main type of postoperative bleeding in the temporomandibular joint area is capillary bleeding. It seems to indicate that TXA may not form blood clots at the capillary level, meaning that TXA may not affect tissue oxygen supply and blood circulation. Of course, further basic and clinical research is needed.
Timing of TXA use
Our data show that in the ZMC fracture group, TXA had the most significant haemostatic effect on the first and second postoperative days. On the third day there was no significant difference. This interesting phenomenon may be related to the mechanism of wound healing. It has been reported that postoperative blood loss occurs most often within 48 hours of surgery.17 By the third postoperative day most bleeding sites had been stopped by the clotting mechanism.18 TXA seems to enhance the haemostatic effect when the body needs to stop bleeding, but it stops working at the end of the physiological haemostatic process. This suggests that the best time to use TXA is within two days of surgery.
Safety
No postoperative thrombosis was observed in any of the patients in our study, which is consistent with the findings of other researchers.3,19â€“21 It indicates that TXA does not increase the risk of thrombosis.
Conclusions
TXA can reduce postoperative bleeding in patients with ZMC fractures, and the optimal usage time is on the first and second postoperative days. For patients with mandibular condylar fractures TXA may not be used.
Acknowledgements
We thank Prof Zubing Li and Prof Zhi Li for their suggestion.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Funding
No funding.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patientâ€™ permission
The study was conducted based on the Declaration of Helsinki, and the protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of the School and Hospital of Stomatology of Wuhan University (Approval number: 2023-B02). All patients were informed that their clinical data might be used for research and informed consents have been obtained.

Title: Efficacy of lasers on reduction of post-surgical lip scar in cleft lip and palate patients: A systematic review
Author: Srivastava, Ayushi; Kale, Tejraj P; Pathak, Radhika; Garg, Akanksha; Bichile, Rahul
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Cleft lip scars, arising from congenital conditions or corrective surgeries, pose unique challenges in scar management, necessitating interventions that balance efficacy with minimally invasive approaches. Laser therapy, with its ability to precisely target scar tissue, has garnered attention for its potential to address hypertrophic scars. The aim of our systematic review is to evaluate the efficacy of lasers in reducing post-surgical cleft lip scar. A systematic search was conducted in PubMed, Google Scholar, Wiley library, Cochrane library databases for the studies published between 1 January 2003 and 1 October 2023. All studies were included in which a laser was used for scar reduction and had a minimum follow-up period of three months. For all study designs the appropriate Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI) critical appraisal tools were used. Primary outcome was to measure reduction in scar using the Vancouver scar scale or total improvement in the scar. From this systematic review we can conclude that lasers have shown better results on post-surgical cleft lip scar. However, more comparative studies are needed with large sample sizes to assess the laser?s pure potential.
Body:
Introduction
Orofacial clefting (OFC) is a range of anomalies seen in newborns, primarily affecting structures around the mouth. It can extend to facial areas, leading to deformities in oral, facial, and craniofacial regions. The primary classification includes isolated cleft palate (CP) and cleft lip (CL), with or without involvement of the palate.1,2
According to a multicentre, hospital-based study involving 94,610 births, the incidence of CL/P was found to be 9.3 cases per 10,000 births, while the incidence of cleft palate stood at 1.7 cases per 10,000 births.3
Individuals born with cleft lip and palate face challenges in feeding, speaking, hearing, and social integration. These can be improved through surgeries, dental treatments, speech therapy, and psychosocial support. Corrective surgery for cleft lip is typically done within the first year of life, between three to six months. Management requires a multidisciplinary team and long-term monitoring.4â€“6
An optimal treatment approach should aim to re-establish regular occlusion and speech functionality, as well as improve facial aesthetics.7 Over the years, several techniques have been suggested (including those by Le Mesuirier in 1949, Tennison in 1952, Cronin in 1966, Millard in 1976, and Noordhoff in 1984) to treat cleft deformities.8,9
The incidence of hypertrophic scar formation following cleft lip repair is seldom reported, and the figures that do exist vary significantly, ranging from 8% to 47%, according to different authors. In a study by Soltani et al, hypertrophic scarring was observed in 25% of patients, while the remaining 75% showed normal wound healing.10 The development of hypertrophic scars (HTS) after cleft lip repair often requires surgical correction. Scar tissue can cause secondary irregularities such as philtrum deformation, Cupid's bow asymmetry, upper lip tightness, whistle deformity, and disruptions in the function of the orbicularis oris muscle. These scars typically develop from three to six months post-surgery due to abnormal wound healing, leading to excessive collagen buildup and inflammation. Normal skin is replaced by nonfunctional fibrous tissue, resulting in functional and cosmetic deformities.11â€“14
Cleft lip scar management options include surgical and non-surgical approaches. Non-surgical methods include silicone gel/cream, taping, scar massages, Botulinum toxin injections, and laser therapy. Some methods like silicone gel sheets, can pose challenges such as ingestion in infants.15â€“17
Lasers have been used for treating hypertrophic scars and keloids for 30 years. Various types of lasers are available depending on their wavelength and mechanism of action.18
This systematic review is done to answer the question: Is laser an effective treatment modality for reducing post-surgical cleft lip scar?
This systematic review aims to evaluate the effectiveness of laser treatments on post-surgical cleft lip scars.
Material and methods
Eligibility criteria
Inclusion criteria
All studies in which a laser was used on human population and Vancouver scar scale or total scar improvement was used to see the efficacy in scar reduction. The studies published between 2003-2023 were included with a minimum follow-up period of three months. Study designs included were randomised controlled trials, clinical trials, retrospective studies, or cross-sectional studies.
Exclusion criteria
The exclusion criteria included studies in foreign languages, animal studies, letter or opinion articles, case reports, and studies in which non cleft scars were treated with laser. Age was not a criterion for exclusion.
PICOS pattern
Population: patients in which surgical repair of cleft lip or revision surgery for scars was done and presented with hypertrophic scar postoperatively.
Intervention: any type of laser used for treating post-surgical/post-repair cleft lip scar.
Comparison: with or without any control group. Comparison can be to any other treatment modality used for reduction of post-surgical cleft lip scar.
Primary outcome: reduction in scar by using Vancouver scar scale or total improvement in the scar.
Secondary outcomes: pain by using visual analogue scale, scar appearance and complications associated.
Information source
An extensive electronic search was conducted for articles published from 1 January 2003 to 1 October 2023, in the following databases: PubMed, Google Scholar, Wiley Library, and Cochrane. Two investigators independently performed the literature search. Manual methods were used for the literature search when electronic databases did not provide access to relevant full texts. Titles and abstracts were screened, and authors were contacted if full texts were unavailable. Cross-references and citations from related studies were also examined.
Search strategy
The keywords used for the literature search are: â€˜Cleft lip,â€™ â€˜Scar,â€™ â€˜Cleft lip scar,â€™ â€˜Laser,â€™ â€˜Lip scar.â€™
These key words were clubbed and an advanced search was done in each database using these keywords (Table 1): (cleft lip) AND (scar); (cleft lip) AND (laser); (cleft lip scar) AND (laser); ((cleft lip) AND (scar)) AND (laser).

Search strategy in databases.
Open table in a new tab
Study selection
Two reviewers independently screened the data. Initial screening was based on title and abstract, with full-text articles obtained for studies lacking sufficient information. Upon obtaining full-text articles the studies were assessed for eligibility and any uncertainty regarding study eligibility was resolved through discussion between the reviewers. Ultimately, six studies suitable for inclusion in the systematic review were identified. Excluded studies were documented, along with reasons for exclusion. Authors were not blinded to journal titles, study authors, or institutions.
Data collection
After a thorough screening of the relevant studies, six full text articles that met the inclusion criteria were included in the review. All the duplicates were removed. Data collection was done independently by reviewers and any incompatibilities were resolved through discussion between the reviewers. The data was then extracted into a standard tabular form using Microsoft Excel.
Data items
Data items included for extracting the data were: Authorâ€™s name/year, Study design, Sample size, Comparison group, Intervention group, Number of sessions, Outcomes measured and Study conclusion.
Risk of bias of individual studies
For all studies the appropriate Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI) critical appraisal tools were used.19â€“21 Any disagreement between the reviewers was resolved through discussion.
Results
Screening process
Databases were screened for articles in English by using a combination of keywords. Thirty-two articles were screened in total and 17 articles remained after removing the duplicates. Finally, six articles that met the inclusion criteria were included in this review. The article selection process is shown in the PRISMA Flow diagram (Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Prisma flow chart.
Study characteristics
In the final six articles, a total of 310 cleft lip patients with post-surgical scars were included in these studies. A complete data extraction was done from the included articles and is stated in Table 2.

Results of individual studies
The included six studies were: one randomised controlled trial, three non-randomised controlled trials, one retrospective study, and one cross sectional study. Out of all the studies, two did not have any control group. The other four studies compared lasers with normal surgical repair, silica gel massage, or corticosteroid creams. The type of lasers that were used in the studies were low power diode laser, fractional CO2, and intense pulsed light with lattice CO2.
Mohsen et al.22 conducted a trial to assess the efficacy of low power diode lasers on cleft lip scars in 60 patients using the Vancouver scar scale and ultrasound. Significant scar reduction (p=0.008) occurred, with a reduction in thickness of the scar by day 14 and improvement appearance by day seven. Jahanbin et al in 2019 conducted a study23 to assess the effectiveness of fractional CO2 lasers in 12 cleft lip scar patients without a control group. The patientsâ€™ satisfaction was achieved along with scar quality improvement by 25%â€“50% and reduced upper lip muscle activity seen in electromyography. In a study by Peng et al.,24 25 cleft lip scar patients were treated by intense pulsed light and lattice CO2 in Group 1 while the Group 2 patients underwent conventional surgery followed by scar cream massage and silica gel products. Group 1 patients had shown significant scar reduction at three and six months postoperatively compared with Group 2 (p = 0.025, p = 0.002, respectively). A cross-sectional trial by Mossaad et al.25 included six cleft lip scar patients and assessed the effectiveness of fractional CO2 diode laser. There was significant scar reduction according to Vancouver scar scale and improved patient satisfaction. Shadad et al in 2021 conducted a non-randomised controlled trial26 on 120 cleft lip scar patients. Patients were divided into three groups; Group 1 received fractional CO2 therapy three weeks after surgery, Group 2 began fractional CO2 laser therapy three months after surgery and Group 3 used corticosteroid cream and silica gel for six months after surgery. Group 1 showed significant scar reduction and a high visual analogue scale score compared with Groups 2 and 3. Chi et al conducted a randomised controlled trial27 on 42 patients. These 42 patients were divided into three groups; Group 1 received fractional CO2 laser one month postoperatively, Group 2 received fractional CO2 laser three months postoperatively and group 3 received fractional CO2 six months postoperatively. The study showed significant scar reduction in Group 1 compared with Group 2 and 3, assessed one month post-therapy using the Vancouver scar scale.
Risk of bias in studies
Quality of the included studies were assessed individually by the reviewers by using JBI tool for critical appraisal for all the included studies (Table 3â€“6). Quality ranking was allocated as low (less than 33%), medium (33%â€“66%) or high (over 66%). Out of six studies, two studies were of medium quality while the other four studies were of high quality.

Discussion
Hypertrophic scarring typically develops within three to six months after the initial injury. Once formed, the scar may remain stable in size or begin to regress. In cleft lip patients, this regression can result in a shortened lip on the affected side. Hypertrophic scars remain localised to the original wound site, primarily increasing in size through growth in the perpendicular plane rather than lateral invasion. Aesthetic complication is a challenge to treat in cleft lip patients as facial expressions are vital for nonverbal communication, influencing how individuals convey emotions and thoughts. Achieving acceptable facial appearance and movements is crucial for their perceived self-worth. Cleft lip scar treatments aim to address both physical and psychological aspects to improve self-esteem and social confidence, ultimately enhancing overall well-being.28â€“31
Laser therapy has emerged as a promising modality for cleft lip scar reduction, offering distinct advantages when compared with other treatment options. Traditional methods for addressing cleft lip scars have included surgical interventions, topical treatments, and corticosteroid injections. Compared with surgical interventions, laser therapy generally involves less downtime, shorter recovery period and can be done under topical anaesthesia, which minimises risk of general anaesthesia. However, laser therapy presents a non-invasive and targeted approach with several notable benefits that include precise control over the depth of tissue penetration, enabling healthcare professionals to specifically target scar tissue without affecting surrounding healthy skin.32â€“34
Various lasers frequently employed for hypertrophic scars have been proven effective in addressing different aspects of these scars. Single or combination of these lasers have showed an effective result for improving the scars in patients.35
Laser types can be broadly categorised as ablative or nonablative. In the current review, studies by Jahanbin et al.,23 Mossaad et al.,25 Shadad et al.26 and Chi et al.27 used ablative lasers, such as a fractional CO2 laser in their studies, and had seen a significant reduction in the post-surgical cleft lip scar. A prominent treatment option for surgical and atrophic scars is fractional ablative laser resurfacing. Microscopic thermal treatment zones, or columns of thermal damage are divided from surrounding untreated skin in fractional ablative resurfacing. Since just a portion of the skin is affected, there is less downtime and a quicker rate of re-epithelialisation. Additionally, fractional lasers can penetrate the skin deeper than completely ablative lasers due to the microthermal therapy zones. CO2 lasers stimulate the wound's renewal processes and promote the growth of myofibroblasts and matrix proteins like hyaluronic acid.36
The study by Chi et al.27 also assessed the optimum time for laser therapy and they concluded that if therapy started at one month postoperatively there is a significant reduction in scarring.
Another ablative option for scar reduction is the erbium-doped yttrium aluminium garnet (Er:YAG) laser. It has two mechanisms; first is epidermal vaporisation, which necessitates skin resurfacing by the dermal appendages for the skin to recover. Second, heat damage to the dermis promotes the formation of collagen, which enhances the look of photodamaged skin and lessens the visibility of rhytids and scars. Moreover, the vaporising water serves as a heat sink, reducing the quantity of thermal injury to the surrounding tissues. Er: YAG lasers can pass over the same target area more than once during a single treatment session because of this cooling, which improves results while requiring fewer treatment sessions. In a case series Er: YAG was used on ten cleft patients, and it stated that the laser showed improvement in scar length, pliability and colour with less erythema.37
But due to the extended recovery time and associated risks, such as scarring, depigmentation, and infection, non-ablative lasers have been introduced. Non ablative lasers target specific elements like oxyhaemoglobin or melanin, following an exponentially decreasing absorption curve, with the highest absorption in the ultraviolet range.
In a clinical study, pulsed dye laser (PDL) was used along with fractional CO2 laser for treating moderate-severe cleft lip scars. They concluded that there was 50% in reduction of scar height, texture, pliability, and erythema. The mechanism of the PDL involves photo thermolysis of neovascularised tissue in hypertrophic scars, resulting in a decrease in inflammation, tissue hypoxia, and the stimulation of neocollagenesis.38,39
Recent studies have suggested that inadequate regulation of interleukin (IL)-6 signalling pathways and the expression of transforming growth factor beta-I (TGF-Î²I) play a significant role in this process. Low-level laser therapy (LLLT) reduces IL-6 mRNA levels.40 In the study by Mohsen et al, low power diode laser 806nm was used on 60 cleft patients. The patients underwent 12 session of laser therapy, and it showed a significant improvement in the scar with respect to scar height, pliability, and vascularity.22
Intense pulsed light (IPL) devices are non-laser high intensity light sourceswhich have been used recently for scar reduction. The precise mechanism of action remains unknown. However, it can serve as a cost-effective alternative to therapies such as PDL and CO2 laser. In a study conducted in Turkey, 109 patients with hypertrophic scars underwent an average of eight sessions of IPL. Remarkably, over 90% of the patients showed significant improvement in height, erythema, and hardness.41,42 A retrospective study by Peng et al.24 used IPL and Lattice CO2 to treat cleft lip scarring and significant reduction in scar was seen during follow up after three and six months.
These lasers, which have been used for scar reduction on the cleft lip patients, have demonstrated better efficacy in enhancing the appearance of postoperative scars and can be recommended as an adjunctive treatment for patients seeking superior aesthetic outcomes. While surgical intervention typically results in an acceptable postoperative scar, hypertrophic scars often have a tendency to recur. Therefore, rather than opting for surgical scar revision, laser therapy can be considered. This treatment has minimal side effects and is unlikely to worsen the scar. Laser therapy can notably enhance aesthetics, particularly in patients prone to hypertrophic scarring.10 It is important to note that laser therapy may impose additional financial burdens on families due to expenses, multiple appointments, and extended treatment durations. However, the findings from these studies indicate promising results for achieving favourable aesthetic outcomes. Other minor complications associated with this are pain while the therapy is ongoing, crusting of the wound, and erythema.
The reviewed studies exhibited several limitations: Follow-up periods were inconsistent, outcome measurements varied, and one of the studies did not use a standard assessment scale. Additionally, inconsistencies were observed in the point of laser application, and optimal timing for therapy initiation was not consistently reported. A lack of randomised controlled trials was also seen. There is also a lack of evidence on the reaction of different skin types to the laser treatment.
The systematic review identifies several future implications. Firstly, further investigation into the unclear mechanisms of the action of lasers is necessary to improve understanding and refine treatment strategies for cleft lip scars. Secondly, there is a need for more randomised controlled trials (RCTs) to compare the efficacy of laser treatments with other non-invasive methods. Thirdly, future research should prioritise the assessment of patient satisfaction as a crucial outcome measure. Lastly, consensus guidelines should be established regarding the optimal timing to initiate laser therapy and standardise follow-up protocols across studies. Also, numerous NGOs supporting cleft patient treatments across several countries could consider integrating this approach as an adjunctive method for managing postoperative scars. Doing so would elevate the quality of treatment, lead to improved outcomes, and potentially lower treatment expenses for patients.
Conclusion
From this systematic review we can state that lasers have shown a significant effect on scar reduction on cleft lip patients. It has also shown a decrease in muscle activity of the upper lip. Different lasers were used in the included studies, the most common of which was fractional CO2. According to this review we can conclude that early use of fractional CO2, such as one month postoperatively, has shown better results in scar reduction. It requires fewer sessions to show a satisfactory result, thus reducing time and the cost of the treatment. The study in which low power diode laser was used required 12 sessions (three sessions per week) to show a significant reduction in scarring. This will increase the cost and number of visits of the patients. Lastly, IPL the lattice CO2 was used in the study by Peng et al and treatment needed to be for six months postoperatively to show a significant result, which also increases treatment time and number of visits.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Funding
This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
No ethics approval needed. No patient consent needed.
Registration and protocol
The study followed the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic review and Meta-analysis (PRISMA) guidelines 2020 checklist. The review has been officially documented within PROSPERO and can be found under registration number CRD42022385054 on the website.

Title: Efficacy of the Hegab temporomandibular joint splint in treating patients diagnosed with dystonia with or without systemic involvement: A report of 14 cases
Author: Hegab, Ayman F; Shahien, Mohamed; {Abd Al hameed}, Hossam I
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Dystonia is a neurological motor disorder characterised by involuntary and uncontrollable muscle contractions, tension, twisting, and tremors. The aim of the present study was to analyse the improvement in dystonic contractions in patients with dystonia following the use of a Hegab temporomandibular joint splint (HTS). The Fahn-Marsden Dystonia Movement Scale (DMS) and Disability Scale were used in the current study to evaluate dystonia. An HTS with a thickness ranging from 4 to 6Â¬â€ mm was used to treat the patients enrolled in the study. The final sample comprised 14 patients (10 female and four male) with mean (range) ages of 35.64 (18 to 55) years. Pre-treatment DMS ranged from 6.5 to 57 mean (SD) 18.21 (13.38). At the end of the study, DMS ranged from 0 to 15 mean (SD) 3.14 (3.86). Statistical analysis of the differences between pre-treatment and post-treatment DMS showed a significant decrease in DMS at the end of the treatment period (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.0001). Regarding the disability scale, pre-treatment disability scale ranged from 7 to 18 mean (SD) 9.46 (3.02). At the end of the study, DMS ranged from 0 to 3 mean (SD) 1.46 (1.13). There was a statistically highly significant decrease in the Disability Scale at the end of the treatment period (p value â€šÃ¢Â§ 0.0001). This study suggests that the HTS can be considered an effective treatment modality for dystonia, as it significantly decreases both the DMS and the Disability scale.
Body:
Introduction
Dystonia is a movement disorder characterised by involuntary and persistent severe muscle contractions that lead to rhythmic and atypical movements in various parts of the body. Based on the aetiopathogenesis, it can be categorised as focal, segmental, multifocal, or generalised. Based on the aetiology, dystonia can be categorised into primary dystonia (idiopathic or inherited) and secondary dystonia, which develops after traumatic or surgical incidents, brain diseases, or as a result of medications.1
Oromandibular dystonia (OMD) is a focal dystonia of the oral cavity. It is a rare focal neurological disorder that affects the lower facial muscles and is characterised by repetitive or sustained involuntary prolonged spastic movements of the tongue, facial, and masticator muscles. OMD is classified into jaw-opening, jaw-closing, jaw deviation, lingual dystonia, or a combination of these.2,3
Meigeâ€™s syndrome is the combination of OMD, blepharospasm, and dystonic movements of the upper face.4 Tongue protrusion is usually a component of OMD or Meigeâ€™s syndrome. Other terms for OMD include orofaciomandibular dystonia, orofacial-buccal dystonia, lingual dystonia, jaw dystonia, cranial dystonia, and adult-onset facial dystonia.2â€“4
Clinical presentations vary based on the affected muscles as well as the severity and distribution of OMD.2 Dysfunctions include impaired mastication, dysphagia, dysphonia, unconscious opening and closing of the mandible, pulling and twisting of the mandible forward or laterally, and temporomandibular disorders (TMD) such as open locks.3,4
However, the mechanisms and causes of OMD are poorly understood. OMD may occur as a neurological disorder or secondary to certain drugs or disorders such as trauma or Wilsonâ€™s disease.2
Diagnosis of OMD is complicated because its clinical presentation is not uniform. The diagnosis is based on individual information, history, clinical examination, neurological examination, and confirmation through intramuscular electromyography.5
OMD treatment is multidisciplinary, and the efficacy of different treatment modalities has not been adequately evaluated.4 However, anticholinergic drugs, baclofen, benzodiazepines, anti-Parkinson drugs, and anticonvulsants are some of the agents used to manage OMD.
Botulinum neurotoxin (BoNT) injections are considered a promising therapy for treating OMD.6 Swallowing difficulties, speech problems, and excessive muscle weakness have been reported in the treatment of lingual dystonia using BoNT.7 Deep brain stimulation surgery has been reported to be an effective and safe treatment.8
This prospective clinical study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the Hegab temporomandibular joint (TMJ) splint (HTS) in the treatment of dystonia.
Patients and methods
The study followed all tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki for research involving human subjects and was reviewed and approved by the Institutional Review Board of Al-Azhar University School of Dentistry. Written informed consent was obtained from all patients enrolled in the study.
Inclusion criteria
Patients between the ages of 18 and 70 years, who were referred to the clinic with complaints of bruxism and/or myofascial pain, jaw movement disorders, or TMD, were diagnosed with dystonia by a neurology specialist.
Exclusion criteria
For this study exclusion criteria included systemic diseases (the presence of polyarthritis or other rheumatic diseases), congenital anomalies, and previous treatment for dystonia (such as Botox).
This study was conducted at the Faculty of Dental Medicine, Al-Azhar University and Hegab Academy for Maxillofacial and TMJ Disorders from October 2018 to October 2022.
Sample size calculation
A power analysis was conducted using the statistical program G*Power version 3.1 by Franz Faul, based on previously conducted trial cases involving OMD. The input parameters were a power of 0.80, and an error probability of 0.05. The results indicated that a sample size of at least 12 participants was necessary.9
Clinical diagnosis of oromandibular dystonia
Blepharospasm; involuntary jaw opening and closing; jaw deviation; involuntary tongue movement; platysma muscle spasm; eating dysfunction; retraction of lips or lip pursing; cervical dystonia (spasmodic torticollis); limb dystonia (musicianâ€™s dystonia, writerâ€™s cramp); and difficulty chewing, eating, and speaking, owing to the inability to control jaw movement, are the observed symptoms. Patients diagnosed with dystonia were referred to a neurologist for consultation and confirmation of the diagnosis.
Another psychological consultation was conducted with all patients enrolled in the study to confirm or exclude the presence of psychological disorders.
The Fahn-Marsden Dystonia Movement Scale (DMS) and Disability Scale10,11 were used in this study. A detailed description of the DMS is provided in Table 1.

Because of associated TMJ disorders, all patients enrolled in the study underwent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of both TMJ. The MRI scans were obtained using a dental silicone latex mouth prop (bite-block rubber mouth opener). MRI images were evaluated for the presence or absence of disc displacement and osteoarthritis by a radiologist with more than 15 years of experience in MRI of TMJ disorders.12,13
The HTS13 was used to treat patients with all types of dystonia enrolled in this study. The HTS is a maxillary full-arch hard-stabilisation splint fabricated using a fluid resin. The splint was attached to the upper jaw using ball clasps without any extension of the acrylic resin on the buccal or labial surface of the upper jaw. The HTS has deep indentations on its occlusal surface to guide and hold the mandible at maximum intercuspation using bite registration records and study casts to prevent lateral dystonic movements. The selection of the vertical thickness of the occlusal splint depends on the MRI findings13 and the severity of dystonia. Based on the MRI measurements and clinical outcome records of Hegab et al,14 a 4 mm vertical splint thickness is recommended for disc displacement with reduction (DDR) and a 6 mm thickness is recommended for disc displacement without reduction (DDNR).
The dystonia movement and disability scales were recorded pre-treatment and at the end of the treatment period. The results were collected, tabulated, and statistically analysed. The significance level was set at p < 0.05. Descriptive statistics and chi squared (Ï‡2) tests were performed to compare the variables. Data were analysed using InStat statistical software (GraphPad Software Inc).
Results
During the study period, 450 patients were screened for eligibility. Based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria, as well as clinical and neurological evaluations, only 15 patients were diagnosed with dystonia. One patient with Meige syndrome was edentulous (and therefore unable to be treated with the HTS), treated with Botox injection, and excluded from our study (the patient had a history of haemorrhagic stroke).
The final sample comprised 14 patients (10 female and four male). Two patients were diagnosed with systemic dystonia, four with Meige syndrome, and eight with OMD. The patientsâ€™ ages ranged from 18 to 55 (mean 35.64) years.
The jaw-opening type of OMD was found in 5/14 patients, while 3/14 patients had the jaw-closing type. Additionally, 6/14 patients had a mixed form (both jaw closing and opening) of OMD, and lingual dystonia was present in 10/14 patients.
Two patients had multiple sclerosis; two were Khat addicts; two had obsessive-compulsive disorder and were undergoing medical treatment; seven had depression; and one had no significant comorbidities.
MRI evaluation showed that 10 patients had TMJ osteoarthritis; three, DDR; three, DDNR; one, unilateral dislocation; one, joint effusion; and four, disc degeneration. Conversely, three had normal MRI findings.
The treatment period ranged from three months to one year, and the follow-up period ranged from six months to two years. Table 2 presents the descriptive data of the patients enrolled in this study.

Regarding the disability scale, pre-treatment disability scale ranged from 7 to 18 mean (SD) 9.46 (3.02), and at the end of the study, DMS ranged from 0 to 3 mean (SD) 1.46 (1.13). In the two patients diagnosed with systemic dystonia, the use of HTS resulted in immediate changes in posture, including body alignment, head shift, head tilt, and shoulder alignment. These changes were confirmed by the treating orthopaedic physician. The splint was used for six months to one year with follow-up periods ranging from nine to 18 months. The patients were administered clonazepam and gabapentin.
