Historically, oral and maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) has been pursued predominantly by dental graduates who later obtain a medical degree. Recently, however, increasing numbers of medicine-first graduates are exploring OMFS, highlighting the need for enhanced exposure and educational resources. In response, an online conference was developed to boost awareness and interest among undergraduate medical students.

The one-day event, conducted via Zoom, comprised six lecture sessions and a research competition. Lectures were delivered by post-certificate of completion of training (CCT) OMFS surgeons, an associate OMFS professor, and a fully qualified dentist. Key topics included trauma management, academic pathways in OMFS, dental conditions, and the treatment of malignant or premalignant oral lesions. Title: How good is good enough? Lessons learned from review of outcomes of 50 patients following extraoral open reduction and internal fixation of condylar neck and base fractures at a regional major trauma centre
Author: Leow, Julian; Exley, Rebecca; Holmes, Simon; Bhatti, Nabeel
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: The management of mandibular fractures is routine owing to their frequency, particularly those of the mandibular condyle, which are invariably common. Notwithstanding disparities in the literature, the international consensus towards which fractures of the mandibular condyle benefit from open surgical intervention is almost universally accepted. Closed reduction or non-operative management may be utilised in certain circumstances. Whilst outcome research has addressed complications with respect to operative side effects, outcomes related to the quality of bone repair and the setting in which this is delivered have not been universally addressed. The aim of this study was to determine the predictability of translating an indicated operative treatment plan into an acceptable functional result. We evaluated the outcomes of 59 extracapsular condylar fractures in 50 patients who were treated by extraoral open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) between March 2021 and August 2022. We reviewed demographic data, surgical approach, and plating strategy, and critically evaluated the clinical and radiological outcomes. Whilst we found that the quality of reduction was not universally perfect, the majority were within tolerance, which we set according to the Strasbourg Osteosynthesis Research Group (SORG) definition for minimal displacement (<2Â¬â€ mm overlap and 10Â¬âˆž angulation). The cohort had good functional occlusion and minimal long-term postoperative complications. Two patients required re-operation for non-union, and we discuss causality in these cases. In conclusion, we found that ORIF of condylar neck and base fractures is predictable in real-time surgical practice with respect to functional outcome. However, if imperfectly reduced, there is a small risk of non-union.
Body:
Introduction
There is increasing evidence from clinical research studies and international consensus that the standard of care for displaced and angulated condylar neck and base fractures is open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).1,2 Symptomatic and functional improvement with respect to interincisal opening, movement, pain, and malocclusion have been observed. Traditional closed reduction, whilst avoiding injury to the facial nerve and external scarring, is less favoured as techniques have evolved.3
The seminal paper that established an accepted threshold for open reduction demonstrated an advantage for ORIF in cases with 2 mm overlap and 10Â° angulation.4 Whilst surgeons can be more confident of both the indications and surgical approach, we know of little written about the quality of reduction and resultant functional outcome in ORIF of condylar neck and base fractures. The aim of this study therefore was to find out if our practice allows for the translation of the treatment plan into an acceptable radiological and functional outcome.
In keeping with modern surgical practice, the operative procedures were performed by oral and maxillofacial (OMF) surgeons with varying experience. Complex cases were managed by subspecialist trauma OMF surgeons.
Patients and methods
We conducted a retrospective review of all patients with condylar neck and base fractures who were treated by ORIF at our unit between March 2021 and August 2022. The study was registered with the audit department and no identifiable patient information was recorded. Patients were identified from theatre lists and the weekly trauma multidisciplinary (MDT) meeting, and entered on to a secure centralised Microsoft Excel spreadsheet.
Classification system
We used the standard classification for condylar fracture by Loukota et al, which we find highly predictive of operative difficulty.5 Fractures of the condylar neck and base were subclassified according to the revised Strasbourg Osteosynthesis Research Group (SORG) criterion: the one-third to two-thirds rule with reference to the proportion of the fracture line above and below the level of the sigmoid notch.
Data collection
The following parameters were recorded: age, time of fracture, medical and surgical history, smoking, and alcohol consumption. With respect to management, the type of fracture, associated maxillofacial injuries, approach, and plating strategy, were recorded.
Treatment indication
The operative indication was an overlap of more than 2 mm or angulation of 10Â° of the condyle.4 All patients were reviewed at a dedicated trauma MDT irrespective of operating surgeon.
Evaluation and outcomes
The primary outcome measure was radiological accuracy which was independently reviewed on a Sectra PACS (Sectra Ltd) workstation by two surgeons for degree of residual shortening and angulation. The outcome tolerance defined a good outcome as <2 mm overlap and <10Â° angulation of the condyle. We defined suboptimal outcome as >2 mm overlap and or >10Â° angulation.
We recorded functional outcomes related to the surgical approach and fixation: trismus, use of TheraBiteÂ® (Atos Medical), facial nerve injury, Frey syndrome, sialocele, requirement for botulinum toxin, and malocclusion.
Follow up
In keeping with our standard operating procedure, outcomes were reviewed at standardised intervals at our MDT clinic by OMF, psychology, and restorative and periodontology clinicians. All complications were recorded contemporaneously.
Results
Demographic data
This study identified 50 patients with a median (range) age of 38 (15-69) years. A total of 55 condyles were managed operatively and four needed revision surgery. Three patients were aged between 61 and 70, six between 51 and 60, eight between 41 and 50, 12 between 31 and 40, 19 between 21 and 30, and two between 11 and 20, with the youngest being 15 years old. Of the 50 patients, 40 were male and 10 female. Eighteen were American Society of Anesthesiologists grade (ASA) I and 32 were grade II. Sixteen smoked. The commonest aetiology was interpersonal violence (20/50 patients) followed by a fall from standing (15/50). Five patients had been involved in a road traffic accident, five had fallen off a bicycle, two had fallen off an escooter/eskateboard, two had jumped from a height, and one had a sports injury.
Fracture location
A total of 14/50 patients had isolated condylar fractures, 16 had condylar and parasymphysis fractures, five had condylar and body fractures, five had guardsman fractures, five had panfacial fractures, and five had condylar fractures with other concomitant fractures. The majority (48/59 condyles) were condylar base fractures, with the remaining condyles having neck fractures.
Surgical approach
The incision was transcutaneous in all patients. Thirty of 59 exposures were retromandibular anteroparotid, 19 were retromandibular transparotid, one was coronal retromandibular, four were other sites, and five were not recorded.
All patients were managed postoperatively with mobilisation except for five who had intermaxillary fixation (IMF).
Of the 59 condyles, the commonest plating strategy was a four-hole miniplate posteriorly and two-hole miniplate anteriorly (38/59), followed by a trapezoid plate (8/59). (Table 1)
         No. of condyles(n = 59)
2-hole anterior, 4-hole posterior        38
Trapezoidal        8
4-hole anterior, 4-hole posterior        5
4-hole posterior        2
2-hole anterior, 2-hole mid, 2-hole posterior        1
2-hole anterior, 6-hole posterior        1
3-hole anterior, 4-hole posterior        1
Y-shape anterior, 4-hole posterior        1

Lag screw anterior and 2x 4-hole plates        1
Table 1

Clinical outcomes
Primary revision rate (1 of 59 condyles)
Case 1 was a 33-year-old male with a condylar base fracture, who was fit and well. The complexity of the fracture was incompletely appreciated on computed tomography (CT) and perioperatively, an undisplaced high ramus fracture was mistaken for the displaced condylar base fracture. He underwent subsequent ORIF of the condylar base fracture (see Clinical pearls section for radiological detail) (Fig. 3).
Secondary revision rate (2 of 59 condyles)
Case 2 was a 64-year-old female with stage II non-Hodgkin lymphoma who underwent ORIF of a condylar neck fracture with suboptimal ORIF utilising a trapezoidal plate with a screw in the line of the fracture. She had a sialocele that was managed with aspiration and botulinum toxin. She required re-ORIF and a bone graft (see Clinical pearls section).
Case 3 was a 45-year-old female current smoker with malnourishment. She underwent ORIF of a condylar base fracture with a four-hole posterior plate and two-hole anterior plate with good reduction. Subsequent fixation failure and non-union were attributed to secondary trauma complicated by medical factors, and she required re-ORIF and a bone graft.
Complications
Complications are detailed in Table 2. In our series, no patients experienced permanent facial nerve weakness. Two had a minimal lateral open bite that resolved, and one had a class 3 malocclusion that was likely to have been pre-existing.
Complication        No. of patients
(n = 50)
Temporary facial nerve weakness        4
Temporary lateral open bite        5
Sialocele        2
Persistent pain        4
Non-union        2
Missed condyle        1
Malocclusion        3
Table 2
Complications following ORIF.
Open table in a new tab
Radiological outcomes
Postoperative reduction was independently scored by two OMFS surgeons with reference to reduction and angulation, as defined by the SORG criteria. Postoperatively 49/59 condyles had <2 mm overlap, and 52/59 had <10Â° angulation. Additionally, anterior and posterior radiological reduction was scored and a tolerance of 2 mm set. Postoperatively 44/59 condyles had <2 mm anterior reduction and 56/59 had <2 mm posterior reduction.
Four patients had combined poor anterior and posterior reduction, two of whom had trapezoid plates (one had two plates and one had lag screws).
Discussion
There is little doubt that there has been an evolution in surgical management following numerous low powered case series6,7 and opinion papers,8â€“10 augmented by a meta-analysis11 and international consensus meetings.12 The relative lag in this surgical revolution is due to the acceptability of IMF as a low-risk procedure that can be enacted by junior staff with an adequate outcome. The technically challenging open reduction, which Ellis et al refers to as â€˜lush with anatomical hazardsâ€™, requires an experienced surgeon with a steep learning curve, but has definable advantages with regard to function and appearance postoperatively.13 Over the course of time these advantages are becoming accepted and surgical morbidity is acceptable. Should the fracture be fixed anatomically, the use of IMF should be questioned.
In fractures affecting the dentate portion of the mandible, the same question arises, although Christensen et al highlighted the fact that a short period of IMF could potentially reduce the risk of surgical site infection in fractures of the mandibular angle.14 The case for IMF in the plated condyle remains to be justified. Our case series represents a transparent review of objective outcomes achieved by surgeons of differing experience who employed a variety of techniques, all evidence based and practised routinely. We believe that this reflects pragmatic practice in a modern trauma centre. All ultimate outcomes were satisfactory, although reflective analysis has demonstrated some key learning points.
The commonest surgical approach was retromandibular, both transparotid and anteroparotid, each with minimal temporary complication (four cases each of temporary mild weakness that resolved in two months). The two sialoceles were managed conservatively and resolved in four weeks. The anteroparotid approach has the advantage of reducing sialocele formation, but is difficult to achieve in patients with alcoholic sialosis,15 whilst the transparotid approach enables relative protection of the nerve within the parotid gland.6,16
Osteosynthesis was achieved by different plating strategies, a two-plate (spaced four-hole, and spaced two-hole) versus a trapezoid plate primarily, or a mixed technique for more abstract fracture patterns. The use of IMF was unusual in the series (n = 5). Indications were additional complex fractures in the dentate mandible (n = 1), the need to support wound healing (n = 1), the need to encourage maximum intercuspation (n = 1), and for reassurance (n = 2).
Reduction was largely satisfactory. There was good alignment of bony fragments with 49/59 cases remaining with less than 2 mm shortening (59/59 within 5 mm) and 52/59 with less than 10Â° angulation. This produced a satisfactory occlusal outcome in all but two cases.
Medium-term complications included two non-unions, one due to surgical error following the application of a trapezoid plate with one screw in the fracture line, the second attributed to heavy bruxism. Both required re-operation. For this reason, the authors advocate the use of cone-beam CT (CBCT) with a small field of view to evaluate postsurgical reduction.
The concept of medium to long-term change was introduced by Ellis et al13 who reported that 10%â€“20% of plated fractures developed a worsening final position by six months postoperatively without functional discrepancy. The authors commented that miniplates should be avoided if active mobilisation of the mandible is required because a certain number will fracture. In their series of 61 cases they noted two cases of plate bending and three loose screws, so hardware predictability remains unproven.13 With respect to postoperative IMF, the precise definition is open to interpretation; elastic guidance was used to support those with an imperfect occlusion. In a refreshing series, Nys et al,17 who compared conservative management (IMF versus IMF with open reduction), found malocclusion in 24% of cases, and secondary surgery was required in 25% of cases. Whilst there was likely to have been selection bias, the group found that bilateral cases were more likely to suffer occlusal discrepancy. This supports the conclusions of the conference at Groningen which considered unilateral condylar fractures separately.12 Our results do not support the need for routine postoperative IMF for the majority of condylar fractures, and it is reserved to control malunion in the event of inadequate reduction, or when open reduction is not offered.
Clinical pearls
CT-based imaging allows for accurate assessment of the position of the condylar minor fragment, the presence of secondary fractures, and the nature of the fracture site itself. It is important to place screws either side of the fracture where the buccal and lingual cortices are present. In fractures of a sagittal nature, the screw may distract the fracture.
Imaging
Prior to surgery it is important to appreciate the 3-dimensional (3D) anatomy. This allows for appropriate planning, and the assessment of comminution, angulation, displacement, and oblique fractures, which may not be evident on radiographs.18
Lingual flange evaluation
Oblique fracture patterns result in a lingual flange that cannot be appreciated on plain film radiography. In such situations, CT permits operative planning and the authors advocate a four-hole spaced and two-hole anterior plating strategy to avoid a screw in the line of the fracture. Postopertive reduction is well visualised using small-field-of-view CBCT (Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Posterior view of a preoperative 3D CT of a left condylar base fracture showing medial override and oblique fracture with a lingual flange
Surgical technique- traction screw
Due to muscle pull, access, and fracture pattern, it can sometimes be difficult to reduce condylar fractures adequately. For these cases we use a traction screw and a transcutaneously-placed 0.5 mm stainless steel wire (via a large cannula) to aid intraoperative reduction and establish the posterior height (Fig. 2).

Fig. 2 3D reformat CT of a left condylar fracture showing placement of 2 hole anterior and 4 hole posterior plates with screw hole for the interoperative traction screw (arrow)
Complications following ORIF: suboptimal cases
Revision case 1 â€“ primary revision required
This case highlights the difficulty of this procedure and failure to appreciate the surgical anatomy (Fig. 3). The patient had malocclusion and required re-ORIF. This may have been avoided with judicious review of the preoperative CT scans in all planes, and intraoperatively if the superior part of the fracture had been visualised.

Fig. 3 Postoperative 3D CT of right condyle showing ORIFed vertical ramus fracture but missed condylar base fracture
Revision case 2 â€“ secondary revision required
In this case of non-union, a trapezoidal plate was used, and causality was attributed to screw placement into the fracture and insufficient reduction.
Revision case 3 â€“ secondary revision required
In the second case of non-union, a two-hole anterior miniplate and four-hole posterior miniplate were used and an ideal radiological result was achieved. Failure was attributed to secondary trauma complicated by heavy bruxism.
Learning points
â€¢        
Condylar ORIF is a difficult procedure that requires appreciation of the anatomy, but it can be done with adequate training, ideally in a high-volume unit.
â€¢        
In our series facial nerve weakness was temporary and the incidence was low.
â€¢        
Re-ORIF is challenging due to constraints of existing screw holes, bony resorption, and scar tissue.
Conclusion
This study demonstrates the challenges of condylar ORIF; it highlights potential pitfalls and proposes strategies to avoid them. In our high-volume specialist unit we have found it possible to translate treatment plans to acceptable functional results, and surgeons with a spectrum of operative experience have achieved outcomes of less than 2 mm overlap and 10Â° angulation. We advocate a posterior four-hole spaced plate and anterior two-hole plating strategy for better negotiation of the lingual flange and closure of the anterior diastasis. CT for preoperative planning is unmatched, and postoperative small-field-of-view CBCT permits critical evaluation of reduction. Operative intervention was associated with good functional occlusion and minimal long-term complications.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
No ethics approval required. Patientsâ€™ permission obtained.

DeepSeek R1: This study evaluates the outcomes of open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) for condylar neck and base fractures, focusing on radiological accuracy and functional results. Conducted at a high-volume trauma center, the retrospective review included 50 patients (59 condyles) treated between March 2021 and August 2022. The primary outcome was radiological accuracy, defined as <2 mm overlap and <10Â° angulation postoperatively. Results showed that 49/59 condyles achieved <2 mm overlap, and 52/59 achieved <10Â° angulation, with satisfactory occlusal outcomes in most cases. Complications included temporary facial nerve weakness (4 cases), sialocele (2 cases), and non-union (2 cases), all managed successfully. The study highlights the technical challenges of ORIF, emphasizing the importance of preoperative CT imaging for accurate assessment and planning. A posterior four-hole and anterior two-hole plating strategy was recommended to address oblique fractures and avoid screw placement in the fracture line. The use of postoperative intermaxillary fixation (IMF) was limited and reserved for specific cases. The study concludes that ORIF, when performed by experienced surgeons, yields acceptable functional and radiological outcomes, with minimal long-term complications. Key learning points include the necessity of detailed preoperative imaging, careful surgical technique, and the avoidance of IMF in most cases. This study supports ORIF as the standard of care for displaced condylar fractures, provided it is performed in a high-volume, specialist unit.

Title: Impact of childhood/adolescent cancer history on prognosis in parotid mucoepidermoid carcinoma
Author: Gu, Hefeng; Tu, Sunyi; Ma, Lan; Su, Kuiwei; Zhou, Yeqing
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Our goal was to assess the impact of childhood/adolescent cancer history on overall survival (OS) and disease-specific survival (DSS) in patients with parotid mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC). Patients who underwent surgical treatment for primary parotid MEC and those with a second malignancy of parotid MEC were retrospectively identified from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database. The primary outcome variables were OS and DSS. The hazard ratios (HRs) of these survival rates associated with cancer history were analysed using Cox regression models. In total, 2681 patients were included, 263 of whom had a second malignancy. The 10-year OS rates in the primary (72%) and second malignancy groups (59%) were significantly different. Cox regression confirmed that a history of cancer tended to decrease OS (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.062, HR: 1.28, 95% confidence interval: 0.99 to 1.64). Subgroup analyses showed that a history of solid tumour as opposed to haematological cancer predicted worse OS, with central nervous system tumours exhibiting a more significant influence than others (pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.030 vs pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.088). Cancer history was not related to DSS. A history of childhood/adolescent cancer negatively influenced the prognosis of patients with parotid MEC, and this effect was primarily driven by a history of solid malignancy.
Body:
Introduction
Owing to the rapid development of early diagnosis, improved therapy, supportive care, and multidisciplinary approaches, the number of long-term survivors with prior childhood/adolescent cancer increases annually by 2%. 1 However, survivors are still at risk: damage to the body from previous radiation and/or chemotherapy, which may not manifest for a long time,2 places them at greater risk of developing a secondary malignant neoplasm (SMN).3 A second malignancy of parotid mucoepidermoid carcinoma (sMEC) accounts for a non-negligible proportion of SMNs and has been described in multiple case reports as well as original studies with small sample sizes. 4â€“10
The occurrence of a sMEC has been reported in survivors with a history of leukaemia, neuroblastoma, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, sarcoma, and several other cancers.4â€“10 The demographic, pathological, and molecular features of sMEC may be comparable to those of primary parotid MEC (pMEC).11 However, reported differences in survival are inconsistent, with one study identifying similar overall survival (OS) and disease-specific survival (DSS) in patients with pMEC and sMEC,12 and others describing worse OS and DSS in those with sMEC.11,13 Moreover, since these studies were limited by small sample sizes, a reliable conclusion cannot be drawn.
This study therefore aimed to identify differences between patients with primary and secondary parotid MEC, and to assess the impact of childhood/adolescent cancer history on prognosis.
Material and methods
Patient selection
All data were obtained from the National Cancer Instituteâ€™s Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) 18 database (Incidence-SEER Research Plus Data, 18 Registries, November 2019 Submission 2000â€“2017), which provides publicly accessible cancer statistics with the aim of reducing the cancer burden in the US population. The profiles of patients who had undergone surgical treatment for parotid MEC between 2000 and 2018 were reviewed. The inclusion criteria were as follows: the disease was primary or a second malignancy that developed following a prior cancer diagnosis during childhood or adolescence with a latency time of >5 years between the first cancer diagnosis and sMEC occurrence, and the patient had received surgical treatment for parotid MEC. Patients with a history of previous MEC or no detailed information on surgical procedures or follow up were excluded (Supplementary Figure). Data on demographic characteristics, histological grade, cancer stage, treatment, and follow up were extracted from the database and analysed. Ethics approval was not required for this study as the data are publicly accessible.
Variable definitions
Cancer stage, defined as localised, regional, or distant, was based on SEER stage classification.14 Histological grade was classified as low for well-differentiated, intermediate for moderately differentiated, and high for poorly or undifferentiated tissue. Treatment was divided into surgery only, surgery and adjuvant radiotherapy, or surgery and adjuvant chemoradiotherapy. Latency was defined as the duration between the first cancer diagnosis and sMEC confirmation. Finally, race (white, black, or other) and marital status (married, single, or other) were also categorised for assessment.15
The primary outcome variables were OS and DSS. OS time was calculated from the date of MEC treatment to the date of death or final follow up, and DSS time was calculated from the treatment date to the date of cancer-caused death or final follow up.
Statistical analyses
Demographic and clinicopathological variables were compared between the pMEC and sMEC groups using chi squared tests. Differences in OS and DSS between the pMEC and sMEC groups were evaluated using the Kaplanâ€“Meier method. Univariate and multivariate Cox proportional hazards models were used to further explore the independent effects of childhood/adolescent cancer history on OS and DSS; hazard ratios (HRs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated for both survival rates. All statistical analyses were performed using R version 3.4.3 (R: a language and environment for statistical computing. R Core Team). Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05.
Results
Baseline data
In total, 2681 patients were included in the study, 1351 (50.4%) of whom were male, with a mean (SD) age of 55 (23) years. Additionally, 74.7% of the patients were white and 59.5% were married at the time of MEC diagnosis. Slightly more patients were treated before 2010 (n = 1509, 56.3%). The histological grade was low in 655 (24.4%) patients, intermediate in 1070 (39.9%), high in 651 (24.3%), and unknown in 305 (11.4%). Cancer was localised in 1707 (63.7%) patients, regional in 703 (26.2%), distant in 223 (8.3%), and unknown in 48 (1.8%). A total of 1252 patients received adjuvant radiotherapy, 138 of whom also underwent chemotherapy.
Among the included patients, 2418 (90.2%) had pMEC (pMEC group) and 263 (9.8%) had sMEC (sMEC group). The median (range) latency between prior cancer diagnosis and sMEC was 9.8 (5.2â€“38.7) years. The previous cancer type was haematological (56.9% leukaemia and 43.1% lymphoma) in 167 patients and solid in 96. Among the solid tumours, the most common was central nervous system cancer (n = 36, 37.5%) followed by neuroblastoma (n = 15, 15.6%), and the least frequent type was germ cell cancer (n = 9, 9.4%; Supplementary Table).
Demographic and clinicopathological differences between pMEC and sMEC groups
Significant differences in age (p < 0.001), race (p < 0.001), year of diagnosis (p < 0.001), cancer stage (p < 0.001), and treatment type (p = 0.006) were identified between the pMEC and sMEC groups. Compared with those in the pMEC group, patients in the sMEC group were more likely to be younger, non-white, and to have regional-stage disease. Moreover, adjuvant therapy, especially adjuvant radiotherapy alone, was more commonly administered in the sMEC group. The two groups had similar distributions of sex (p = 0.080), marital status (p = 0.624), and histological grade (p = 0.353) (Table 1).

Impact of childhood/adolescent cancer history on survival
After a mean (SD) follow-up time of 85 (64) months, 673 deaths had occurred, 298 of which were caused by parotid MEC. The overall 10-year DSS and OS rates were 86% (95% CI: 84% to 88%) and 69% (95% CI: 67% to 71%), respectively.
In the univariate analysis of DSS, the 10-year rates were not significantly different between the groups (86%; 95% CI: 84% to 88% for the pMEC group and 83%; 95% CI: 77% to 89% for the sMEC group, p = 0.734) (Fig. 1). Additionally, patients who underwent different treatments had similar DSS rates (p = 0.301). On the other hand, age, sex, race, year of diagnosis, marital status, histological grade, and cancer stage were significantly associated with DSS. The multivariate analysis also showed that cancer history did not influence DSS (p = 0.378; HR: 1.89; 95% CI: 0.75 to 3.28). Independent predictors of DSS included age, year of diagnosis, histological grade, and cancer stage (Table 2).

In the univariate analysis of OS, the 10-year OS rates were significantly different between the two groups (72%; 95% CI: 70% to 74% for the pMEC group and 59%; 95% CI: 51% to 67% for the sMEC group, p < 0.001) (Fig. 2). Other significant factors included age, race, sex, year of diagnosis, marital status, histological grade, and cancer stage. Cox regression similarly showed that a history of cancer tended to decrease OS (p = 0.062; HR: 1.28; 95% CI: 0.99 to 1.64). Independent risk factors for OS included age, sex, year of diagnosis, marital status, histological grade, and cancer stage (Table 3).

Subgroup analyses
The potential effects of cancer history stratified by latency time and pathological type were analysed. Compared with patients with no cancer history, latency of more than or less than 10 years in the secondary group did not affect DSS (both p > 0.05), but both durations tended to decrease OS rates (p = 0.076 and p = 0.054, respectively). History of a solid tumour predicted worse OS than did prior haematological cancer, whereas neither had a significant effect on DSS. Central nervous system tumours in particular were more significantly related to OS than others (p = 0.030 vs p = 0.088). A history of leukaemia or lymphoma did not significantly affect OS (Table 4).

Discussion
The major findings of the current study were: (1) the median time for the development of sMEC following the occurrence of primary cancer in childhood/adolescence was nearly 10 years; (2) a cancer history was likely to decrease OS but not DSS; and (3) this effect was primarily due to a history of solid malignancy, especially central nervous system cancer. Our study has characterised the significance of childhood/adolescent cancer history in survival in parotid MEC, which may aid the clinical management of such patients in future.
Due to rapid progress in medicine, survival is improving in patients with childhood/adolescent cancer. However, concerns have been raised that the incidence of a SMN in these survivors is increasing. The cumulative SMN incidence after 30 years may be as high as 8.8% in survivors of childhood sarcoma,3 and the median latency from first cancer diagnosis to SMN occurrence has been reported as 6.8 years. Additionally, Villanueva et al16 reported that after a median follow up of nine years, 24 of 714 (3.4%) patients with pediatric retinoblastoma developed 25 SMNs. Another study reported that the risk of SMNs remained elevated for more than 20 years for all primary childhood cancer diagnoses,17 so it is not surprising that the histological types of previous cancers in the current study were relatively complex. Interestingly, the median latency between first cancer diagnosis and sMEC occurrence in our study was nearly 10 years, slightly longer than that reported in the literature. Unlike other similar studies,18 in the assessment of SMNs, we included only parotid MEC, which usually grows slowly and without apparent initial symptoms,19 making early detection difficult; this may explain the longer latency period in the current study. The occurrence of a SMN differs with age, sex, family history, pathology, stage of first cancer, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. For example, alkylating agents, which are typically an important component of leukaemia chemotherapy, are associated with an increased risk of SMNs. 6
The clinicopathological features of parotid MEC have been frequently evaluated, although few studies have compared pMEC and sMEC; to the best of our knowledge only four such original studies were available for review. VÃ©drine et al 12 were the first to report that primary and secondary MEC groups had similar distributions of age, sex, tumour grade, and tumour location, and that advanced clinical stage disease was more likely to occur in survivors with sMEC. However, only 18 cases were included in this analysis, which limits the studyâ€™s conclusiveness. Verma et al 20 reviewed 58 secondary chemotherapy or radiotherapy-induced MEC cases and observed that the parotid gland was organ most likely to be involved (87.5% of the cancers had a low or intermediate histological grade, and most patients were staged as T1 or T2). Hao et al 11 systematically analysed the demographic, pathological, and molecular features of 63 primary and 15 secondary MECs. Suggesting that these two cancers are essentially the same, the two groups showed comparable distributions of age, sex, tumour stage, neck lymph node stage, perineural invasion, lymphovascular invasion, p53 and BCL-2, proliferating cell nuclear antigen and carcinoembryonic antigen levels, and Ki-67 index. This finding conflicts with our observation that patients with sMEC were significantly younger than those with pMEC. Since we only selected patients with a childhood/adolescent cancer history for the sMEC group, differences in year of diagnosis, cancer stage, and treatment may be explained by advancements in disease understanding and medical technology that provided patients with earlier and more accurate diagnoses as well as improved treatments.
Several studies have evaluated the influence of cancer history on survival. Worse prognosis was predicted in patients with Hodgkinâ€™s lymphoma, sarcoma, or breast, thyroid, or testicular cancer.21 Additionally, a longer latency time (>5 years) suggested an overall increased risk of death. 22 At the time, whether these conclusions could be applied to MEC was unclear. VÃ©drine et al 12 reported that differences in OS and DSS rates between primary and secondary MEC groups were not statistically significant, although their sample size was small. Hao et al 11 and Seng et al 13 determined that a history of cancer was significantly associated with decreased DSS; these authors proposed that previous chemotherapy for blood malignancy had a significantly adverse impact on the lymphatic defence system. Conversely, our study showed that a history of childhood/adolescent cancer did not affect DSS but tended to decrease OS. This difference may be explained by our study design. We only enrolled patients with sMEC who had a latency time of more than five years (because a five-year disease-free period would typically classify the patient as â€˜curedâ€™ for most cancers) so patients with pMEC and sMEC had similar DSS rates in our study.
To our knowledge, we are the first to analyse the effect of the pathological type of previous cancer on survival of sMEC. We observed that previous solid cancers, especially central nervous system tumours, influenced OS. Paediatric central nervous system tumours usually require radiotherapy and chemotherapy, which is poorly tolerated by children and adolescents; further, these tumours often affect growth and development, especially cognitive and learning abilities, potentially leading to an increased overall mortality risk.
The limitations of the current study should be acknowledged. First, this was a retrospective study that consequently had inherent bias. Secondly, our findings were based only on parotid MEC, and external validation is needed before clinical application. Thirdly, it was challenging, if not impossible, to accurately determine why certain treatment choices were made.
In summary, a childhood/adolescent cancer history decreased OS but not DSS, and the effect on OS was mainly influenced by a history of solid as opposed to haematological malignancy, especially central nervous system cancer.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Funding
The manuscript was sponsored by Zhejiang Provincial Medical and Health Science and Technology Project under grant No. 2022KY409, Shaoxing People's Hospital Youth Research Foundation (2023YB03), Medical and Health Science Technology Project of Shaoxing Municipality (Public Welfare Technology Application Research): 2020A13003, Zhejiang Provincial Medical and Health Science and Technology Project under grant no. 2022KY403.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Not applicable.
Data availability
All data generated or analysed during this study are included in this published article. The primary data have been uploaded for public access.
Authors' contributions
The authors made all contributions of study design, manuscript writing, studies selecting, data analysis, study quality evaluating, and manuscript revising. The final manuscript was read and approved.

Title: Impact of dental state and surgical factors on postoperative neck infection in oral cancer patients
Author: Chang, Victor K O; See, Lydia; Griffin, Alison; Breik, Omar; Batstone, Martin D; Liu, Timothy P J
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Postoperative neck infection (PONI) is a known complication of neck dissection. In this study we explored the impact of dental status on the development of PONI, using orthopantomograms to assess edentulism, periodontal health, and caries status. Retrospective analysis was performed for all new oral cancer patients who had neck dissection between January 2008 and January 2020 in a tertiary head and neck centre. PONI risk factors assessed included patient characteristics, dental status, tumour, and surgical factors. Development of PONI was the primary outcome. Edentulous patients had lower risk of PONI (OR 0.06, pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.026) compared to those with 21 or more teeth. Periodontitis and dental caries were not statistically significant. Current smokers (OR 2.09, pÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 0.044) and free flap reconstruction (OR 5.41, pÂ¬â€ <Â¬â€ 0.001) were also significant predictors for development of PONI. This study highlights the presence of teeth as a potential source of infection post neck dissection and that orthopantomogram assessment may be inadequate to identify at risk patients. Future studies are required on direct clinical assessment of dentition to evaluate the impact of dental optimisation in prevention of PONI.
Body:
Introduction
Neck dissection (ND) is integral to management of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) as cervical nodal metastases is the most significant prognostic factor.1 Neck dissection improves survival, even for early tumours, and up to 30% of clinically node-negative patients are found to have involved nodes following elective ND.2,3 However, ND is not without risk and postoperative neck infection (PONI) may affect prognosis by delaying adjuvant therapy4 and prolonging admissions.5
Neck dissections are typically clean procedures, but they are classified as clean-contaminated when performed in conjunction with oral cancer resection.6 According to the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, PONI in clean-contaminated ND should be less than 10%.7 Comparatively, the occurrence of infection among surgically-treated OSCC patients, irrespective of antimicrobial use, is disproportionately high with documented rates ranging from 10% to 40%.8â€“10
Postoperative neck infection is multifactorial with studies identifying prolonged operative time, presence of tracheostomy, and patient comorbidities as significant predictors.9â€“11 Alcoholism, active smoking, and higher categories in the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification increase the risk of surgical site infections.4,9â€“12 The impact of oral hygiene on PONI, however, is poorly understood. While Sato et al13 described preoperative dental care as a means to decrease the risk of infection, others have not found this association.4,8 Oral microflora have been documented as common pathogens for OSCC patients with postoperative infections.14
It is important to consider a patientâ€™s dentition during planning for OSCC surgery and dentists are critical to the Head and Neck Multidisciplinary Team.15 While dental examination is recommended in OSCC treatment guidelines,16 accessibility to preoperative assessment is often limited by resource availability. Consequently, some centres rely on orthopantomography (OPG) for dentition assessment and identification of patients who may benefit from preoperative dental optimisation. Patients with fewer teeth should theoretically have a lower oral bacterial load, reducing risk of PONI. The aim of this study is to define the association of edentulism, periodontal and caries status to PONI using OPG as a screening tool.
Methodology
In a retrospective study, histologically confirmed OSCC patients who had ablative surgery and ND at the Royal Brisbane and Womenâ€™s Hospital between 1 January 2008 and 31 January 2020 were eligible. The NDs were typically performed prior to the OSCC ablation but all neck wounds were considered â€˜clean-contaminatedâ€™ as surgical instruments for wound closure of neck and oral cavity were not separate. Cefazolin and metronidazole, or lincosamides for patients with penicillin/cephalosporin allergies, were prescribed perioperatively and 48 hours postoperatively.
Patients with no OPG records were excluded. Patients who had salvage ND for recurrence or radiotherapy were excluded due to altered neck anatomy, fibrosis, and perivascular necrosis that impaired tissue healing with increased risk of infection.17
Variables included patient characteristics, dental status, tumour factors, and surgical techniques. Patient characteristics included age, gender, smoking history, and immunosuppression. Patients were considered immunosuppressed if comorbid with conditions such as, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus and liver cirrhosis or exposure to immunosuppressant medications. Smoking status was defined as life-long non-smoker, current smoker, and ex-smoker if they smoked at least 100 cigarettes in their lifetime but stopped at least 28 days prior to surgery.18
Tumours were categorised according to T and N classification as per the eighth Edition of the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC).19 Surgical factors included unilateral or bilateral ND, free flap reconstruction and site of tumour resection.
Dental status was assessed on caries, degree of edentulism and periodontal health. Caries status was graded based on a combination of degree of caries and number of quadrants involved (Table 1). Degree of edentulism (Table 2) was graded by the number of teeth on preoperative OPG. Periodontal health and dental caries were assessed on preoperative OPG as indirect measures of oral hygiene and bacterial biofilm. Periodontal grading was adapted from the American Academy of Periodontology (AAP),20 measured by the ratio of bone loss (Fig. 1) to age and graded from 1 to 3 (Table 2).

Dental assessments were performed independently on preoperative OPG by three experienced clinicians, who were blinded to patient outcomes, demographics, factors related to the tumour, and surgical procedures. Final grades were recorded on consensus between two or more clinicians. Interobserver reliability was 100% on degree of edentulism, 99% for periodontal grading, and 94% for caries grading. Discrepancies were re-assessed, and final gradings were recorded upon discussion.
The primary outcome was development of PONI, diagnosed and documented in patientsâ€™ clinical notes within 30 days of surgery21 in both inpatient or outpatient settings. PONI diagnosis was based on clinical findings including neck swelling, cutaneous erythema and/or purulent discharge. Time to infection was recorded in days from date of ND to diagnosis. All PONI had a wound swab sent for microscopy and culture.
Statistical analysis
Predictor variables and outcomes are displayed as numbers and percentages for categorical variables. Associations between variables and primary outcome were examined using univariable and multivariable logistic regression models. For multivariable model building, initially all dental factors and additional variables with p â‰¤ 0.30 were included in models, characteristics were sequentially removed in order of highest to lowest p value until only those with p < 0.05 remained in the model. Finally, each variable was individually re-added to the model and any with p < 0.05 retained in the final model. The results of multivariable logistic regression analyses were presented as odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals. Stata v17.0 (Stata Corp) was used to complete statistical analysis and a p value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.
Results
A total of 780 patients were identified. Two-hundred-and-eight patients who had surgery without ND were excluded. A further 57 patients without preoperative OPGs were excluded. Of 515 eligible patients, 65.2% were male. The largest proportion were aged between 60â€“79 years (49.9%).
Table 2 shows the patient characteristics. There were 210 current smokers (40.8%) and 91 (17.7%) immunocompromised patients. T1 tumour accounted for 13.6% of patients with the remainder approximately equally distributed between T2 to T4 classification. The majority of 515 eligible patients (77.5%) had unilateral ND and were N0 (60.6%) post ND. 321 patients (62.3%) received free flap reconstruction and the most common cancer site was the tongue (47.2%).
PONI was diagnosed in 55 patients (10.7%) with a median time to infection of 12 days (interquartile range 7â€“21 days), ranging from four to 30 days. Table 3 lists the bacteria cultured from wound swabs with Streptococcus milleri (56.4%) being the predominantly isolated bacteria. Univariable associations between development of PONI and predictor variables are presented in Table 4. The variables that were statistically significant in the multivariable model were number of teeth (including no teeth), smoking status, and type of reconstruction (Table 5).

Patient characteristics
Univariable analysis showed those aged below 60 (15.9%, N = 226) were more likely to develop PONI (p = 0.012). Current smokers had higher infection rates (15.2%, N = 210) than non-smokers (7.1%, N = 184) and ex-smokers (8.3%, N = 121, p = 0.023). Immunosuppressed patients had similar rates (12.1%, N = 91) to immunocompetent patients (10.4%, N = 424, p = 0.63). There were trends towards increased rates of PONI in tumours of higher T and N classification, but not statistically significant.
In multivariable analysis, the only patient characteristic that remained statistically significant was smoking status (p = 0.044). Current smokers had twice the odds of developing PONI (OR 2.09; 95% Cl, 1.02 to 4.26) as non-smokers, while ex-smokers were not at increased risk (OR 0.95; 95% CI 0.39 to 2.30).
Surgical factors
Free flap reconstruction (p < 0.001), bilateral ND (p = 0.004) and cancer site (p = 0.04) were associated with PONI in univariable analysis. Free flap reconstruction was the only surgical factor that remained statistically significant in the multivariable model with odds of PONI being almost 5.5 times more likely than patients without reconstruction (OR 5.41; 95% CI 2.22 to 13.16; p < 0.001).
Dental status
Univariable analysis showed lower rates of PONI with one edentulous patient (1.1%, N = 89, p = 0.012) having PONI compared to 54 dentate patients (12.7%, N = 426). However, this association was not reflected with increasing number of teeth (p = 0.72). Caries grading was also not associated with PONI (p = 0.40). Although not statistically significant (p = 0.079), there was a trend towards higher rates of PONI in patients with higher grades of periodontitis, where seven grade 1 (7.9%, N = 89), 33 grade 2 (12.4%, N = 267), and 14 grade 3 (20%, N = 70) patients had PONI.
The only dental characteristic that was an independent predictor in the multivariable model was number of teeth (p = 0.026). Edentulous patients had the lowest PONI risk (OR, 0.06; 95% CI, 0.01 to 0.43) followed by those with 1â€“8 teeth (OR, 0.44; 95% CI, 0.13 to 1.54) while those with 9â€“20 teeth (OR, 1.02; 95% CI 0.51 to 2.07) had similar odds to those with 21 or more teeth (reference).
Exploratory analysis (Supplementary Table 1) showed smoking status was associated with dental status. Current smokers were more likely to be edentulous (p = 0.002), have fewer teeth (p = 0.014), and worse grading for periodontitis (p < 0.001) and caries (p < 0.001).
Discussion
This study demonstrated the presence of teeth to be associated with an increased PONI risk. Edentulous patients had substantially lowered odds of PONI. Independently of dental status, patients who had free flap reconstruction had five times the odds of PONI. Current smokers had twice the odds as non-smokers, while ex-smokers had the same risk as non-smokers. Overall, the rate of PONI was found to be 10.7% for 515 OSCC patients treated with tumour resection and ND. This was on the lower end of reported incidences between 10% to 40%.8,9,11
It would be expected for older patients with medical comorbidities and immunosuppression to be at higher risk of infection. However, PONI was not associated with either in this analysis. Patients above 60 years were found to have a lower rate of PONI, but this may have been confounded by the likelihood that older patients will have fewer teeth or be edentulous. Although younger age was associated with development of PONI in univariable analysis, this was no longer present in adjusted analysis, further suggesting the univariable between age and PONI was confounded by edentulism.
Postoperative neck infection was significantly less in edentulous patients (1.1%, N = 89). This is consistent with previous findings of decreased bacterial load and diversity in edentulous patientsâ€™ saliva.22,23 Patients with fewer teeth may have a similar advantage compared to those with more of their dentition. Although not statistically significant, patients with eight teeth or fewer had half the odds of developing PONI, while patients with more than eight teeth had the same odds as fully dentate patients.
Dental and periodontal cleaning removes biofilm, which may decrease bacterial contamination of a neck wound. In this study, statistical analysis on dental disease identified on OPG did not demonstrate statistical significance and the extent of dental caries was not associated with PONI. However, worsening periodontal health did show a possible trend for increasing rates of PONI, where there was a 12.1% increased rate of PONI between patients with slow and rapidly progressing periodontitis. Given the strong association between smoking and dental status, it may be that smoking status, rather than dental status, is conferring the risk for PONI. However, the absence of statistical significance may also be attributable to the lower rate of PONI in this study.
Oral bacteria, namely Streptococcus milleri, was the predominant bacteria cultured in this study (56%, N = 55) while gram negative organisms accounted for 18.1% (N = 55). In contrast, Iwamoto et al14 isolated higher numbers of gram negative periodontopathic bacteria in patients with mandibular gingival malignancy and wound infections. The lower number of periodontopathic bacteria cultured may explain the absence of association between periodontal disease and PONI. Future research with clinical periodontal assessment and evaluation of biofilm would shed more light on the impact of periodontal disease on PONI as OPG cannot differentiate between active and stabilised disease.
Postoperative neck infection relating to advanced tumours and aggressive surgeries is a recurrent theme in the literature. Karakida et al11 and Lofti et al8 found those with advanced tumour and nodal categories had a higher probability for infection. Tracheostomy and longer operative time have also been found to be predictors.9,10,24â€“26 Unsurprisingly, patients who received free flap reconstruction were found to have almost 5.5 times the odds of developing PONI to those without, consistent with work published by Ogihara et al25 and Gondo et al26 Iwamoto et al proposed OSCC in sites such as the floor of mouth, retromolar trigone and mandible were risk factors for infection due to oral-neck communication from surgical resection.14 This study did not identify an association of tumour site with PONI on multivariable analysis. However, free flap reconstruction, which fundamentally creates oral-neck communication through tunnelling of the flap and pedicle for vascular anastomoses, supports this theory.
Smoking was an independent predictor for PONI in this study. There is, however, no consensus on the impact of smoking in literature.9,11,27 A recent systematic review by Garip et al28 found smokers were at increased risk of haematoma and impaired wound healing but was not associated with infection. In contrast to other studies,24,29 medical comorbidities relating to immunosuppression were not associated with neck infection in the present study. It is important to note that analysis relating to patientsâ€™ medical health can be confounded by the quality of perioperative management at each institution. Therefore, early smoking cessation and optimisation of comorbidities is still recommended for all OSCC patients.
The lack of OPG records was the major limitation of this study. Clinical examination remains the gold standard in recording periodontitis, caries, and compliance with oral hygiene. It also allows assessment for signs of chronic infections such as periodontal pocketing, bleeding on probing, tooth mobility, and suppuration. While this study did not show statistical significance between dental status and PONI, there were observed trends of increased infection rate with higher grades of periodontitis. Further research is recommended to focus on clinical assessment of dentition to determine if dental optimisation would decrease the risk for PONI.
Conclusion
Patients with OSCC who are planned for free flap reconstruction are at high risk of PONI and early smoking cessation is also recommended for patients to decrease the risk of developing PONI. This study highlights the presence of teeth as a significant predictor for PONI. While OPG is a useful tool for rapid assessment of dentition without direct patient contact, future studies should take into account both direct and indirect assessments beyond the capabilities of OPG, in evaluating the impact of dental optimisation on PONI.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Ethics approval has been gained by the local ethics committee. Consent not obtained and all information is de-identified in the retrospective study
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Recognizing that cervical nodal metastases are a major prognostic factor in OSCC and that ND, although generally a clean procedure, becomes clean-contaminated when performed with oral cancer resection, the study addressed why infection rates in OSCC patients range between 10% and 40%â€”exceeding the recommended infection rate of less than 10% for clean-contaminated surgeries. Prior research has identified factors such as prolonged operative time, tracheostomy, and patient comorbidities as risks for PONI, yet the role of oral hygiene remained unclear.

Data were collected from 515 OSCC patients treated at the Royal Brisbane and Womenâ€™s Hospital between January 2008 and January 2020, all of whom had preoperative orthopantomography (OPG) records. Dental status was assessed via OPG for number of teeth, degree of caries, and periodontal health. PONI was diagnosed in 10.7% of patients with a median onset of 12 days postoperatively. Multivariable logistic regression revealed that the presence of teeth, smoking, and free flap reconstruction were independent predictors of PONI. Specifically, edentulous patients had substantially lower odds of infection, current smokers were at double the risk of non-smokers, and free flap reconstruction increased the risk by more than fivefold. Title: Impact of parathyroidectomy on quality of life in primary hyperparathyroidism
Author: Shepherd, Daniel; Kethireddi, Keerthi Madhurya; Borumandi, Farzad
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) frequently report symptoms that are associated with the disease and impact on their quality of life (QoL). While parathyroidectomy corrects calcium and PTH levels, its impact on improving patients? QoL is not clear. In this single centre prospective study, we aimed to assess the impact of a parathyroidectomy on PHPT patients? pre and post parathyroidectomy QoL over a period of three years and nine months. PHPT patients, undergoing parathyroidectomy, voluntarily completed a modified Pasieka Parathyroidectomy Assessment Score (PAS), a tool correlating 13 PHPT symptoms to QoL. Sixty patients with PHPT (mean age 64 years, female to male 4:1) were included in the study. Pre parathyroidectomy, the most common symptoms were: feeling tired easily (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 58); being forgetful (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 51); pain in the joints (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 49); feeling irritable (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 48) bone pain (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 45); feeling weak (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 45); mood swings (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 42); and being thirsty (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 42). Parathyroidectomy reduced severity of mean total PAS by 44%, improving from 509 to 284 (pÂ¬â€ <Â¬â€ 0.01). A total of 77% (nÂ¬â€ =Â¬â€ 46) of patients experienced some improvement of PAS. The five most severe symptoms (highest reported individual PAS) showed a significant reduction post parathyroidectomy (pÂ¬â€ <Â¬â€ 0.01): feeling tired easily (mean PAS 65 vs 38); pain in the joints (52 vs 31); being thirsty (46 vs 22); being forgetful (45 vs 28); and bone pain (45 vs 27). Patients with PHPT demonstrated impaired QoL as evidenced by the PAS, and assessing this is valuable in treatment planning. Parathyroidectomy impacts the symptoms that most affect QoL and significantly improves overall QoL in these patients.
Body:
Introduction
Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is a common endocrine condition affecting approximately 1% of the adult population.1 PHPT has an increasing incidence with age, usually presenting in the sixth decade of life. Given the age distribution and having a female to male ratio 3-4:1, PHPT classically occurs in post-menopausal patients.2 While the vast majority of PHPT cases are due to solitary benign parathyroid adenomas (80%), multiple adenomas, multi-gland hyperplasia, and parathyroid carcinoma are potential causes.3,4
PHPT is usually associated with an elevated, or inappropriately high normal, parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration and resultant hypercalcaemia. The frequently reported symptoms of PHPT can include bone aches, abdominal pain, excessive thirst, excessive urination, low impact fractures, renal stones, and constipation.5 A subset of patients may also present with acute dehydration, acute kidney injury, fragility fractures from osteoporosis, hypertension, renal stone disease or chronic kidney disease.6 The psychoneurological and cognitive dysfunction symptoms lack specificity and are often undifferentiated, such as easy fatiguability, poor concentration, depression, cognitive decline, and mood swings.6â€“19 Although these symptoms have a marked impact on quality of life (QoL), they are commonly misinterpreted as a process of normal ageing or postmenopausal state due to the demographic affected by PHPT.9 It should be noted many patients with PHPT can be asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms, however, and are diagnosed incidentally through biochemical screening. Interestingly these patients are still at risk of end organ damage.3
Parathyroidectomy is the primary treatment option for PHPT. If surgery is unsuitable, declined, or unsuccessful, non-surgical management may be considered. Non-surgical management includes calcimimetics and bisphosphonates, which assists in managing hypercalcaemia and increased bone turnover.20,21 Currently indications for surgery relate to symptoms and effects of hypercalcaemia and osteopenia.5,21,22 Despite the impact on QoL many of the symptoms of PHPT have on patients, especially the psychoneurological and cognitive dysfunction symptoms, current guidelines do not take an assessment of PAS symptoms and QoL into account.3,6,7,10,11,14
Symptoms, particularly the psychoneurological and cognitive dysfunction symptoms, are non-specific and have not shown a strong link to the degree of biochemical derangement.3,14,23 It is therefore difficult to quantify the impact on QoL that PHPT has on a patient by using biochemical markers alone. Several studies have previously been conducted to assess the improvement of overall QoL of PHPT patients. These have generally used standardised systems of well-being and QoL evaluation such as RAND-36 of SF-36 scales. Pasieka et al developed a simplified tool specific to PHPT: a set of 13 questions (parathyroid assessment score or PAS) that has been shown to be an accurate tool to analyse the impact of QoL in the PHPT patients pre and postoperatively.8,9,13,20 Evidence confirming this link is conflicted, with a recent Cochrane review by Pappachan et al highlighting limitations with current evidence.3,7,14,20,23 While parathyroidectomy corrects underlying calcium and PTH levels, and one would expect an improvement in symptoms and therefore overall QoL, its impact on improving patientsâ€™ frequently reported symptoms is not clear.
We conducted a prospective study to review the impact of parathyroidectomy on frequently reported symptoms known to impact QoL in PHPT patients.
Material and methods
This was a single-centre prospective observational study reviewing all patients undergoing parathyroidectomy for PHPT under the care of a single surgeon between December 2019 to October 2023 (three years and nine months). The surgical technique was consistent with standard techniques.24 The inclusion criteria for this study were: confirmed diagnosis of PHPT in adults requiring surgical treatment based on current NICE guidelines;22 undergoing parathyroidectomy within the study period of December 2019 to October 2023; voluntary and complete completion of preoperative and postoperative symptom score assessment. Patients with normocalcaemic PHPT were excluded from the study. No adjustment for comorbidities or other potential confounding factors was made. All patients with incomplete data were excluded from this study.
The impact and severity of symptoms on a patientâ€™s QoL was quantified using a disease specific Parathyroid Assessment Score (PAS), originally reported by Pasieka et al.10 This is a self-reported assessment tool, measuring the impact of PHPT on a patientâ€™s QoL. This has been shown to correlate to the SF-36 QoL scores and is an accurate method of assessing overall health status and QoL for PHPT patients.10,12,15
Patients were asked to complete an identical standardised questionnaire pre and postoperatively through a mixture of paper and electronic means. This was the standard 13 symptom PAS questionnaire with an addition of nausea.15 A visual analogue scale was used to assist patients to score each symptom from 0-100. Total PAS was calculated as the sum of all 13 symptoms (maximum score 1300), excluding nausea. The self-reported pre and post ECOG/WHO Performance Status and Clinical Frailty Scale scores were also collected for this cohort. Pre and post parathyroidectomy scores of the 14 symptoms above, as well as the total PAS score, were assessed and examined for trends and significance in line with previously published similar studies.25
Biochemical markers are used as an both a diagnostic tool and an objective measure of successful treatment in PHPT.26 Pre and post parathyroidectomy albumin adjusted calcium and PTH were collected as biochemical markers for PHPT. The samples for this study were not taken at any specific intervals pre or post treatment.
The normality of the data was determined using Shapiroâ€‰âˆ’â€‰Wilk statistical test. Statistical comparisons were conducted via the Studentâ€™s t test and Mannâ€“Whitney U test, in accordance with the normality of the data. Pearson and Spearman correlations were used to assess for correlation between the change in different biochemical markers of PHPT and change in symptom score for individual symptom as well as total PAS scores. All tests were two-tailed, with a statistical significance of p < 0.05. The data analysis for this paper was performed using Microsoft ExcelÂ© and the Real Statistics Resource Pack software (Release 8.9.1). Copyright (2013 â€“ 2023) Charles Zaiontz. www.real-statistics.com.
Results
Sixty of the initial 82 patients identified as undergoing parathyroidectomy for PHPT met all the inclusion criteria. Twenty-two patients were excluded due to having an incomplete data set as result of being lost to follow up, opting out of study (n = 20), or being deceased (n = 2). The mean age was 64 years old (range 26-85 years), with a 4:1 female to male ratio.
Although an overall pre to post parathyroidectomy improvement in both the self-reported performance status and frailty index score was observed (from modes of 1 to 0, and 3 to 2, respectively), this change was not considered significant (p = 0.23 and p = 0.07, respectively). No adjustments were made for other comorbidities and progression thereof.
Prior to surgery, the most common symptoms were: feeling tired easily (97%, n = 58); being forgetful (85%, n = 51); pain in the joints (82%, n = 49); feeling irritable (80%, n = 48) bone pain (75%, n = 45); feeling weak (75%, n = 45); mood swings (70%, n = 42); and being thirsty (70%, n = 42). Parathyroidectomy reduced severity of mean total PAS by 44%, improving from 509 to 284 (p < 0.01) (Fig. 1). A total of 77% (n = 46) of patients experienced some improvement of PAS.

Fig. 1 Box plot of total parathyroid assessment score (PAS) pre and post parathyroidectomy (n = 60, p < 0.01).
All 14 symptoms assessed showed a reduction in individual symptom PAS (Fig. 2). The five highest reported individual symptom PAS showed a significant reduction post parathyroidectomy. These were feeling tired easily (mean PAS 65 vs 38, 43% reduction, p < 0.01); pain in the joints (52 vs 31, 40% reduction, p < 0.01); being thirsty (46 vs 22, 52% reduction, p < 0.01); being forgetful (45 vs 28, or 38% reduction, p < 0.01); and bone pain (45 vs 27, 52% reduction, p < 0.01) (Fig. 3). This indicates a significant chance of reducing the symptoms that cause the highest impact on QoL.

Fig. 2 Bar chart of mean severity score (max 100) for severity of self-reported symptoms pre and post parathyroidectomy (n = 60).

Fig. 3 Radar chart of mean severity score (max 100) for five most severe symptoms pre and post parathyroidectomy (n = 60, p < 0.001.
Adding nausea as a modification to the PAS did not impact on assessment of symptoms as a predictor of QoL as nausea was the least severe symptom and showed only a very small reduction in severity of 3 (p = 0.48) (Fig. 2).
The mean pre and postoperative corrected calcium was 2.73 mmol/L and 2.35 mmol/L (reference range, 2.2 â€“ 2.6 mmol/L), with a mean reduction of 0.35 mmol/L (p < 0.001). The mean pre and postoperative PTH 23.35 pmol/L and 8.35 pmol/L (reference range, 1.6 â€“ 7.2 pmol/L), with a mean reduction of 15.0 pmol/L (p < 0.001). Correlation was assessed between PAS and biochemical markers of PHPT as well as individual symptom PAS and biochemical markers of PHPT. Although it was noted that a weak positive association of calcium and pre parathyroidectomy PAS existed (Pearsonâ€™s coefficient 0.23, p = 0.08), this was neither significant nor was there a correlation between post treatment calcium and PAS (Pearsonâ€™s coefficient 0.05, p = 0.7). No other linear association was found between biochemical markers of PHPT and the PAS.
Discussion
This study demonstrates a significant reduction in the burden of symptoms following parathyroidectomy in patients with PHPT. In this single centre retrospective analysis of 60 patients revealed a significant decrease in the mean total PAS from 509 to 284, representing a substantial decrease (44% less) in experienced burden of disease for these patients. A total of 77% of patients reported some improvement in symptoms and the overall improvement in total PAS was predominantly because of reductions of the most debilitating symptoms reported by these patients. These included fatigue, joint pain, thirst, forgetfulness, and bone pain. The reported frequency of all symptoms, and improvement thereof, highlights the substantial impact of PHPT on patients' QoL and the potential for parathyroidectomy to significantly improve well-being in this cohort.
Numerous other similar studies have also shown that there appears to be a significant improvement in QoL following parathyroidectomy in PHPT patients.6,7,11,12,14â€“18 Despite these findings, a recent Cochrane review by Pappachan et al highlighted the difficulties in drawing conclusions from current studies due to the quality of evidence being limited.20 Randomised control trials have yet to show conclusively that parathyroidectomy compared to observation alone leads to a better health-related QoL outcome.8,9,20
While parathyroidectomy is effectively curative for the underlying biochemical derangements of PHPT, this study found no significant correlation between biochemical markers and PAS scores. This is supported by the literature that have not shown a reliable relationship between the degree of experienced symptoms and the level of biochemical derangements.20 Despite this, this study showed a significant reduction in the burden of the psychoneurological, and cognitive symptoms experienced by PHPT patients after parathyroidectomy. This is also supported by similar studies, which show these tend to have the strongest relationship with the underlying hypercalcemia of PHPT.13,14,23 Improvements in the psychoneurological and cognitive symptoms are likely to have a marked impact on daily activities, work productivity, and social interactions. By alleviating the burden of these distressing symptoms, parathyroidectomy has the potential to significantly enhance patientsâ€™ physical and psychological well-being and overall QoL. For this reason, there is some support for considering surgery in patients who do not meet the guideline recommended indications in cases where the surgeon, endocrinologist and patient agree on surgical treatment.19 An understanding of the severity of experienced symptoms and expected improvements thereof are a significant aid in this decision-making process.
While this study provides positive evidence for the role of parathyroidectomy in managing PHPT symptoms, several limitations warrant consideration. The sample size in this study was small and a large proportion of cases were excluded due to incomplete data/lost to follow up (22 of 82 cases or 26.8%). The lack of predetermined follow-up time intervals also reduced the standardisation of the data, making it difficult to assess the short- and long-term improvements in the PAS scores. This patient population underwent parathyroidectomy due to the current recommended guidelines, therefore the data is inherently skewed towards patients already being at risk for PHPT-associated complications. The lack of any control non-surgical group limits the ability to draw definitive conclusions as to the role of parathyroidectomy alone compared to observation over time in the change in these symptoms.
Due to the non-specific nature of the PAS symptoms, the lack of any comparison with a matched cohort of non-PHPT patients also makes it difficult to assess the true burden of disease and may confound results. For the same reason the lack of adjustment for other comorbidities is a significant limitation in interpretation of this data given the non-specific and generalist nature of symptoms that have significant overlap with several common medical conditions in this population of patients.27
Despite the above-mentioned limitations, the results of this study have significant clinical implications. The substantial improvement in quality of life reported by patients following parathyroidectomy highlights the importance of early diagnosis and intervention for PHPT. Additionally, the identification of specific symptoms that are most responsive to surgical treatment is useful to fully inform patient counselling and treatment planning.
Conclusions
This study highlights the negative impact PHPT has on patientsâ€™ QoL, and the role parathyroidectomy has in transforming the QoL for these patients. The lack of strong correlations between biochemical markers and PAS suggests the importance of considering the symptomatic burden, and potential improvement thereof, experienced by patients when making treatment decisions for PHPT. This study supports and adds to the already existing evidence showing parathyroidectomy impacts the symptoms that most affect QoL in PHPT, and that using a symptom-based assessment tool may provide valuable complementary information for treatment planning and evaluating outcomes.

Additionally, we thank Dr Christina Koulouglioti for her assistance and guidance through the initial project planning phase and her valuable advice on processing the data.

No identifiable patient data have been shared and patients were provided with an opportunity to withdraw consent at any point in this study.
