DeepSeek R1:
This research paper investigates the optimal needle depth for temporomandibular joint (TMJ) arthrocentesis, a minimally invasive procedure used to treat TMJ disorders such as arthralgia and internal derangement. The study aimed to improve the safety and efficacy of the procedure by determining precise needle insertion depths based on MRI measurements of the TMJ anatomy. Conducted retrospectively at Istanbul Medipol University, the study analyzed 264 TMJ MRIs from 132 patients (91 females, 41 males) aged 16â€“68 years. Measurements were taken at four entry points (anterior lateral, anterior medial, posterior lateral, posterior medial) and condylar angles were assessed to evaluate anatomical variations.

Key findings revealed gender-based differences, with females requiring shorter needle depths than males across all measurements (p < 0.05). No significant age-related differences were observed, though a weak inverse correlation between condylar angle and age was noted, suggesting shallower needle depths for patients with higher condylar angles. The study concluded that a 20 mm needle depth is generally safe and effective for TMJ arthrocentesis, aligning with previous recommendations but providing more precise, patient-specific guidelines.

The study highlights the importance of tailoring needle depth to individual anatomical variations to minimize complications such as nerve damage. Limitations include the lack of body mass index (BMI) data and patient classification based on specific complaints, which could influence needle depth requirements. The findings are particularly valuable for novice surgeons, offering a standardized approach to improve procedural safety and outcomes. Future research with larger, more diverse cohorts is recommended to further validate these results and refine clinical guidelines.

Title: Optimising oral cancer reconstruction: a retrospective cohort study on the modified radial forearm free flap technique to eliminate the need for a secondary donor site
Author: Huang, Weijia; Chen, Victoria; Xie, Zefeng; Rezaei, Azadeh; Liu, Yanming
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: The radial forearm free flap (RFFF) is commonly used in the reconstruction of oral cancer patients. Traditional RFFF (TRFFF) techniques, which often require a secondary donor site to repair the forearm defect, may result in a scar extending to the dorsal hand. This can lead to significant functional and aesthetic concerns in the forearm. We designed a modified RFFF (MRFFF) that incorporates a glasses-shaped flap and features deep venous drainage. To evaluate its effectiveness we conducted a retrospective chart review of 105 patients with oral squamous cell carcinoma who underwent reconstructive surgery between 2018 and 2022. These patients were treated either with a TRFFF (n = 60) or the newly developed MRFFF (n = 45). Our inclusion criteria, guided by preliminary surgical experience prior to initiating the study, stipulated that single oral defects should be no larger than 6 Ã— 6 cm2, and adjacent double defects no larger than 3 Ã— 6 cm2. Flap size, pedicle length, harvesting duration, and anastomosis during the surgical procedure were compared between the two techniques. Preoperative and postoperative oral function, recurrence, mortality, and dorsal scarring were recorded. One-week, one-month, and six-month postoperative subjective aesthetics assessments, and self-reported postoperative donor hand function, were measured using the Michigan hand questionnaire (MHQ). There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of flap size, pedicle length, harvesting time, anastomosis time, postoperative oral function, recurrence, and mortality. However, patients with a MRFFF did not require a second donor graft site and did not have scars extending to the dorsal forearm. They also had significantly improved postoperative aesthetic outcomes (1 week: 70.6%, 1 month: 62.2%) and donor hand function (1 week: 54.6%, 1 month: 40.4%) compared with the TRFFF group (p < 0.001). The MRFFF eliminates the need for secondary donor sites and improves primary donor site outcomes. It is versatile and can be employed for either single or composite oral defects. Through extensive case studies, we have defined its specific scope: it is suitable for single defects measuring no more than 6 Ã— 6 cm2, or for composite defects no larger than 3 Ã— 6 cm2. Furthermore, it does not compromise the functional recovery of the recipient site, and should be widely adopted for all qualifying patients.
Body:
Introduction
The rising prevalence of oral and oropharyngeal cancer1â€“3 has led to an increase in the use of microvascular free flaps for reliable and anatomically accurate orofacial reconstruction.4,5 Since its introduction in the 1980s, the vascularised radial forearm free flap (RFFF) has been used widely to reconstruct orofacial soft tissues following tumour ablation, with flap survival rates between 90% and 98.3%.6â€“8 However, harvesting the radial artery can lead to hand ischaemia and reduced functionality,9,10 and damage to the sensory branch of the radial nerve can result in diminished grip strength and loss of sensation.11,12 The traditional RFFF (TRFFF) also requires a second donor site, such as the abdomen or thigh, to restore the primary donor site. The TRFFF usually grafts the cephalic vein, which can extend the initial incision into the dorsal forearm and make scars more noticeable.13,14 Despite these donor site morbidities, the TRFFF remains the preferred option for defects of the tongue, palate, and mucosa6,15 due to its consistent vascular anatomy, design flexibility, and versatility.
To minimise the risks associated with donor site injuries, several surgical techniques have been proposed, including primary closure,16â€“18 full-thickness and split-thickness skin grafts,19,20 dermal substitutes,21 and negative pressure therapy.22 Although studies have shown that these methods can reduce the size of the donor site to some extent, they may not be suitable for all patients, and the use of an artificial dermis often results in significantly higher costs.
To address these concerns, we propose a modified RFFF (MRFFF) technique. This innovative approach incorporates deep venous drainage and a glasses-shaped design, which aims to improve both functional and aesthetic outcomes by eliminating the need for a secondary donor site. By harvesting the deep vena comitans or radial artery instead of the cephalic vein, the incision can be limited to the dorsal hand, making the scar less visible. Additionally, the design of the glasses shape eliminates the need for a second donor site. In 2015, Zhang et al used two rectangular RFFFs to avoid a second donor site in 11 cases.23,24 The objective of the technique is to obtain double skin paddle flaps that are narrower than those gathered using the traditional method. The approach facilitates tension-free closure at the donor site, thereby minimising morbidity and enhancing cosmetic outcomes.25
This study aimed to evaluate the significant postoperative donor site differences between patients who underwent TRFFF and MRFFF techniques for orofacial reconstruction. The outcome measurements included one-week, one-month, and six-month postoperative oral function assessment, as well as aesthetic and functional assessments of the forearm donor site, as measured by subjective scores and the Michigan hand questionnaire (MHQ).
Patients and methods
Inclusion
The charts of 105 patients who underwent RFFF reconstruction for various orofacial defects due to ablation of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in our department between January 2018 and June 2022 were retrospectively reviewed. According to preliminary surgical experience prior to initiating the study, patients should have single oral defects no larger than 6 Ã— 6 cm2, or adjacent double defects no larger than 3 Ã— 6 cm2. Among the 105 patients, 65 and 40 underwent TRFFF and MRFFF reconstruction, respectively. This study conforms to the ethical standards outlined in the present version of the 1964 Declaration of Helsinki, and was approved by the ethics committees of our hospital.
Surgical process and flap data collection
All patients had preoperative assessments using Doppler ultrasonography and the modified Allen test to evaluate the ulnar artery and vein in the donor forearm, and to confirm adequate collateral flow within the hand. TRFFF reconstruction was completed following the protocol described by Soutar.26 The forearm fascia, radial artery, and cephalic vein or vena comitans of the radial artery were harvested in flap sizes ranging from 3 Ã— 3 cm to 6 Ã— 6 cm.
In the MRFFF group, skin laxity was assessed using a pinch test. Cases with a pinch width of less than 1.5 cm were included in the study, as they achieved primary closure with minimal tension in incisions up to 6 cm wide. The surgical protocol for MRFFF is shown in Figs. 1â€“3. Following tourniquet inflation, the radial artery and vena comitans were traced on the skin. The double paddle kiss flap was designed to resemble the shape of glasses, with two adjacent semicircular skin paddles, each with dimensions not exceeding 6 Ã— 3 cm. Following tourniquet deflation (Fig. 1), the forearm fascia, radial artery, and vena comitans were harvested (Fig. 2). Prior to transfer, the distal paddle was rotated counterclockwise by 180Â° and sutured to the proximal paddle along its straight edge, thereby creating a circular, double-width flap measuring up to 6 Ã— 6 cm (Fig. 3). After transfer, the donor site was closed primarily with 4-0 Vicryl (Ethicon) and 5-0 Prolene (Ethicon) sutures. During the surgical process, the flap size, pedicle length, and the time spent on flap harvesting and vein anastomosis were measured and recorded for each patient.

Fig. 1 Surgical protocol for modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF). Step 1: design of the glasses-shaped double paddle flap.

Fig. 2 Surgical protocol for the modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF). Step 2: harvesting the flap.

Fig. 3 Surgical protocol for modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF). Step 3: merging of the flap.
Outcome measurement
Functional assessment of donor site
Postoperative hand function outcomes at one week, one month, and six months were documented using the Michigan hand questionnaire (MHQ), which is widely used in the assessment of postoperative hand function in TRFFF donor site outcomes. The MHQ was developed in 1998 by Chung et al.27 to standardise the evaluation of various health state domains experienced by patients with hand disorders.28
Aesthetic assessment of donor site
Two hand surgeons independently evaluated the postoperative aesthetic outcomes at one week, one month, and six months on a scale of 0â€“10 (0 being unacceptable and 10 being satisfactory for the aesthetic assessment). The final score was calculated by averaging the scores. Figs. and 5 illustrate the typical three-month postoperative outcomes of the TRFFF and MRFFF groups, respectively.

Fig. 4 Three-month postoperative appearance of the traditional radial forearm free flap (TRFFF).

Fig. 5 Three-month postoperative appearance of the modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF).
Oral function assessment
Preoperative and postoperative oral function outcomes were assessed at one week, one month, and six months by two surgeons. The following five aspects were assessed: orofacial pain, mouth opening, swallowing, language expression, and masticatory function. Each aspect was scored on a scale of 0 to 10 (0 being unable to function and 10 being functioning well), resulting in a total score of 20.
Statistical analysis
The chi-squared test and Studentâ€™s t test were used to compare demographic characteristics between the two groups. Normal distribution testing was conducted, and statistical significance was set at p<0.05. ANOVA was used to compare the postoperative MHQ and aesthetic scores between groups. All statistical analyses were performed using IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows version 29.0 (IBM Corp).
Results
Demographic characterisation
A total of 105 patients who underwent RFFF for orofacial reconstruction were divided into two groups: 65 patients who underwent TRFFF and 40 who underwent MRFFF. Patient demographics are shown in Supplementary 1. There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of age (p = 0.66), sex (p = 0.6), comorbidities (p = 0.37), smoking status (p = 0.3), or stage of malignancy (p = 0.07). All included patients completed one-week, one-month, and six-month follow-up evaluations.
Flap characterisation and recipient outcome
No significant differences were observed between the groups in terms of average flap size, pedicle length, harvesting and anastomosis times, and postoperative oral function. The mean pedicle length was significantly shorter in the MRFFF group than in the TRFFF group (p<0.01).
Donor site outcome
Comparison of quantitative hand function and aesthetic outcomes
After the surgical process, scarring rates on the dorsal side of the hand were observed to be 0% in the MRFFF group and 72.31% in the TRFFF group, respectively (Supplementary 2). At one-week and one-month postoperative assessments, patients in the MRFFF group had significantly higher MHQ scores than those in the TRFFF group (p < 0.05). At these postoperative assessments, MRFFF patients also had significantly higher aesthetic scores than TRFFF patients (p < 0.05) (Table 1).

Discussion
To our knowledge, this study is the first retrospective cohort analysis to explore the utilisation of the MRFFF featuring deep venous drainage and a â€˜kiss flapâ€™ design in oropharyngeal reconstruction. Over a span of five years, we evaluated 105 patients diagnosed with SCC. All patients successfully underwent tumour ablation and subsequent RFFF reconstruction, 65 with the traditional technique and 40 with the novel modified technique described above.
The MRFFF has a distinct advantage over the TRFFF as it provides a thin, pliable, and well-vascularised pedicle, which facilitates reliable and aesthetically pleasing reconstruction of oral and oropharyngeal tissues without the need for a secondary donor site. We conducted this retrospective analysis to quantitatively assess donor site outcomes and determine whether the MRFFF could offer superior functional and aesthetic benefits. Our findings show that, compared with the TRFFF, the MRFFF more quickly restores hand function and improves six-month postoperative aesthetics without compromising oral function.
In addition, harvest of the vena comitans of the radial artery avoided an extended incision on the dorsal hand, and the glasses-shaped design led to better wound closure than that of the rectangular shape presented by Zhang et al.23,24 Without the sharp angles of a rectangle, the gentle curve of the glasses shape is easier to align.
Demographic characterisation showed no significant difference in age, sex, comorbidities, smoking status, or malignancy stage between the groups, making them comparable at baseline. For the average flap size, no significant difference was observed in harvesting and anastomosis times, and postoperative oral function. Due to the design of the MRFFF (two parallel semicircles on the forearm), the maximum pedicle length is shorter than that of the TRFFF. However, in practice, the length of the MRFFF is sufficient for oral facial vascular reconstruction. This is consistent with the recipient outcomes, which showed no significant difference in postoperative oral function between the TRFFF and MRFFF.
It is crucial to consider the limitations of the study design when interpreting the results. First, only patients who presented for six monthsâ€™ follow up were included. Additionally, we evaluated postoperative donor site hand function with the widely accepted patient-based MHQ assessment, and two hand surgeons, who used the mean score to determine the aesthetic result, evaluated postoperative donor site aesthetic outcomes. However, to better quantify the results, future studies should incorporate objective methods, as both methods relied on subjective evaluations. Finally, the complexity of the surgery as well as the variability in patient demographics and orofacial involvement contribute to the lack of randomised controlled trials in this field. Therefore, while limited by these parameters, retrospective cohort studies have become the second-best option to provide evidence.
Conclusion
The MRFFF with deep venous drainage and a glasses-shaped design is a reliable technique for orofacial reconstruction in patients with oral cancer. Successful reconstruction was achieved in all 105 (100%) patients included in the study. The technique eliminates the need for a second donor site while significantly improving donor site function and cosmesis. The MRFFF is suitable for single defects measuring no more than 6 Ã— 6 cm2, or double defects no larger than 3 Ã— 6 cm2. Future prospective studies involving follow up are now required to determine the true utility of this procedure, which may represent an improved approach to the treatment of a complex clinical problem.

Rising rates of oral and oropharyngeal cancer have increased the demand for reliable microvascular free flaps for orofacial reconstruction. Traditionally, the radial forearm free flap (TRFFF) has been favored for its consistent vascular anatomy, design flexibility, and versatility in reconstructing soft tissue defects after tumor ablation. However, the TRFFF is associated with significant donor site morbidities such as hand ischemia, sensory nerve damage, reduced grip strength, and conspicuous scarring that may require a secondary donor site.

This study retrospectively evaluated 105 patients with squamous cell carcinoma who underwent orofacial reconstruction between January 2018 and June 2022. Sixty-five patients received the traditional technique while 40 underwent a modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF) procedure. The innovative MRFFF incorporates deep venous drainage by harvesting the vena comitans of the radial artery and employs a novel â€œglasses-shapedâ€ double paddle design. This design limits incisions to the dorsal hand, avoids a secondary donor site, and facilitates tension-free primary closure.

Outcome assessments included postoperative hand function measured by the Michigan Hand Questionnaire, aesthetic evaluations by hand surgeons, and oral function tests at one week, one month, and six months. The MRFFF group demonstrated significantly improved early hand function and aesthetic outcomes, with a 0% dorsal hand scarring rate compared to 72.3% in the TRFFF group, while maintaining comparable oral function. Despite a slightly shorter pedicle length, the MRFFF offers a promising alternative that minimizes donor site morbidity and improves cosmetic results. Future prospective studies are recommended to further validate these findings. Results strongly support MRFFF.

This study investigates a modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF) technique for orofacial reconstruction following oral cancer ablation, aiming to improve donor site outcomes compared to the traditional RFFF (TRFFF). The MRFFF utilizes deep venous drainage and a "glasses-shaped" design to avoid a secondary donor site and minimize scarring.

The researchers retrospectively reviewed 105 patients who underwent RFFF reconstruction (65 TRFFF, 40 MRFFF). The study assessed postoperative oral function, hand function (using the Michigan Hand Questionnaire (MHQ)), and aesthetic outcomes at one week, one month, and six months.

Results showed no significant differences in flap size, harvesting/anastomosis times, or postoperative oral function between the groups. However, the MRFFF group demonstrated significantly better hand function and aesthetic scores at early postoperative assessments (1 week and 1 month), and improved aesthetics at 6 months. The MRFFF also eliminated dorsal hand scarring. The study concludes that the MRFFF offers improved donor site outcomes without compromising oral reconstruction, offering a potentially superior approach for suitable patients with single defects no larger than 6x6 cm2, or double defects no larger than 3x6 cm2.

This research paper evaluates the outcomes of a modified radial forearm free flap (MRFFF) technique for orofacial reconstruction in patients with oral cancer, comparing it to the traditional radial forearm free flap (TRFFF). The MRFFF incorporates a glasses-shaped design and deep venous drainage, aiming to eliminate the need for a secondary donor site and improve both functional and aesthetic outcomes. The study retrospectively analyzed 105 patients (65 TRFFF, 40 MRFFF) who underwent reconstruction following squamous cell carcinoma ablation between January 2018 and June 2022.

Key findings revealed that the MRFFF group experienced significantly better hand function and aesthetic outcomes at one-week and one-month postoperative assessments compared to the TRFFF group (p < 0.05). The MRFFF also achieved primary closure without extending the incision to the dorsal hand, reducing scarring. Both techniques showed similar oral function outcomes, with no significant differences in flap size, harvesting time, or anastomosis time. However, the MRFFF had a shorter pedicle length, which did not compromise its effectiveness.

The study highlights the MRFFF as a reliable alternative for orofacial reconstruction, particularly for single defects up to 6 Ã— 6 cmÂ² or adjacent double defects up to 3 Ã— 6 cmÂ². It offers improved donor site aesthetics and function without requiring a second donor site. Limitations include the retrospective design and reliance on subjective assessments. Future prospective studies are recommended to further validate the MRFFF's utility and long-term outcomes. Overall, the MRFFF represents a promising advancement in addressing the complex challenges of oral cancer reconstruction.

Title: Oral and maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) ‘controlled’ second-degree places in the UK – there are sufficient numbers (with high application ratios) to meet current and future OMFS recruitment needs in the UK
Author: Magennis, Catherine; Davies, Anna; King, Rhydian; Ilahi, Nida; Morgan, Roseanna; Stonier, Gemma; Howson, Kate; Dattani, Amit; Hamps, Christopher; Rowe, Aimee; Jenkyn, Ian; Basyuni, Shadi; Magennis, Patrick
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: In 2008 the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB) Review of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) recommended that OMFS specialty training should start with second-degree studies. This recommendation has not yet happened. Currently, no OMFS controlled places at medical/dental schools are directly linked to OMFS Specialty Training (ST) posts. ?OMFS controlled? in this paper refers to dedicated places on shortened second degree courses to which OMFS specialists/trainers have the key role in selection. Freedom of Information requests were sent to 14 medical schools known to have OMFS ?controlled? second-degree MB places: Aberdeen, Birmingham, Bristol, Cambridge, Cardiff, Glasgow, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester, London?Kings, London?QMUL, Newcastle, Plymouth and York/Hull. Information was also requested from the London-Kings BDS Dental Programme for Medical Graduates (DPMG). These data were supplemented by information from consultants and trainees with experience of the processes. Replies were received from six medical schools in Birmingham, Cambridge, Glasgow, Liverpool, London-Kings, and London-QMUL, plus the dental school of London - Kings DPMG. These seven programmes provide approximately 30 OMFS controlled places per year. The application ratios, between 5:1 and 29:1, are significantly more competitive than selection to ST1 and ST3 places. There are more OMFS controlled second degree places than presented in this paper which only details universities from whom replies were received. If all students in OMFS controlled second-degree places progressed to ST without loss, there are more than sufficient to fill all available OMFS ST places. Linking OMFS controlled second degree places through to OMFS ST posts would deliver the key PMETB recommendation in a process which would be more competitive than current ST selection. For OMFS trainees whose first degree was medicine, OMFS selected places at shortened dental courses are needed outside London.
Body:
Introduction
This paper is designed to address three gaps in knowledge about oral and maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) controlled places for second degree studies i.e. medical/dental school places allocated to OMFS trainees to which OMFS specialists/trainers are the â€˜keyâ€™ selectors.
The number of OMFS specialty-controlled places and their locations are published to help those stakeholders involved in recruitment and workforce planning to understand this key step in dual-degree OMFS. Contemporaneous information on second degree places is published by the Junior Trainee Group (JTG) of the British Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons (BAOMS)1.
The application ratios for OMFS â€˜controlledâ€™ second-degree places may be a proxy for the attractiveness of the specialty to doctors and dentists. Applying for a second degree is not something which is done lightly.
Information about the process of applying for OMFS controlled places is included to help doctors and dentists who have made the decision to pursue a career in OMFS.
Method
Universities with OMFS specialists/trainers involved in the selection process for second-degree places were contacted and asked for information about their processes using Freedom of Information (FoI) requests. Additional information was collected from OMFS trainees who were students on these courses and from OMFS specialists involved in the selection processes by direct contact.
Results
Responses were received from the medical schools of Aberdeen, Birmingham, Bristol, Cambridge, Cardiff, Glasgow, London-Kings, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, London-QMUL and York/Hull2. The BDS DPMG of London-Kings also returned data.
No replies with numerical data were received from the medical schools at Aberdeen, Bristol, Cardiff, Leeds, Manchester, Newcastle, Plymouth or York/Hull Universities. The nature of the data returned from the other universities made it difficult to create a single comparison table but did provide useful information about total applications and total places. Some universities replied with the text â€˜fewer than fiveâ€™ rather than numbers for some categories of data to avoid breaches in data protection. This made their returns less useful.
Data supplied from universities was combined with information from analysis of second-degree locations of specialty trainees and specialists.3
Birmingham medicine
Average applications per year 40.7, average places filled per year 3.4, application ratio 12:1
Birmingham supplied information (Table 1), which is an exemplar for this purpose. We would encourage those involved in OMFS controlled places to keep a similar summary. That said, there were also OMFS trainees who obtained places to study medicine in Birmingham through the normal UCAS (Universities and Colleges Admissions Service) process rather than the official OMFS controlled places. These â€œunofficialâ€ OMFS second degree students will make the attrition rate for those in the official places an under-estimate because OMFS specialists and trainees whose second degree was from Birmingham medical school will include those who secured OMFS controlled places and those whose places were obtained outside this process (Table 1 and Figure 1).

Over the 10 years for which data were supplied, 407 dentists applied for the second-degree places at Birmingham Medical School with an average of 40.7 per year (range 27â€“67). Of these a total of 110 were offered an interview with an average of 11 interviews per year (range 6â€“14). A total of 54 places were offered with an average of 5.4 per year, of which 34 students enrolled an average of 3.4 (range 1â€“5).
Data from current OMFS trainees and consultants
The OMFS team at Birmingham were early to recognise the value for the specialty of OMFS controlled second-degree places. The first OMFS trainees received places at a four-year course in 1985. In 1996 it became a three-year course.
In some individual years all places translated into specialty training places. In others (1995, 2008, 2011) none of those offered places pursued an OMFS career. Over the 30 years Birmingham have been offering places to OMFS trainees, of approximately 144 second-degree OMFS trainees, 64 (44%) entered OMFS specialty training (Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Second degree graduates from Birmingham Medical School by year of graduation showing numbers who became OMFS specialists or trainees
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
The â€˜second-degreeâ€™ option is a point of entry for dental graduates directly to year three of the five-year MBChB (A100). Candidates are not expected to have completed the UCAT (University Clinical Aptitude Test). Having completed the membership exam of the Faculty of Dental Surgery (MFDS) is essential.4
Since the COVID-19 pandemic, interviews have been conducted remotely in two parts covering commitment to medicine, audit and research followed by a clinical situation with an adverse outcome.
The West Midlands is a large geographical area which offers adequate opportunities for OMFS work and out of hours emergency dental work.
Cambridge medicine
Applications per year 29, places one, application ratio 7:1
The data returned from Cambridge covered six years 2014â€“2019. There were 175 applications, 21 places were offered, 17 places accepted of which seven have completed their studies. The mean applications per year were 29 with a mean of 4 places offered per year.
A total of 13 OMFS trainees and consultants obtained their second-degree in medicine from Cambridge, about four every decade since 1980.
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
The graduate programme has expanded recently. The collegiate system offers support with academic and extracurricular pursuits. Local units provide regular employment, mentorship and discretional study budget from a charitable trust. Students can also teach anatomy and work in local dental practices. Students are eligible for a Â£5600 per annum Cambridge bursary. There are opportunities to take part in high quality research.
Application involves the Graduate Course in Medicine application form in addition to UCAS and UCAT, but dentists are exempt from the requirement of A level chemistry within seven years.
Glasgow medicine
Applications per year 19, places per year 1â€“2, application ratio 10:1
The data returned from Glasgow, 2019â€“2024, were too recent for any graduates to have entered specialty training. They averaged 19 applications per year with six interviews offered for 1â€“2 places. The FoI said that there were fewer than five places per year offered.
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
The pathway to the three-year medical degree in Glasgow was overhauled recently. Applications are directly through the Universityâ€™s website and shortlisted candidates are interviewed by OMFS Surgeons and Medical School faculty. Successful applicant(s) enter Year Three with an intensive and rigorous semester of didactic teaching. During the third and fourth years, students undertake two Student Selected Components (SSC) and two electives. These give plentiful opportunities for clinical, research and academic work with the OMFS team which help with BAOMS bursaries, publications and presentations. Local OMFS units have on-call and other contracted clinical work which can ensure pay is protected on starting foundation training in the Scottish system.
Liverpool medicine â€“ short course for dental graduates A101
Applications per year 22, places filled two, application ratio 11:1
Liverpool University were only able to generate incomplete data shown in Table 2. There have been 179 applications for the eight years for which data is available, a mean of 22.4 applications per year (range 15â€“32). If similar numbers applied in the two years for which there are no data, there would be approximately 220 applications over 10 years.

Data about candidates interviewed is available for nine years with a total of 71 candidates and an average of 7.9 per year (range 7â€“14).
Twenty-five places were offered over the 10 years (average 2.5 per year, range 2â€“3) of whom a total of 22 enrolled (average 2.2 and range 2â€“3). The reasons for offered places being declined were mostly the acceptance of a second degree place at another university whose location/course was more preferable to the trainee.
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
Applications are made through UCAS to join second year of the A101 programme, with a supplementary application on Liverpool Universityâ€™s website.5 There is strong support from the Regional OMFS unit during their second-degree studies.
Applicants require to have passed both parts of the membership dental examinations Membership of the Joint Dental Faculties (MJDF) or Membership of the Faculty of Dental Surgery (MFDS) and one year of OMFS experience. No further admission tests are required. Shortlisted OMFS applicants have a panel interview led by local OMFS surgeons, which may be online with a CV and logbook sent in advance.
Studies are completed in âˆ¼34 months with opportunities for student selected components and electives.
Work is available in various surrounding units in Liverpool, Manchester, and North Wales.
London-Kings dentistry: Dental Programme for Medical Graduates (DPMG)
Application number 11 â€“ places per year 10, application ratio â€“ 1:1
The data returned from Kings (Table 3) regarding the DPMG do not seem to reflect the experience of those students and trainees who provided feedback about the programme.

Background to DPMG figures
The DPMG6 started in 2007 as a way for doctors to acquire a dental qualification as part of training in OMFS. This coincided with the Medical Training Application System (MTAS)7,8 which prevented surgeons with â€˜too muchâ€™ experience in a specialty from applying to train in that specialty. For OMFS, the second-degree â€˜resetsâ€™ the training clock so many of the initial DPMG students were from this background.
Data from current OMFS trainees and consultants
Table 4 shows DPMG graduates currently in or who have completed OMFS training. At 10 per year, 150 doctors would have completed the DPMG8 programme since 2007 and so the 74 DPMG graduates in OMFS would represent 49% success. The majority of DPMG graduates who have entered OMFS did so from their final year of the programme as they had completed Core Surgical Training and their MRCS prior to entering the programme.

Of those DPMG whose OMFS training programme is known, the majority (n = 49 [66%]) joined training programmes in the South-East of England (London 26, East of England 10, Kent/Surrey/Sussex five, Wessex five, and Oxford three). (Fig. 2).

Fig. 2 Oral and maxillofacial surgery specialty training rotations to which DPMG dental graduates join â€“ South East of England v other rotations
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
Entry to the three-year DPMG course is competitive via UCAS and consists of a panel interview with both dental and OMFS faculty. There are no entrance exam requirements. Common points of entry are post-FY2 and post-CT2 with MRCS. The introduction of more ST1 posts has made post-FY2 entry more appealing. Students join the dental course in the third year, quickly starting in a simulated clinical environment alongside the undergraduate students. DPMG students are taught a bespoke programme via tutorials as well as being expected to engage in self-motivated learning.
London-Kings medicine - shortened course for dental graduates
Application number 15, places per year five, application ratio â€“ 3:1
The data from Kings about their shortened medical course 2019â€“2024 is shown in Table 3. Total applications were 73 over five years, with 56 entering selection and 25 students enrolled.

Until very recently, the General Medical Council registered medical degrees from all London medical schools in the same way. This makes it impossible to identify a traineeâ€™s university from the medical register. In collaboration with the QMUL, who compared their list of 32 students entering their programme between 2014 and 2017 against a list of current OMFS Specialty Trainees (STs) it was found that 12 (38%) of the graduates in their dual-degree programme were in Specialty Training posts in OMFS (10) or Oral Medicine (2). Looking year by year the 2014/15 had one of five in OMFS (20%), of 2015/16 4 of 8 (50%), of 2016/17 four of seven (57%), of 2017/18 two of seven (29%), and of 2018/19 one of five (20%). Three trainees from these periods left before completing the course.
Of the 10 OMFS STs, three were appointed in Kent/Surrey/Sussex (2) and London (1) with the remaining seven in East of England (1), Mersey (2), Oxford (1), Wales (2) and Yorkshire (1). This shows QMUL is contributing to OMFS training across the UK. Their selection criteria place a high value on tangible financial support (locum sessions) from the region from which the trainees apply. They also had high participation in the BAOMS Mentoring and Support Programme.9,10
Information from second-degree OMFS trainees
QMUL offers an OMFS three-year course and was founded by Professor Iain Hutchison in 1996. Applications open in Autumn and are outside the usual UCAS process thereby leaving four places on the UCAS application for other medical schools. Details of how to apply can be obtained from smd-direct-entrants@qmul.ac.uk.11 Panel interviews run in Spring. Applicants are required to have MFDS/MJDF, minimum 12 months of OMFS and BAOMS membership. UKCAT (or equivalent) is not required.
Successful applicants join the undergraduate third year after a week induction with a crash course in clinical examination and procedures. The clinical years involve teaching weeks and clinical placements alongside Student Selected Components (SSCs) and an elective in fifth year. There are ample opportunities to work in London and connect with OMFS units. Graduation at St Paul's Cathedral is very memorable!
Discussion
Data on all the OMFS controlled places are not included in this review. Some universities did not return numerical data there are likely to be others of which the authors were not aware. OMFS controlled places are constantly evolving and readers are recommended to join the BAOMS Junior Trainee Group which has up-to-date information1 on second degree studies.
The total numbers of applicants for OMFS controlled places cannot be added together as, in each year, those aiming for OMFS will apply using the four spaces available on their University and College Admission Scheme (UCAS) online application. Direct application to London-QMUL for medicine can be in addition to their UCAS form. These data suggest that there are lots of young dentists and doctors who want to be OMFS surgeons in spite of the current financial and life-style commitments required.12â€“14 This is consistent with previous questionnaire based surveys.15,16
The OMFS training programmes in the UK require between 25 and 30 trainees per year.17 The exact number each year depends on which points of entry (ST1/ST3) and how many current trainees choose to extend their time in training by working Less Than Full Time or through fellowships or research.18 ST1 posts include 1â€“2 years of core surgical training and the opportunity to pass the MRCS exam, before they â€˜Run-Throughâ€™ into OMFS specialty training. OMFS ST3 posts are open to applicants who have either completed core training or can demonstrate readiness to enter specialty training with supporting evidence.19
If a national selection process for entry to OMFS controlled second degree places is to be created lessons should be learnt from the existing OMFS controlled selection processes, particularly the ones which have the lowest â€˜drop-outâ€™ rate. There is support from all grades in the specialty19 for selection of OMFS trainees into a Fully Integrated Dual Degree OMFS Specialty Training programme which uses a regional process with national benchmarking.
There are more OMFS controlled places than were available in the last publication on this theme.20 If OMFS controlled could be linked to OMFS Specialty Training (ST) posts, as recommended by PMETB,21 there should be many fewer trainees lost to other specialties.22 Creating these Fully Integrated Dual Degree OMFS Specialty Training programmes (which some call â€˜OMFS Run-Through Maxâ€™)19,23 is supported by the specialty19,24 and the specialty association25,26 and could reduce the costs in time and money for all those involved.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
None needed.
Funding
No funding.

This research addresses three significant gaps in understanding the allocation and impact of OMFS controlled second-degree placesâ€”positions in medical or dental schools specifically earmarked for OMFS trainees selected by OMFS specialists. The study investigates how these dual-degree opportunities are structured and how they influence workforce recruitment into the specialty.

The authors obtained data using Freedom of Information requests to universities involved in the selection process and supplemented this with direct feedback from OMFS trainees and specialists. Respondents included institutions such as Birmingham, Cambridge, Glasgow, Liverpool, London-Kings, and London-QMUL. For example, Birmingham Medical School reported an average of 40.7 applications per year for its OMFS places, with roughly 3.4 students enrolling and an application ratio of approximately 12:1. Comparable competitive figures were noted at other universities, though variations in reporting and data presentation (e.g., â€œfewer than fiveâ€ responses) complicated direct comparisons.

Additional insights came from specialized programmes like the Dental Programme for Medical Graduates (DPMG) at London-Kings and OMFS entry courses at London-QMUL, which revealed distinct admission processes and pathways. The research highlights that despite the considerable commitment required, there is substantial interest among young dentists and doctors in pursuing an OMFS career.

In conclusion, the paper recommends that integrating OMFS controlled places with specialty training posts could streamline the progression into OMFS, reduce trainee attrition, and lower financial and time costs. Such fully integrated dual-degree training programmes are supported by both the specialty and its professional bodies, promising improvements in recruitment and workforce planning.

This research paper examines the application and selection processes for second-degree medical or dental school places controlled by Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) specialists in the UK, focusing on the attractiveness of OMFS as a career and the pathways for dual-degree training. The study emphasizes the importance of regional support, mentorship, and financial incentives in retaining trainees in OMFS.

Title: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Accelerated Dental Programme for Medical Graduates: A review of fourteen graduating years (2010-2023)
Author: Holden, Adam Matthew; Cabot, Lyndon B; Turner, Jonathan; Fan, Kathleen
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: The accelerated dental degree, pioneered by King?s College London (KCL) to facilitate dual qualification training pathways for primary medical degree trainees, has graduated its fourteenth class. The authors present data to demonstrate and analyse the success of the course, which was accumulated through an online questionnaire, direct communication with the alumni, a freedom of information request from KCL and review of the General Dental and Medical Council registers.To date 133 students have graduated with updated information collated for 132 (99.2%). Thirty seven percent of the students are female which is comparable to the wider NHS consultant workforce. Over 70% (n=95) of graduate?s work within a dual qualification specialty, with women more likely to than men. Dentistry was the second most common career path at 16.8% (n=23) and is most likely due to the draws of primary dental care over the NHS secondary care. Attrition rates of the KCL students at each stage of the career pathway were equal to or fewer than other university undergraduate medical and dental degrees, the dentistry-first pathway and other higher surgical training schemes. KCL alumni attest to 29% of the OMFS higher surgical trainees, with the average time between GMC provisional registration and specialist registration being 14.7 years (range 12-19).The authors strongly advocate the success of the accelerated dental degree in KCL and would encourage other institutions around the United Kingdom to accept the model to increase accessibility and build on the success of the primary medical degree OMFS surgical trainee programme.
Body:
Background
Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) is a unique surgical specialty requiring dual qualification in medicine and dentistry. Originating as a dental specialty, there was a move in the 1970â€™s towards dual qualification due to the increasing severity and complexity in the procedures being performed, culminating on 16 March 1984 with the FRCS(OMFS) examination being ratified by the Royal College of Surgeons of England and the first diet occurring 17â€“22 January 1985. 1

Since then, there has been increased interest in OMFS by primary medical graduates who gain little exposure in their undergraduate degree but become aware of it in the post graduate workplace. In order to capitalise on this, and through a collaboration between Health Education England (HEE) and Kings College London (KCL) the three-year undergraduate Dental Programme for Medical Graduates (DPMG) was devised, with provisional funding allocated and the first intake commencing in September 2007 2 for the attainment of a Bachelor of Dental Surgery that is fully registerable with the General Dental Council.

The DPMG course involves students completing the second and third years of the undergraduate programme in their first year with subsequent assimilation into the undergraduate fourth year in the DPMG second year. 3 All aspects of the standard undergraduate programme are completed with some rationalised topics that were covered in depth within medical undergraduate training, including anatomy and human disease. Attendance in these modules is exempt to allow participation elsewhere, but all examination commitments are fulfilled. Throughout the first year there are intense tutorials with world-renowned experts, professors, and senior tutors in all aspects of dentistry with ongoing mentorship by all faculty, current students, alumni and OMFS Consultants long after graduation.

Originally, each year consisted of eight DPMG students with up to four additional students placed on the Graduate/Professional Entry Programme (GPEP) to allow back fill of the DPMG course. This, however, was changed with the 2015 intake to include 10 DPMG and two GPEP after agreement with HEE. Students are typically self-funded with the aid of Student Finance maintenance and tuition loans. At the time of inception, the tuition fees were Â£3000 per academic year, and although this has since risen to Â£9250, 4 a National Health Service (NHS) Bursary is available from the second year up to Â£3191 per year. 5 To finance this shortfall it is common for students to do locum work or fellowship roles, which are plentiful in and around London. 4

Material and methods
The data were collated through dissemination of an online questionnaire, direct updates to the authors, a freedom of information (FOI) request to KCL and review of the General Medical Council (GMC) and General Dental Council (GDC) registers and subsequently analysed. Ethics approval for the project was approved through KCL.

Results
Part of the entry descriptions for the DPMG and GPEP pathways, as defined by Kings College London (KCL), is the course is designed for doctors wishing to pursue a career in OMFS, Oral Medicine or Oral Pathology, 3 therefore we include these specialties in the data collection and analysis. Between the graduating years of 2010 and 2023, 137 students started the accelerated pathway of which the authors were able to find the status of 132 (96.4%); four students failed to graduate and were lost to follow up, and one studentâ€™s outcome was unverified. Genders, as defined on the GMC register, were collated with an overall male to female ratio of 1.7:1 (M = 87, F = 50). This ratio becomes closer when in higher surgical training at 1.5:1 (M = 50, F = 33), and diverges significantly for those that become General Dental Practitioners, 2.8:1 (M = 17 F = 6).

Further data from the GMC register that included the dates of provisional registration and entry on to the specialist register, combined with the graduation dates, enabled analysis between these time periods. The average number of years between provisional registration and KCL graduation was 6.3 years (range 3-13), provisional registration and entry onto the specialist register was 14.7 years (range 12-19) and between KCL graduation and the specialist register was 7.25 years (range 5-12). A gender divide of one year (M = 14.3 vs F = 15.4 years) is evident in the time between provisional registration and entry onto the specialist register.

In total 70% (n = 95) of alumni are in a dual qualification training or are consultants, however, only one graduate has taken a career into oral medicine and none into pathology. Further breakdown demonstrates 51.6% (n = 49) are within OMFS training at various points ( Fig. 1 ), and of the 158 OMFS trainees 6 KCL students equate to 29% (n = 46) and only one out of 95 students to enter into higher surgical training changed career at this point.



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 1
Career Outcomes of Students.
The most common alternative career is dentistry (16.9%, n = 23). Since the first graduating class of 2010 there have been four students (3%) who did not complete the programme, equating to 0.3 students per year. In addition, 3% (n = 4) of students are have left healthcare, which is equal to other dental courses, 3% 7 and lower than in medical courses, 4%. 8 The FOI request sent to KCL, demonstrated in Table 1 , compares the admission and qualifications of each of the individual courses that Kingâ€™s provides, which allows comparative analysis during the same period, but, unfortunately, breakdown of the graduate entry programme of whom were medical graduates was not available.

Table 1
Admission and qualifications of each of the individual courses that Kingâ€™s College London.

Dentistry        1430        1350        94.4

Discussion
The DPMG was established to facilitate an organised and accelerated route for primary medically qualified OMFS trainees to gain dual qualification and proceed onto speciality training in OMFS, oral medicine, and oral pathology. This has been successful, with 133 students graduating and 95 (70%) entering a dual qualification specialty, many of whom would likely have not chosen the career pathway without the existence of the programme. The tailored programme allows accelerated learning, bypassing sections previously completed through medical school and concentrating on the additional requirements to become fully registerable dentists. A testament to the course quality is the number of students who have chosen to work in dentistry post-qualification, demonstrating they felt fully enabled and competent to take up the role. While this is essential with the current requirement for dual qualification, it is somewhat unavoidable that a proportion, 16.9% (n = 23), will choose dentistry as a new career path. These alumni would likely have chosen this option regardless of the KCL degree resulting in a registerable dental degree and more of a demonstration of the current situation of working within the NHS. This is in part due to the significant financial advantages of UK dentistry, where the average salary in London is Â£141 500. 9 The non-financial cost of training has also recently been highlighted by the Association of Surgeons in Trainingâ€™s report in 2024 10 in which half of trainees were considering practise abroad, 76% reported a negative impact on their physical health, and 84% on their mental health.

To the authorsâ€™ knowledge, this is the first publication to analyse the specialty retention of dually qualified medicine-first OMFS trainees and there is no recently published data on dental-first trainees. It is therefore difficult to directly compare the KCL course with other courses for trainees entering the specialty and is an area for further research. Magennis and Ong 11 did present, at the British Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons Annual Scientific Meeting in 2008, a 10-year follow-up survey of 170 dental graduated students with 61% (93/153) either being OMFS Consultants or trainees. These data are over 16 years old but when compared with the KCL alumni entering a dual qualification pathway we present a higher rate of 70% (n = 95/137), further demonstrating the effectiveness and importance of the programme. One potential for this difference is that it is generally considered that for a medic, the attainment of dentistry only creates dentistry as an alternative career and the applicants are further down the specialisation trajectory. This is in direct contrast to a dentist undertaking medical training, where the entirety of medicine and surgical careers are available following graduation.

While more men enter the KCL programme, comparatively fewer are going into OMFS and a higher proportion become dentists. Fifty of the 137 students were women (36.5%) which is in line with the overall gender difference in the consultant body in 2020, 36% 12 and our data show a small gender difference with time to entry onto the GMC specialist register of one year. This could be multifactorial with an area for further research, but with the average only being one year (range M, 12â€“17 vs F, 13â€“19) and women more likely to enter training, further efforts should be made to showcase the career to aspiring female surgeons. The average time between attainment of provisional and specialist registration was 14.7 years (range 12â€“19), which is longer than the minimum period of 11 years and likely due to attainment of higher research degrees, transfers from other surgical training pathways, part time training, and participation in dental training jobs. This is further demonstrated by the variation between provisional registration and KCL graduation, 6.3 years (range 3â€“13) and then attainment of specialist registration, 7.25 years (range 5â€“12). With this age data we can infer the likely average ages of KCL trainees at different points during the training with the average age of provisional registration 24 years old, alumniâ€™s KCL graduation age likely 30.3 years old (range 27â€“37) and entry onto the specialist list 38.7 years old (range 36â€“43). This demonstrates the extensive variability in the length of training, but also that the majority will attain specialist registration before 40.

A FOI request to Kings College London was performed to investigate and compare the number of students that complete each of the medicine and dentistry courses, including the three shortened courses for graduate-entry as second degree in OMFS training. This is demonstrated in Table 1 and combined with our data where the 137 students who started dentistry as their second degree, 97% (n = 133) completed the course. An article in the Times newspaper in 2014 13 also demonstrated a 5% drop out rate of medical students across all universities through a similar FOI request. This is higher than the 3% (n = 4) from our cohort and when compared with the other Kingâ€™s programmes, as well as nationally, our alumni rate is favourable and demonstrates attrition rates that are not specific to second degree therefore should be considered a comparative success.

Our data demonstrate that a high percentage, 48.4% (n = 46/95) of the alumni are on the consultant pathway. This is due to the different stages at which people enrol, ranging from after Foundation Year 2 to the career change of Registrars from other specialties. As a result, it can therefore take a variable amount of time to reach consultancy and the attrition of each stage with all specialties will also apply. This attrition rate for OMFS has been described by Khalil et al 14 as 2.48% over a five-year average. This was slightly lower than the average for all surgical specialties at 2.68% and only applies to those with national training numbers, whereas in our data series to date this only occurred in one case (1.06%, n = 1/95). This demonstrates the importance of the course to the specialty as well as the alumniâ€™s commitment; when graduates enter higher surgical training they almost always compete it and work in OMFS. This is at a better rate than the five-year average for the specialty as well as every other surgical specialty, the next lowest being Neurosurgery at 1.72%. Our data also suggest that with 46 having current OMFS national training numbers, the KCL course contributes to almost 29% of the total 158 national OMFS higher surgical trainee workforce as of 2023, 6 which further demonstrates the essential role the programme has in training OMFS consultants and we would suggest this is likely a stable representation. We also attribute the ongoing success in the students continuing along the pathway to the extensive mentorship and community attributed to the programme. At points where students and alumni can become disenfranchised, this valuable role can encourage and support students reminding them of the reasons they chose the career.

Only one of the alumni has chosen a career, other than OMFS, that is attainable through dual qualification even though it is open to Oral Medicine and Oral Pathology trainees, 3 we propose the reasoning for this is that for a primary medically qualified student, other comparable specialties are available without the need for dual qualification and therefore a more attractive option.

Conclusion
Overall, it should be considered that the KCL course is a successful addition to the OMFS training pathway through enabling over 80 primary medical students to pursue careers within OMFS in an accelerated fashion allowing faster career progression and decreased financial burden. Almost thirty percent of OMFS higher surgical trainees are alumni of the course with lower appreciable attrition rates compared with other routes in all stages of their careers. To additionally appreciate the success in the instigation of the course, further analysis is needed to compare against the percentage of primary dentists and primary medics in other courses and their long-term commitment to the OMFS specialty, which the authors feel would likely be comparable if not lower.

The authors also strongly advocate that the course be expanded to other regions around the United Kingdom, supplying OMFS trainees to low uptake areas while offering increased availability with reduced relocation and living costs. Further efforts also need to be made in streamlining and shortening training in order to continue providing high quality Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons and safeguard the long-term future of the specialty and the public.

Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Ethics granted by Kings College London. Patient permission not applicable.

Funding
No funding.

Title: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Curriculum (2021) and Oral Surgery Curriculum (2023): A forensic comparison of two documents
Author: Capanni, P M; Magill, S; Walker, T; Varley, I; Magennis, P
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: In the UK Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) and Oral Surgery (OS) are distinct specialties governed respectively by the General Medical Council (GMC) and General Dental Council (GDC) respectively. There has always been overlap of training and care between both specialties. The OMFS curriculum was updated in 2021 and the Oral Surgery Curriculum in 2023. This paper quantitatively compares the two documents. The generic professional elements of both curricula are extensive and similar in content. The specialty specific elements of the OS and OMFS curricula, with focus on knowledge domains and competencies including index procedures and critical conditions, were compared with the level of coincidence colour coded: green (matching), amber (some overlap) and red (not present). OMFS curriculum contains all components of the new UK OS curriculum with the exception of formal documented competence in conscious sedation for dentistry. This overlap between OMFS and OS has been recognised by the General Dental Council who give OMFS specialists direct access to the Oral Surgery specialist list by Route 4. In contrast, the OS overlap with OMFS is limited, particularly in the important critical/emergency conditions where ?competence? has been replaced by ?experience of? in the 2023 OS curriculum in the domains of trauma and acute infections. This change will preclude OS specialists trained on the new curriculum being able to share on-call with OMFS specialists without significant additional training. We hope this comparison will be useful to those commissioning services and also for young dentists/doctors considering their future careers.
Body:
Introduction
The General Medical Council undertook a planned review of all medical curricula between 2017 and 2022 including the OMFS curriculum. The core elements for being a specialist doctor were common across all the curricula. The OMFS curriculum was written by the OMFS Specialty Advisory Committee (OMFS SAC), a sub-committee of the intercollegiate Joint Committee for Surgical Training (JCST) and finalised in 2021. 1 The OMFS curriculum, in common with the curricula of all surgical specialties, also requires trainees to have attained competencies in the UK Core Surgical Training Programme 2 before entry to specialty training. The 2021 OMFS curriculum is integrated into the Intercollegiate Surgical Curriculum Programme, the online portfolio with which all UK surgical training is managed, The OMFS curriculum also defines the syllabus/blueprint for the FRCS (OMFS) exit exam and was a key element in the development of the OMFS European Training Requirement (OMFS ETR). 3

In 2017 the General Dental Council started a review of all the dental specialty curricula. Their aim was to modify all dental specialty curricula to follow a similar structure with generic elements common across all specialties. The GDC also asked all dental specialties to focus on the core knowledge and skills required for each dental specialty. The OS curriculum was written by the Oral Surgery Specialty Advisory Committee (OS SAC) which is a sub-committee of the inter-collegiate Joint Committee for Higher Training in Dentistry (JCHST). The OS SAC invited comments and contributions from all stakeholders including the UK Committee of Postgraduate Dental Deans and Directors (COPDEND), the British Association of Oral Surgeons, the British Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons, and the OMFS SAC. There were many iterations of the curriculum until the final version was approved by the GDC on 23 January 2023 4 and published on its website shortly thereafter. The 2023 OS Curriculum is self-contained and does not have extra-curricular requirements or include â€˜extended competenciesâ€™.

In light of the recently updated specialty curricula, 14 and having previously reviewed the curricula for Foundation/Core OMFS and OS, 56 we sought to quantitatively analyse and compare the new OS and OMFS curricula to establish areas of overlap and difference. The aim was to help all those involved with commissioning OS and OMFS care for patients to understand the similarities and differences between the specialties. It might also help those considering their future careers to ponder their options.

Methods
Both the 2021 OMFS and 2023 OS curricula were examined and deconstructed into their respective domains. The Oral Surgery Curriculum was mapped to the OMFS curriculum and the OMFS curriculum, including the UK Core Surgical Training curriculum, was mapped to the OS curriculum. During the analysis a â€˜traffic lightâ€™ system Red, Amber, Greenâ€™, also called a RAG rating, was used to grade the degree of overlap for each procedure/competence/domain. Green indicated that there was substantial coincidence in that domain/competence, Amber indicating some overlap, and Red indicating an area not covered in corresponding curriculum. 7 Where the raters did not agree on the RAG rating, these were discussed to allocate to an appropriate rating. A consensus was achieved for all domains/competencies after discussion and group review.

Oral Surgery curriculum overlap with OMFS curriculum
Analysis of the OS curriculum identified nine domains with a total of 127 competency-based statements. Comparison with OMFS curriculum showed that 118 (93%) of the competencies were green - having complete overlap - with eight (6%) amber and one (1%) red. Four of the OS domains (44%) were completely matched by OMFS, five (56%) were mostly green with some amber areas, with only one domain recording a red score. These results are summarised in Table 1 .

Table 1
Oral Surgery Critical Conditions and curriculum domains: overlap with OMFS competence.

 View full size
*Managing life-threatening airway compromise does not include competency in front of neck access.
** Spreading infections does not include independent practice of surgery to the neck e.g. management of necrotising fasciitis.
*** Does not include severe/life threatening haemorrhage e,g, control of neck vessels.
**** Refers to patients who have been referred to oral surgery specialist.
The â€˜redâ€™ area not covered in OMFS curriculum was from Domain 4 and related to documented competence in the safe and appropriate delivery of inhalational and conscious sedation as an independent practitioner.

Changing the focus to â€˜index proceduresâ€™ within the OS curriculum where competency at level 4 (independent practice) is required, there is complete overlap with the OMFS index procedures with the exception of competencies in solo sedation. For OS Index Procedures where â€˜experience ofâ€™ or â€˜simulationâ€™ is the level of competence required, the OMFS curriculum requires competency at Level 4 (independent practice) except implant placement where the same level of competency is required i.e. â€˜experience ofâ€™ Level 1-2. ( Table 2 ).

Table 2
Oral Surgery Index Procedures â€“ overlap with OMFS. Level 4 independent practice except were indicated in blue.

 View full size
Looking at the syllabus of knowledge within the OS curriculum, it is also important to note that there are domains without matching index procedures i.e. where competence at the level of independent practice is not required on completion of training. The most important of these where OS specialists have â€˜knowledge ofâ€™ rather than â€˜competency inâ€™ are: managing life-threatening airway compromise, life-threatening spreading infections, acute sight-threatening orbital trauma/complications, life-threatening haemorrhage and management of the critically ill patient.

OMFS curriculum overlap with oral surgery curriculum
The OMFS curriculum (134 pages) is more than 100 pages longer than the OS curriculum (32 pages) and has a different structure. The General Medical Council required all specialty curricula to be based around generic elements common across all medical specialties. These are Capabilities in Practice (CiPs) and a General Professional Capacities (GPCs). 8 The CiPs and GPCs are the constituent parts of the role of a specialist in OMFS. Each part is as important as the next, and doctors are required to be capable in all elements of the role of specialist surgeon in order to be able to practice independently. Whilst the definitions of GPCs do not exactly map to GDC generic domains, there are sufficient similarities in principle and practice between GPC in the OMFS curriculum and the generic elements (Domains 1-4) of the OS curriculum that these were accepted to be the same by all authors.

In the specialty specific elements of the OMFS curriculum there was full overlap with oral surgery in the 56 elements of the Dentoalveolar Module of the OMFS curriculum including the 24 clinical skills in this Section. There was overlap with the â€˜dentoalveolarâ€™ component of the OMFS indicative numbers (green) and some overlap (amber) in management of oral dental infections and soft tissue trauma such as closing lacerations. Outside these there is no other overlap in the OMFS indicative numbers with the OS curriculum. ( Table 3 ).

Table 3
OMFS Indicative Numbers/Competencies overlap with Oral Surgery â€“ Level 4 independent practice except where indicated in blue.

 View full size
For CiPs there is some overlap in outpatient working but the referrals accepted by oral surgeons will not match those of OMFS because referring dental and medical practitioners may refer differently based on the perceived differences between the specialties. Similarly, the CiP for multi-disciplinary working will have some overlap but there will be differences in the skills and knowledge brought by each specialist. These were marked as Amber because, for the numerical bulk of referrals, there would be expected to be overlap OMFS CiPS and OMFS Critical Conditions are summarised in Table 4 . There is no overlap of OMFS Critical Conditions with the Oral Surgery curriculum.

Table 4
OMFS Critical Conditions and Competencies in Practice: overlap with Oral Surgery.

 View full size
Discussion
By analysing the competencies and domains required for GDC registration as a specialist in OS alongside those for specialists in OMFS, we have created a broad framework for comparison of the specialties with both qualitative and quantitative assessment. Some of the text associated with OS competency statements were considerably longer than others, with many containing subsections. RAG rating and the presentation of these data graphically gives a three-tiered assessment tool rather than a binary yes/no assessment to take into consideration the complexity of qualitative comparison. â€˜Traffic lightingâ€™ guided discussion between the assessors, particularly in those areas of ambiguity, allowing for a consensus grading to be achieved in all cases.

Surgeon led sedation
Our analysis found that the Oral Surgery Curriculum sits within the OMFS Training curriculum except for competencies in â€˜surgeon led sedationâ€™ ( Fig. 1 ).



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 1
Oral Surgery Curriculum Overlap with OMFS Curriculum represented graphically - overlaps and differences are not to scale.
The Intercollegiate Advisory Committee for Sedation in Dentistry (IACSD) developed standards for the safe delivery of sedation by dental teams in the UK; these were updated in 2020. 7 It details the training required by members of the dental team to provide sedation, including mentored cases.

The Association of Medical Royal Colleges (AMRoC) 9 highlights the requirement of all professionals involved in the provision of conscious sedation to have relevant airway management and life support skills (both of which are covered by the OMFS curriculum). The demonstration of continued professional development required by AMRoC would be demonstrated for OMFS trainees at their Annual Record of Competency Progression (ARCP). It would be expected that OMFS trainees could, if they wished, be able to demonstrate the relevant competencies defined by the AMRoC, if they did not already have IACSD documentation.

Emergencies and on-call
The complete lack of concordance of the OS curriculum with OMFS CIP 2 â€˜management of an unselected emergency takeâ€™ and the OMFS Critical Procedures is one of the most important differences between the OMFS and OS curricula. This represents a significant change between the 2023 OS curriculum and the previous iteration with the new document requiring â€˜experience ofâ€™ rather than â€˜competence inâ€™ these areas. This change may not yet be noted by hospitals, commissioning bodies or trainees. Competence at Level 4 for independent practice in these areas would be essential for participation in an â€˜on-callâ€™ rota with consultants in OMFS.

Route 4 for OMFS specialists to join the OS Specialist List
Comparison of both curricula would support the General Dental Council maintaining this simple route for OMFS specialists who wish to join the OS specialist list voiding unnecessary bureaucracy.

Conclusion
Oral Surgery and OMFS in the UK share a common ancestry. For a spell in the 1980s and 1990s there were programmes for those who held solely a dental qualification to complete an academic training pathway 10 and become a Consultant Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeon with competencies and skills across the whole OMFS curriculum. This route stopped with the creation of specialists lists in Oral Surgery (dental) and Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (medical and dental) in 1996.

Much has happened since the 2008 Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB) Report on OMFS Training 11 and the consequent Medical Education England (MEE) review of Oral Surgery Training in 2010. 12 The facts on the ground have changed. Only a very few current oral surgery consultants have a clinical practice which includes the â€˜extended competenciesâ€™ of the 2013 Oral Surgery curriculum, competencies which have been replaced by â€˜experience ofâ€™ in the 2023 curriculum. This change was anticipated at the time of the MEE review. 13 The surgical experience of OS specialists in 2010 was nearer to the 2023 than the 2013 curriculum. 14 In the UK and across the world there remains some confusion between the scope of the two specialties. 15

Within many secondary care services, multi-disciplinary teams provide Oral Surgery and Oral and Maxillofacial Services with specialists, doctors and dentists working with integration, cohesion and cooperation. This collaborative working, combined with the problems of coding procedures within secondary care, 16171819 has led to confusion amongst service providers and other stakeholders.

The competencies in the Oral Surgery curriculum overlap with OMFS in the areas of dentoalveolar surgery, oral medicine and oral diagnosis. In the knowledge domains there is considerably more overlap.

Oral Surgery specialists trained to the standards required by the 2023 OS curriculum are appropriately focussed on dentoalveolar surgery with â€˜experience ofâ€™ but not â€˜competency inâ€™ the management of serious cervicofacial infections, serious haemorrhage, facial fractures, sight-threatening emergencies and management of the critically ill patient. If OS specialists participate in on-call rotas, without significant additional training they would need the support of an OMFS specialist who has the competencies to manage an unselected emergency take and unwell inpatients. This may be the decisive factor when a Trust is considering appointing and OS or and OMFS consultant.

This narrowing of the OS curriculum may generate a potential problem for the very experienced solely dentally qualified non-consultant staff whose practice within OMFS departments sits outside the 2023 Oral Surgery curriculum and for current Oral Surgery specialists. In 2024 the General Dental Council stated that temporary dental registrants cannot work in the medical specialty of OMFS 2021 and must restrict themselves to the specialty of Oral Surgery. It is not clear if the GDC considers that a similar approach is required for fully registered dentists nor whether, when it refers to â€˜Oral Surgeryâ€™, it is referring to the practice defined by the 2023 Oral Surgery curriculum. If the GDC restricts future practice of Oral Surgery specialists and OMFS SAS grades to the Oral Surgery Curriculum it could impact on patient care.

We hope this illustrated comparison will aid those planning and delivering services. It may also give food for through to those considering future careers in either specialty.

Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Not needed.

Funding
No funding.

The OMFS curriculum, developed by the OMFS Specialty Advisory Committee under the Joint Committee for Surgical Training, integrates core surgical training competencies, is embedded in a broader intercollegiate framework, and defines the syllabus for the FRCS (OMFS) exit exam. In contrast, the OS curriculum, created by the Oral Surgery Specialty Advisory Committee with input from multiple dental and surgical stakeholders, focuses on the core knowledge and skills specific to oral surgery without including extended competencies.

To compare the two, the researchers deconstructed each curriculum into defined domains and mapped competencies using a â€˜traffic lightâ€™ (Red, Amber, Green) system. Analysis of 127 competency-based statements in the OS curriculum revealed that 93% were fully aligned (green) with OMFS competencies, 6% showed partial overlap (amber), and 1% (related to the independent delivery of inhalational and conscious sedation) had no corresponding element in the OMFS curriculum. Additionally, while index procedures required for independent practice were largely consistent between the curricula, notable differences emerged in areas such as emergency management and on-call competencies.

The study underscores that although OS and OMFS share a common historical foundation, the OS curriculum is now more narrowly focused on dentoalveolar surgery. These distinctions have significant implications for clinical service planning, on-call responsibilities, and future career pathways for specialists in these fields.
