Discussion
Following a thorough analysis of eligible papers, a review on patient factors, procedural factors and post-operative outcomes was performed. The analysis highlights a critical gap in current literature on BMAF. This scarcity significantly limits the ability to draw comprehensive conclusions and suggests that our current understanding of BMAF management is based on a narrow scope of evidence.
Patient demographics, mechanisms of injury and associated injuries were reported in in Table 1. The mean age of patients was 25 years, with 94.9% of all cases being male. This is in line with general trends of maxillofacial injuries. However, BMAF shows a higher predilection for males-affected compared to general maxillofacial injuries, where 80% of those affected are males.[16], [17], [18], [19] The leading cause of BMAF was interpersonal violence, accounting for 76.8% of cases. Comparatively, interpersonal violence is responsible for approximately 60% of general maxillofacial injuries.[18], [19] The stronger predilection for males compared to general trends of maxillofacial injuries may be explained by the higher rates of interpersonal violence as a cause for BMAF.20 There was similar mechanism of injuries reported between studies regardless of them being performed in different locations. However, both studies performed in Australia showed a higher prevalence of sports-related injury.
Only one study reported associated facial injuries (10.7%), with no data on other injuries.1 Given that concurrent facial, cervical spine, and neurological injuries frequently accompany mandible fractures, this emphasises a gap in reporting of BMAF and underscores the broader limitations imposed by the scarcity of studies. [16], [21] Future studies should aim to address this by providing comprehensive data on concurrent injuries and their impact on BMAF management.
Data on procedural timing, surgical approach, and fixation methods were reported in Table 2 and varied among the included studies. Surgical timing reporting was inconsistent, however, all studies highlighted the importance of early primary management. One study reported a median operation time of 3 days, another stated that all operations were performed within a week of presentation.[2], [3] No studies discussed precise imaging protocols, including timing of radiographs or use of panoramic vs CT imaging.
The surgical approach was delineated based on the incisions at each fracture site, as different surgical approaches were often employed for each fracture. The transbuccal approach was the most common, utilised in just over half (53.2%) of surgical sites, followed by intraoral and then combined intraoral-and-transbuccal approach. There was discrepancy between two authors on the best approach for when a superior lateral border plate (Champy technique) was used. One paper demonstrated preference for a transbuccal approach, citing lower complication rates compared to when an intraoral approach is used.3 However, one paper preferred using an intraoral approach for the Champy technique, citing reduction in facial nerve injury, easier technique, quicker patient recovery and avoidance of facial scars.2 Selection of the approach varied based on the fixation method applied, surgeon preference and patient-specific factors.
Similarly, there was significant variation in the fixation methods between studies. Non-rigid/rigid fixation was the common fixation, employed in over half (55.4%) of cases. In cases where non-rigid/rigid fixation was used, there was a preference rigid fixation at the more displaced fracture. Fracture displacement was nonuniformly categorised and reported in the studies, posing a limitation to this review.
Definitions of rigid fixation varied among studies. This was seen by differences between Young et al3 and Raidoo et al1 in the width required to be considered rigid fixation. This lack of standardisation posed a limitation, as rigidity was reported based on the individual surgical methods of each study.[1], [3]
Postoperative IMF was uncommonly used; employed in under one-in-ten (9.2%) cases. Segura-PallerÃ¨s et al4 used post-operative IMF for 2 weeks exclusively for cases of non-rigid/non-rigid fixations, claiming bilateral non-rigid fixation was insufficient for maintaining interfragmentary reduction. However, Young et al3 employed 52 cases of non-rigid/non-rigid fixation, and only implemented post-operative IMF in three of these cases. With comparable outcomes observed with contrasting IMF usage, this suggests that IMF may not be universally required in non-rigid/non-rigid fixation. Decisions should be tailored to patient-specific factors and fracture complexity.
Impacted lower third molars were present in 91.6% of fracture sites. However, it is important to note that one study excluded all cases without impacted lower molars.4 The association between BMAF and impacted third molars supports previous studies that demonstrate that impacted third molars increase the susceptibility of the mandible to angle fractures.[5], [6], [7] Impacted third molars were extracted in over one-third (36.7%) of the cases where they were present in the fracture site. While Cillo et alâ€™s findings couldnâ€™t be quantified for this analysis, they reported that 27 patients had at least one impacted lower third molar and all of these were removed during management of BMAF. A 2023 review on removal of third molars in mandible angle repair demonstrated that retaining asymptomatic molars in fracture sites may result in lower overall complications and less IAN damage.5 Indications for extracting the third molar have been suggested, including cases where there was a pathology associated with the tooth or if the molar interfered with fracture reduction, however, there is insufficient evidence to substantiate these indications. The studies contributed insufficient uniform clinical data regarding whether extraction of impacted third molars alters BMAF outcome prognosis and hence no unified consensus on this exists yet. Thus extraction risks or considerations must weigh alongside surgical expertise, individual anatomical features and clinical judgement.
Complications following BMAF management were reported in Table 3. The overall incidence of postoperative complications was 18.2%. Infection was the most common complication (n=11), followed by malocclusion and hardware failure. Revision surgeries were performed in approximately 1 in 10 surgeries, primarily due to infection and hardware failure. Surprisingly, this is lower than the reported revision surgery rate for isolated mandible fractures in some studies.22 One proposed explanation for this disparity is the varying surgical experience among surgeons managing isolated mandibular fractures as opposed to BMAF.
In three studies, complication rates were able to be discussed at a fracture-level and compared between the method of fixation. Complication rates between fractures managed with rigid and non-rigid plates was similar (9.7%, 9.5% respectively). Similarly, no individual study reported changes in complications based on the overall fixation status. Previous retrospective studies on other types of bilateral mandible fractures suggested that non-rigid/non-rigid fixation was associated with significantly higher major complications when compared to rigid/non-rigid fixation of bilateral mandible fractures.23 However, recent RCTs have demonstrated successful outcomes with both non-rigid/non-rigid and rigid/non-rigid fixation.24 These results emphasise patient-specific factors and surgical experience in fixation decisions. Young et al. demonstrated an increasing preference for use of non-rigid/non-rigid fixation in the later stages of its study; noting surgical ease and reduction in surgical cost and operation time as advantages to this technique.3 Other papers demonstrate preference for rigid/rigid fixation in cases of severe displacement fractures and difficult reductions.4 Overall, whilst there is insufficient evidence that specific fixation methods are associated with higher rates of complications, these findings suggest that clinicians should rely on a case-by-case assessment, incorporating patient-specific factors, fracture complexity, and their own surgical expertise to guide fixation decisions.
At a review level, the limited number of studies available for inclusion underscores the imperative for future research endeavours with robust methodologies, standardised protocols, comprehensive reporting, and consistent outcome measures. Exclusion of non-English publication is a further limitation of the study, through restricting the breadth of studies eligible for inclusion in the review. At a study level, addressing the challenges posed by inconsistent reporting highlights the importance of adopting standardised approaches for reporting. Specifically, future studies should apply more consistent classification of fixation status, imaging protocols, identifying associated injuries, and categorising fracture displacement.
In conclusion, this systematic review provides valuable insights into the clinical characteristics, treatment outcomes, and complications associated with BMAF. By adhering to rigorous methodology and transparent reporting, this review informs of current clinical practice in BMAF management, contributes to the existing literature on BMAF, and guides future research endeavours. Further well-conducted research is essential to building upon the understanding of this rare and complex maxillofacial injury. Addressing this gap in literature is crucial for expanding knowledge, improving evidence-based decisions and advancing patient outcomes.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Not applicable
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

This systematic review examines bilateral mandibular angle fractures (BMAF), a rare and challenging subset of mandibular injuries that account for about 2% of cases. Predominantly affecting young males in their third decade, BMAF are frequently associated with impacted lower third molars, which compromise the mandibleâ€™s structural integrity. Commonly resulting from interpersonal violence, motor vehicle accidents, sports injuries, or falls, these fractures are complicated by the biomechanics of three detached mandibular fragments. The opposing force vectors often result in anterior open bite, malocclusion, trismus, and temporomandibular joint pain, making prompt and precise management critical.

Following PRISMA guidelines, the review searched PubMed and Scopus for English-language studies from January 1993 to November 2023. Out of 181 identified records, four studies met the inclusion criteria, providing data on 198 BMAF cases. Demographic analysis revealed that 94.9% of patients were male, with interpersonal violence emerging as the leading cause. The review details diverse procedural factors, noting that imaging (with CT as the gold standard), surgical approaches (with transbuccal incisions used in over half the cases), and fixation techniques (ranging from rigid to non-rigid methods) varied widely across studies. Impacted third molar management was inconsistent, with extractions performed in roughly one-third of cases.

Overall postoperative complications occurred in approximately 18% of cases, with infection, malocclusion, and hardware failure being the most common. The review highlights significant gaps and heterogeneity in the current literature, underscoring the need for standardized protocols and more robust, well-designed studies to optimize clinical outcomes in BMAF management.

This systematic review examines the management of bilateral mandibular angle fractures (BMAF), a rare and complex subset of mandibular fractures, which predominantly affect young males and are often associated with impacted third molars. The review synthesizes data from four studies (198 cases) to evaluate patient demographics, surgical approaches, fixation methods, and postoperative outcomes. BMAF are primarily caused by interpersonal violence (76.8%), with sports injuries, motor vehicle accidents, and falls being less common. Surgical management typically involves transbuccal (53.2%) or intraoral (29.9%) approaches, with non-rigid/rigid fixation being the most common method (55.4%). Impacted third molars were present in 91.6% of cases, with 36.7% extracted during surgery.

Complications occurred in 18.2% of cases, with infection being the most frequent (n=11), followed by malocclusion and hardware failure. Revision surgeries were required in 10.6% of cases, primarily for infection and hardware issues. The review found no significant difference in complication rates between rigid and non-rigid fixation methods (9.7% vs. 9.5%). Postoperative intermaxillary fixation (IMF) was used in 9.2% of cases, with mixed opinions on its necessity for non-rigid/non-rigid fixation.

The review highlights the lack of standardized protocols for BMAF management, particularly in imaging, fracture classification, and fixation definitions. It emphasizes the need for future research with robust methodologies and standardized reporting to improve evidence-based decision-making. The findings suggest that surgical decisions should be tailored to patient-specific factors, fracture complexity, and surgeon expertise. Overall, this review provides valuable insights into BMAF management, guiding clinical practice and future research to enhance patient outcomes.

Title: Survey of United Kingdom oral and maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) specialists and trainees about the reasons that they retain or drop their registration with the General Dental Council (GDC) including a summary of changes in the numbers registered with the GDC 2014-2023
Author: Magennis, Patrick; Hutchison, Iain
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: When dual degree OMFS training was mandated in the UK in 1995, OMFS specialists were required to be registered with both the General Dental Council (GDC) and General Medical Council (GMC). In 2005 this legal requirement for dual registration with both regulators was removed. During 2021 the authors surveyed UK OMFS specialists and trainees asking them why they chose to remain on or leave the Dental Register to give context to the changing numbers of OMFS specialists and trainees holding Dental Registration between 2014 and 2023. In 2014 of 539 OMFS specialists and trainees only 62 (12%) were solely GMC registered, that is, they had let their Dental Registration lapse. In 2023, of 709 OMFS specialists and trainees, 320 (45%) were solely GMC registered. Those whose first qualification was medicine were less likely to be dually registered. Of those who replied to the survey and remained dually registered, most (40%) based this decision on ?worries about the consequences? of dropping their dental registration. Some other reasons were not based on fact at that time. Cost was the most common reason (49%) given for dropping their GDC registration by respondents who were only registered with the GMC. On the positive side, the January 2023 GDC position statement about OMFS who are not on the Dental Register removed the GDC?s previous restriction on location of practice and teaching dental students. However the statement does not unambiguously allow OMFS surgeons to practice across the full OMFS curriculum. Will the 2023 GDC position statement alter the trend of OMFS specialists and trainees towards single medical registration?
Body:
Introduction
In the United Kingdom, OMFS decided it would be a dual degree specialty in 1984, long before any legislative changes made this mandatory. Prior to 2005 all new OMFS specialists and trainees were registered with both the dental and medical regulators. When UK law changed in 2005, following a European Union Directive 1 which removed the 1995 requirement for GDC registration, 2 OMFS specialists began to drop their dental registration. The UK OMFS specialty, at several BAOMS Annual Scientific Meetings and Annual General Meetings (AGMs) over three decades, has always voted in favour of dual degree training being mandatory 345 , recognising that the knowledge and skills gained from both degrees and training are vital to deliver the highest standard of care for OMFS patients. The most extensive, expensive and external review of OMFS training, the 2008 Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB) Review of Training in OMFS, 6 supported dual degree training and also recommended that OMFS should have a single regulator.

In 2015, when the GMC fee was Â£420 per year, the GDC increased its Annual Retention Fee from Â£576 to Â£890 for dentists. This jump in GDC fees caused many in OMFS to reconsider their GDC registration and triggered a mass departure. Having two regulators is expensive and has risks. 7 A survey was designed to assess why OMFS specialists and trainees to drop GDC registration, and also to look at the reasons that some surgeons retained their dental registration.

Method
During December 2021 an e-mail was sent to OMFS trainees and specialists asking the main reason that they chose to remain on the Dental Register or chose to let their Dental Registration lapse. The list of reasons was based on a small pilot study of 20 OMFS trainees and specialists. Respondents were invited to expand on their reasons if they wished. The options given were:

â€¢ Cost
â€¢ Risk of having GDC as a regulator (in principle)
â€¢ Risk of having GDC as a regulator (personal experience)
â€¢ Issues with CPD/CME with GDC (in principle)
â€¢ Issues with CPD/CME with GDC (personal experience)
Colleagues were asked to choose only one (the main) option. Many chose more than one option. Others offered additional reasons which were not on the list. The reasons were counted and presented as a percentage of the total reasons. Results were compiled on ExcelÂ® and analysed using WinstatÂ®.

Every January from 2014â€“2023 Freedom of Information requests were made to view the GMCâ€™s publicly available OMFS specialist list. These data were combined with a database of OMFS specialists and OMFS trainees. By comparing this merged database with the GDCâ€™s online Dental Register, OMFS specialists and trainees who were and were not on the Dental Register were identified. Results were compiled on ExcelÂ® and analysed using WinstatÂ®.

Results
Reasons for remaining on or leaving the GDC register in 2021
We received responses from 69 of 145 specialty trainees (response rate 48%). Of those replying, 50 (72%) were on both registers, 17 (25%) GMC only and for two, their status was unknown. For OMFS specialists 211 replied (response rate 43%) and of those replying 118 (58%) were on both registers and 89 (42%) were registered with the GMC only.

Table 1 summarises the replies from specialists and trainees who remained on the Dental Register. (n = 163). Not all those replying gave a reason, and some gave more than one reason. Of those replying 66 (40%) cited â€˜General worries about leaving the dental registerâ€™, 27 (17%) felt that their registration was needed for DCT supervision, 23 (14%) stayed registered to support their Private Practice, 13 (8%) were â€˜Proud to be a dentistâ€™, 10 (6%) stayed on the register because it was â€˜Needed for their CCTâ€™, 9 (6%) to allow supervision of Temporarily Registered dentists and for five (3%) it was a contractual requirement. The background to these reasons will reviewed in the discussion.

Table 2 lists the reasons given by those who were registered with the GMC only. The top reason was cost 52 (49%), then the risk associated with having two regulators 26 (24%), next problems with maintaining GDC compatible Continuing Professional Development (CPD) records 12 (11%) and finally five (5%) said that the GDC was irrelevant. Of the 12 citing CPD issues, six had personal experience of problems. Comments from medicine first group included â€˜never registeredâ€™ and â€˜irrelevantâ€™.

GDC and GMC registration
Table 3 and Fig. 1 show the changes in dual GDC and GMC registration of OMFS specialists and trainees with time. â€˜GMC onlyâ€™ specialists increased year on year with the exception of 2016â€“17. This dip followed strong advice from the UK specialty association and the UK national training advisory body (OMFS Specialty Advisory Committee â€“ OMFS SAC) of risks associated with giving up dental registration. The change between 2014 and 2015 is associated with the GDCâ€™s Annual Retention Fee (ARF) almost doubling from Â£576 to Â£890. The ARF remained at Â£890 until 2020 when it reduced to Â£680. For comparison GMC annual fees ranged up and down between Â£390 to Â£420 across the same period.

Changes of in number of OMFS Surgeons (specialists and trainees) with dual registration or GMC only registration 2014-2022.
As the survey took place during December of 2021, the most relevant statistics regarding the registration of OMFS specialists and trainees are from January 2022. Of 608 specialists and trainees whose gender was known, 82 (13%) were female and 526 (87%) male. There was no difference in the percentage of males and females having dual registration, with 45 females (54%) and 307 males (56%) â€“ chi-squared 0.82.

Of 628 OMFS specialists and trainees whose first degree (medical or dental) was known, 517 (82%) were dentistry first and 111 (18%) were medicine first. Of the 111 â€˜medicine firstâ€™ specialists/trainees, 50 (45%) were dually registered and 61 (55%) were GMC only. By contrast of the 517 â€˜dentistry firstâ€™ OMFS surgeons, 302 (58%) were dually registered and 215 (42%) GMC only â€“ chi-squared 0.01. For specialty trainees, of 88 â€˜dentistry firstâ€™ 22 (23%) were GMC only, compared to the 59 â€˜medicine first/ of whom 35 (59%) were GMC only â€“ chi-squared 0.000. The proportion of trainees from â€˜dentistry firstâ€™ and â€˜medicine firstâ€™ is different in each new cohort, which may contribute to variability in trainees.

Table 4 shows the registration of specialists and trainees by region in January 2022. Training rotations and NHS regions do not quite match perfectly. In Scotland 32 (82%) of specialists are solely on the medical register, compared with 25% in Northern Ireland, East Midlands and East of England. The Southwest has the highest percentage of OMFS specialty trainees who were GMC only with five (63%) followed by Scotland and Wales with 50%. Like differences with time, regional differences for trainees may be due to variations in â€˜first degreeâ€™ or could reflect advice from or influence of trainers.

Discussion
In this discussion we review the reasons given by OMFS surgeons to remain on or leave the Dental Register in the context of published information. The reason is in bold text at the start of each paragraph.

â€˜Worries about risks of letting registration lapseâ€™ : there had been a lack of clarity from the GDC about what it considers is a â€˜medical taskâ€™ i.e. that which it is possible for a â€˜GMC onlyâ€™ OMFS specialist or trainee to do. In the 2005 amendment to the Dentistsâ€™ Act 1984 8 the GDC allows a few unspecified â€˜medical tasksâ€™ that are not considered â€˜dentistryâ€™ to be carried out by non-dentally registered professionals provided they are suitably trained and regulated. The GDCâ€™s 2019 statement 9 did not allow OMFS specialists and trainees without dental registration to practice outside an â€˜OMFS settingâ€™ but did not define what an OMFS setting was, leaving uncertainty. For example, at the start of 2022 a UK OMFS consultant received a letter from the GDC pointing out that, as they were not on the Dental Register and their private practice website stated that they could remove wisdom teeth, they may be offering â€˜illegal practice of dentistryâ€™. The 2023 GDC update 10 provides more but still incomplete clarity. It has removed the location restriction allowing OMFS specialists and trainees to undertake â€˜medical tasksâ€™ in other settings. It says â€œ The GDC considers that a qualified person who is registered with one of the other statutory healthcare regulators should use their professional judgement to determine whether it is appropriate for them to practise dentistry using the medical task exemption when not registered with the GDC. This should involve assessment of whether the dentistry to be delivered is a necessary part of wider clinical care. The GDCâ€™s expectation is that patient safety remains paramount. â€ The statement falls short of saying â€˜medical tasksâ€™ are defined by a regulated professionalâ€™s curriculum which would allow OMFS surgeons to practice all â€˜dentalâ€™ procedures within the OMFS curriculum.

Without absolute clarity from the GDC or a change in the law, 11 it is likely that worries will persist for OMFS surgeons.

â€˜Supervising Dental Core Trainees (DCT)â€™: the UK Committee of Postgraduate Dental Deans and Directors (COPDEND) who administer and co-ordinate DCT training 12 do not require trainers and clinical supervisors to be dentally registered. Although this is made clear in BAOMS documentation including BAOMS/COPDEND Joint Position Statements 1314 this false belief persists.

â€˜Teaching dental studentsâ€™ : at the time of the survey, based on the 2019 GDC position statement, 9 OMFS specialists and trainees were not allowed to teach dental students at all. The January 2023 GDC statement 10 allows medically registered OMFS to teach dental students all of the OMFS curriculum.

â€˜Supervising temporarily registered dentistsâ€™ : only a registered dentist can be the named supervisor temporary registrants 15 (dentists whose dental qualification is not registerable in the UK). This means that if an OMFS unit wishes to be able to employ a temporary dental registrant, at least one member of staff must be on the Dental Register. In January 2023 a change to the GDC website says temporary dental registrants cannot practice in the medical specialty of OMFS. 1516

â€˜Private practiceâ€™ : Location of private practice was limited at the time of the survey to an â€˜OMFS settingâ€™ but the 2023 GDC statement does not limit OMFS practice by its location. Performance of an extraction for a patient not referred by a dentist (self-referred or referred by medical practitioners) and which is not part of other medical care may remain â€˜illegal practice of dentistryâ€™.

â€˜Oral surgery (OS) specialist listâ€™ : OMFS specialists must maintain Dental Registration to join or remain on the GDCâ€™s OS specialist list. The 1998 Statutory Instrument 17 grants a legal right for OMFS specialists to gain entry onto the OS List by Route 4. 1819202122

â€˜Problems with the GDCs requirements for Continuing Professional Development (CPD)â€™: the requirements for CPD for dentists are defined in a Statutory Instrument. 23 The GDC does not offer flexibility. A number of OMFS trainees and specialists have had notices of erasure linked to their CPD/CME documentation which was satisfactory for their medical appraisal but were not in the GDCâ€™s required format. This problem will continue without legislative change.

â€˜Needed for Certificate of Completion of Training (CCT)â€™: dental registration is not required for CCT. 24 Instead, trainees must demonstrate that their dental degree is potentially registrable or they are fully registered. The GMC has allowed at least two OMFS trainees whose dental qualifications were from outside the EU and who had not completed the Overseas Registration Examination ORE) to join the OMFS specialist.

â€˜Risk of having two regulatorsâ€™ : There is undoubtedly a risk associated with having two regulators 7 and this will persist until there is a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the GMC and GDC for the management of complaints made about dually registered OMFS surgeons. Alternatively OMFS should follow the 2008 PMETB 6 recommendation of the having the GMC as its single regulator.

Conclusions
Whilst the data about dental and medical registration of OMFS specialists and trainees are comprehensive, the response rate of less than 50% is not ideal even if this survey of OMFS specialists and trainees in the UK is one of the largest ever published.

The cost of GDC registration is the most common reason given by OMFS surgeons for letting their GDC registration lapse, followed by the risk of having two regulators.

In the survey, some reasons given by OMFS surgeons for remaining on the dental register were not fact-based at that time. Others were valid (location of care and teaching dental students) but are no longer relevant as they have been removed by the GDCâ€™s 2023 position statement. 11

Until there is more clarity from the GDC or legislative change, it would seem that the primary reason of retaining GDC registration of â€˜General worry about letting their registration lapseâ€™ continues to be valid.

Almost half the OMFS profession in the UK are only registered with GMC. The GDCâ€™s 2023 position statement does not allow OMFS surgeons to practice across the entire OMFS curriculum but rather asks professionals without GDC registration to â€˜self-regulateâ€™. It is hoped that this paper will encourage OMFS specialists and trainees to review the GDCâ€™s 2023 position statement and consider how it applies to them.

In the aftermath of Brexit, there will be a significant amount of rewriting of legislation to remove references to European Union legislation. This may offer OMFS a once-in a-lifetime opportunity to approach the government to provide legal clarity and allow the specialty to prosper. 12 We hope that this paper and our editorial will stimulate discussion 16 and promote engagement of all the relevant stakeholders.

Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
None needed.

Title: Synergistic effect of zoledronate and compressive force suppresses proliferation and differentiation of human gingival fibroblasts
Author: Hemmi, Tomoharu; Yusa, Kazuyuki; Ishikawa, Shigeo; Takano, Hiroshi; Fukuda, Masayuki; Iino, Mitsuyoshi
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: We investigated the effects of zoledronate (ZA) and compressive force, separately and in combination, on the proliferation and differentiation of human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) to verify the mechanism underlying medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ). The addition of 100Â¬â€ Â¬ÂµM ZA markedly inhibited cell proliferation. Expression of type I collagen, fibroblast growth factor 2, and connective tissue growth factor genes, was decreased by ZA and compressive force. Similar results were observed for collagen expression by using Sirius red staining. These results, together with clinical findings that MRONJ is more common in cases with excessive mechanical stress on the oral mucosa, suggest that bisphosphonates such as ZA and mechanical stress may act in conjunction as risk factors for the development of MRONJ by affecting homeostasis of the oral mucosal tissues, including HGFs.
Body:
Introduction
Bisphosphonates (BPs) are analogues of pyrophosphatases, which inhibit bone resorption by inducing osteoclast apoptosis, and thus affect bone remodelling. 1 Because of these pharmacological properties, BPs, including zoledronate (ZA) are indicated for diseases such as osteoporosis and bone metastasis of malignant tumours. Adverse effects of BP include medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ). 2 MRONJ is generally refractory to treatment, worsening a patientâ€™s quality of life by affecting multiple oral-specific complaints, including pain and problems with speech. 2

In the oral mucosa the connective tissue is composed of human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) and extracellular matrix components, especially type I collagen ( COL1 ), 3 produced by HGFs. 4 Keratinocytes use this connective tissue as a scaffold to form an epithelial and keratinising layer that acts as the physicochemical barrier on alveolar bone. 4 Additionally, the oral mucosa is exposed to constant mechanical stresses caused by occlusion and mastication. 5 Although moderate mechanical stress is considered indispensable for maintaining homeostasis by inducing HGF proliferation, which enhances the expression of transforming growth factor-Î² (TGF-Î²) at the gene and protein level, 6 excessive mechanical stress has been implicated in the pathogenesis of various dental diseases because of its effect on the oral mucosa and alveolar bone remodelling. 7 Moreover the oral mucosa protects the jawbone from oral bacteria, 4 so its loss may allow bacteria to reach the jawbone, and this may be related to the development of MRONJ.

BPs are thought to have a role in the development of MRONJ by suppressing osteoclasts, osteoblasts, and epithelial cells, including keratinocytes. 8910 Our previous study revealed that compressive force and ZA inhibit both osteoblast proliferation and differentiation. 11 However, the effects of BPs on the oral mucosa which, along with the jawbone, makes up the alveolar portion of the mouth, are unclear. We know of no studies to date that have examined the combined effect of mechanical stress and BPs on the oral mucosa.

This study therefore investigated the effects of BPs and mechanical stress on the proliferation and differentiation of HGFs with a view to verifying the mechanism underlying MRONJ.

Material and methods
Evaluation of cell proliferation and observation of cell morphology
HGVs (ScienCell Research Laboratories) were cultured in fibroblast medium (containing 10% foetal bovine serum, fibroblast growth supplement, and 100 U/ml penicillin/100 Âµg/ml streptomycin, ScienCell Research Laboratories). Zoledronate (ZA, Sigmaâ€“Aldrich) was dissolved in the medium according to the concentration of BP in each experiment. HGFs were seeded at a concentration of 2 Ã— 10 4 /well in six-well tissue culture plates (collagen type 1-coated microplate, Iwaki, Japan) and cultured for 24 hours. Then, ZA (0, 10, 100 Î¼M) was added to the medium. Cell proliferation was evaluated on days 1, 2, 3, 5, and 7 after the addition of ZA. An MTS assay (CellTiter 96 AQ One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay Kit, Promega) was used for evaluation, and absorbance was measured using Varioskan Flash 2.4 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The measurement wavelength was 490 nm. Cell morphology, under the culture conditions described above, was observed under an inverted microscope (Zeiss Primovert, Zeiss).

Application of compressive force
HGFs were seeded at 1 Ã— 10 5 /well in six-well plates (collagen-type 1-coated microplate). After a 24-hour incubation, ZA (0, 10 Î¼M) was added to the medium. A compressive force of 2.0 g/cm 2 was applied for 24 hours following the method described by Ichimiya et al. 12 After removal of the stress, incubation was continued for 24 hours in the gene expression experiment and for 72 hours in the Sirius red-staining experiment.

Gene expression of HGFs
HGFs were washed with phosphate-buffered saline (Dulbecco's PBS, Cell Science & Technology Institute Inc) and were then detached with trypsin-EDTA (Trypsin-EDTA solution: 0.25%, Sigmaâ€“Aldrich). The number of cells was adjusted to 10 3 â€“10 5 per sample. DNA was extracted using the Kaneka Easy DNA Extraction Kit Version 2 (Kaneka Corp). Real-time polymerase chain reaction was performed using TB Green Premix Ex Taq II (Takara Bio Inc) and CFX96 (Bio Rad). Gene expression levels were calculated using the Î”Î”Ct method with reference to glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH). The primers used (Perfect Real Time, Takara Bio Inc.) were for genes encoding COL1 , fibroblast growth factor 2 ( FGF2 ), connective tissue growth factor ( CTGF ), and GAPDH .

Sirius red staining
Sirius red staining was performed to examine the effects of compressive force and ZA on collagen production by HGFs. 13 After the incubation period, the medium was aspirated and the cells dried at room temperature for 24 hours, after which they were reacted with Sirius red stain (Polysciences Inc) for 60 minutes and washed with 0.1 N HCl. The stain was then dissolved in 0.1 N NaOH, and the absorbance measured at 540 nm using a Varioskan Flash 2.4 (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

Cell proliferation ability under the same culture conditions was evaluated using the MTS assay, and cell morphology and staining were observed using an inverted microscope.

Statistical analysis
The Shapiro-Wilk test was used to check for normality for all continuous variables obtained ( n = 5â€“9). As non-normality was confirmed, the Kruskalâ€“Wallis test was used for analysis, and the Bonferroni method was used for multiple testing correction. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Statistical analyses were performed with EZR version 1.60 (Saitama Medical Center, Jichi Medical University, Shimotsuke, Japan).

Results
Effect of ZA on cell proliferation and cell morphology
The control and 10 Î¼M ZA samples showed similar trends in terms of cell proliferation, but the addition of 100 Î¼M ZA markedly suppressed the cell proliferation of HGFs ( Fig. 1 ). In terms of cell morphology, the control and 10 Î¼M ZA had little impact on the spindle-shaped characteristic of fibroblasts, while the addition of 100 Î¼M of ZA caused HGFs to exhibit a spherical shape from day three, with many detached dead cells observed on day seven ( Fig. 2 ).



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 1
Effect of zoledronate (ZA) on cell proliferation of human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs). Control and ZA (10 Î¼M) samples showed similar growth curves, but the cell proliferation of HGFs was markedly inhibited by the addition of 100 Î¼M ZA (n = 9). * Statistically significant difference (p < 0.05) among ZA (0 Î¼M), ZA (10 Î¼M), and ZA (100 Î¼M). ** Statistically significant difference (p < 0.05) between ZA (0 Î¼M) and ZA (10 Î¼M).


 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 2
Effect of zoledronate (ZA) on human gingival fibroblast morphology. The control and ZA (10 Î¼M) exhibited spindle-shaped morphology, characteristic of fibroblasts, while ZA (100 Î¼M) exhibited a spherical morphology and an increase in detached, dead cells over time (Ã— 200). Scale bar: 200 Âµm.
Effect of compressive force and ZA on gene expression of HGFs
As demonstrated in Fig. 3 a, the expression of COL1 genes was reduced by compressive force (89.1%), but the reduction was not statistically significant. The addition of ZA, and the combined effect of ZA and compressive force, significantly down-regulated COL1 gene expression by HGFs (65.6% and 61.6%, respectively). FGF2 showed down-regulation by compressive force (41.0%: non-significant), and ZA (4.0%) which was statistically significant. The synergistic effect of both compressive force and ZA showed a significant reduction in FGF2 gene expression (1.6%) ( Fig. 3 b). As for CTGF , although the difference is not significant, compressive force decreased the gene expression (55.8%). ZA weakened CTGF expression (9.3%) which was significant when compared with the compressive force alone. Further diminishing was observed by the combination of compressive force and ZA (3.4%), and the difference was significant when compared with the control and compressive force ( Fig. 3 c). The most repressive gene expression of HGFs when compressive force and ZA were applied simultaneously was common to all three genes.



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 3
Effect of compressive force and zoledronate (ZA) on gene expression of human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs). a. Type â…  collagen ( COL1 ). b. Fibroblast growth factor 2 ( FGF2 ). c. Connective tissue growth factor ( CTGF ). The expression of these genes was markedly weakened by the addition of compressive force to ZA. Values represent mean and standard deviation ( n = 5). The group to which neither ZA nor compressive stress was applied is shown as control. Each gene expression was normalised by GAPDH. * p < 0.05
Sirius red staining
During the incubation period, no significant effects of compressive force and ZA on the proliferation of HGFs were observed. In the absence of ZA addition, there was no marked change in collagen production by HGFs when compressive force was applied. On the other hand, the addition of ZA significantly attenuated collagen production, which was further weakened by the addition of compressive stress ( Figs. 4 and 5 ).



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 4
Effects of zoledronate (ZA) and compressive force on collagen production by human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) (microscopic image). Collagen production of HGFs was decreased by the addition of ZA and compressive force (Ã— 200). Scale bar: 200Âµm.


 View full sizeOpen full size image
Fig. 5
Effects of zoledronate (ZA) and compressive force on collagen production by human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) (absorbance). The absorbance was attenuated by ZA and was markedly reduced by the addition of compressive force to ZA. Values represent median, interquartile range, maximum and minimum (n = 9). * p < 0.05. ** p < 0.01.
From the above results, it is speculated that the observed attenuation of collagen expression by ZA administration and compressive stress is not due to the inhibition of cell proliferative capacity.

Discussion
The clinically specific finding of MRONJ is osteonecrosis of the jaw with soft tissue defects, which suggests that disruption of homeostasis in oral soft tissue may influence its development. Oral soft tissues are exposed to intermittent mechanical stresses from tooth contact and denture bases due to mastication, 61214 and the organ is subjected to various forces such as tension and shear stress. 15 While mechanical stress is thought to have an important role in maintaining homeostasis in periodontal tissue, 6 it exacerbates various oral diseases, such as periodontitis and peri-implantitis, when it is excessive. 12 In this study, based on the assumption that the oral mucosa is subjected to mechanical stresses, for example, from mastication and denture bases, we examined the effects of compressive force and ZA on the proliferation and differentiation of HGFs. Our findings suggest that ZA and mechanical stress may act in conjunction to affect homeostasis of the oral mucosal tissues, which may promote the development of MRONJ.

According to the user instructions provided by with ZometaÂ® (Novartis), the maximum concentration of ZA in serum in an adult human body within 15 minutes of administration (4 mg) is estimated to be 1.47 ÂµM. The concentration is considered to be higher by the rate of uptake of drug by bone. 16 ZA concentrations exceeding 10 ÂµM significantly inhibit proliferation of HGFs. 17 Li et al reported that compressive force exerted on osteocytes enhanced RANKL mRNA and protein expression and thus promoted osteoclast differentiation. 18 In addition, Ichimiya et al revealed that compressive force may be an aggravating factor for temporomandibular joint osteoarthritis, since mRNA and protein expression of RANKL were enhanced when a compressive force of 2.0 g/cm 2 was applied to synovial cells in the same way as was used in the present study. 12 Based on the results of these previous studies, the ZA concentrations were set to 0 (control), 10, and 100 ÂµM, and a compressive force of 2.0 g/cm 2 was applied.

The results of this study confirm that high concentrations (100 ÂµM) of ZA significantly inhibit the proliferation of HGFs, which is in accordance with previous reports. 1920 As cell proliferation of HGFs is regulated through the SMAD-mediated TGF-Î² signalling pathway, 17 the inhibition of HGF proliferation by BPs may also be caused by the inhibition of SMAD-mediated signalling: phosphorylation of Smad2/3. 1721

FGF2 is a major differentiation marker of fibroblasts and is involved in the formation of benign granulation tissue, which is indispensable in wound healing. 22 The results of this study confirm that gene expression of FGF2 is attenuated by the addition of ZA and compressive stress to HGFs. Imada et al reported that local use of FGF2 in vivo can prevent the development of MRONJ after tooth extraction. 23 Together with the results of this study, it is suggested that reduced expression of FGF2 in HGFs may be involved in the development of MRONJ.

CTGF is a growth-promoting factor for connective tissue that affects bone remodelling by promoting the differentiation and proliferation of osteoblasts and epithelial cells. 24 CTGF also functions in a complementary manner to FGF2 and consequently regulates the homeostasis of soft and hard tissues. 1424 Manzano-Moreno et al examined the effects of several BPs, including ZA, on the function of HGFs, and reported that the expression of FGF2 and CTGF was decreased, as was also seen in the present study. 14 The results of the present study demonstrated that expression of FGF2 and CTGF in HGFs was markedly reduced by the additive effects of compressive force and ZA, suggesting that the paracrine-mediated and autocrine-mediated collagen production of HGFs could have been influenced by these stimuli.

COL1 gene expression and protein production by HGFs are suppressed by BPs. 17 Komatsu et al reported that this is regulated by TGF-Î² signalling, as is cell proliferation. 17 Mechanical stress also affects the function of fibroblasts through TGF-Î² signalling, 25 mediated by focal adhesion kinase (FAK), a mechanosensor of these cells. 2627 Nan et al reported that COL1 gene expression and protein production of HGFs under compression are mediated by this pathway. 6 The results of the present study indicate that COL1 expression was significantly suppressed by the addition of 10 Î¼M ZA, a concentration that does not affect HGF proliferation. The same tendency was found with Sirius red staining experiments. Furthermore, the combined action of compressive force and addition of ZA tended to attenuate COL1 expression and significantly decrease collagen production. These findings imply that mechanical stress, which normally enhances collagen production by HGFs, may act in a suppressive manner when combined with BPs.

The results of this study indicate that the combined effects of compressive force and ZA may significantly impair the function of HGFs, including their collagen production, but not their proliferation or morphology. Although it is speculated that ZA and compressive force affect the signalling of different pathways, 17212627 it remains to be elucidated why the combined effects, compared with compressive force alone, impaired the gene expression and collagen production of HGFs. More detailed experiments to explain the precise mechanism will be needed. To the best of our knowledge, no previous study has evaluated the effects of BP combined with mechanical stress on the proliferation and differentiation of HGFs, the present study therefore is novel in this respect. Our results indicate that their combined effect can have a negative impact on the oral mucosal barrier. Our results support the hypothesis that mechanical stress in the oral cavity is a possible cause for the organ-specific occurrence of MRONJ.

The limitations of this study include a lack of temporal measurement of gene expression by HGFs after the loading of compressive force, and the absence of confirmation of the effects on protein expression of COL1 , FGF2 , and CTGF . In reports of the loading of mechanical stress on oral soft tissues and jaw bones in vivo, methods that have used dentures and metal frameworks in rats 28 and the application of traction by wires have been described. 29 However, it is not clear whether these methods reflect the mechanical stresses due to occlusion and denture bases in humans. Future studies therefore should construct an in vivo research model to address this question.

Conclusions
Based on our results and the clinical findings that MRONJ is more common in cases of excessive mechanical stress on the oral mucosa, we speculate that the combined effects of BPs and mechanical stress may contribute to the development of MRONJ by affecting homeostasis of the oral mucosal tissues, including HGFs.

Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Statement of clinical relevance
Our research provides clinical insights that eliminating excessive mechanical stress may contribute to the prevention of MRONJ.

Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Not applicable.

Title: Systematic review of patients’ experience with temporomandibular disorders
Author: Crummey, Sarah; Rae, Alexander; Jacob, Oliver; Rogers, Simon N; Fan, Kathleen
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Temporomandibular disorders (TMD) are a group of common conditions that can have significant detrimental impact on patients functional, emotional and social wellbeing. The aim of this systematic review is to collate and summarise the literature reporting patients? experience of TMD. This helps put the condition into the context of the patient themselves and their interaction with healthcare professionals. The study was completed according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA) guidelines. A systematic literature search was performed on 1 December 2023 using following databases: MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, PsychInfo (American Psychological Associated) and the Cochrane Library. Of these 439 articles, 13 met the inclusion criteria for the review. It was a heterogenous sample with relatively poor methodological quality. The cohorts ranged from nine to 44; totalling 280 participants. Two key themes and six subthemes illustrate the experience of patients with TMD: Impact (Physical, Psychological) and Coping (Understanding the disease, Experience of healthcare professionals, Seeking treatment, Adapting behaviours). Clinical care needs to reflect the experience of patients with better explanation of the condition, access to services and support. Further research should explore how to address patients? concerns more effectively. One method might be through the development of a PCI-TMD.
Body:
Introduction
Temporomandibular disorders (TMD) encompass a spectrum of conditions affecting the joint, muscles of mastication and their associated structures. TMD is multifactorial and can significantly affect patientsâ€™ activities of daily living and quality of life. 1

The highest prevalence of TMD is found in women aged 20 to 40 years. 2 Additional factors such as stress, trauma and anatomical variations may contribute to onset and severity. 3 Diagnosis and management of TMD poses significant challenges to healthcare professionals due to the diverse nature of symptoms and conflicting treatment modalities. 4

Despite advancements in diagnostic techniques and treatment options, understanding the experience of patients suffering from TMD remains paramount. Qualitative research allows exploration of patientsâ€™ perspective by delving into their lived experience. This systematic review aims to synthesise the qualitative experiences of TMD patients using thematic synthesis, placing the condition into context with respect to its impact on patients and their interaction with healthcare professionals.

Material and methods
The systematic review was conducted according to the protocol registered in PROSPERO (ID: CRD42023473091). The study was completed according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA) guidelines. 5

Search strategy
A systematic literature search was performed on 1 December 2023 using the following databases: MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, PsychInfo (American Psychological Associated) and the Cochrane Library. Searches were conducted in English, and the general search strategy was adapted for each database ( Appendix A ). No restrictions on publication date were imposed; however, only articles available in the English language have been included. Reference lists of included studies have been iteratively searched to identify additional articles. Selection criteria is presented in Table 1 .

Table 1
Selection criteria.
Inclusion        Exclusion
â€“ Patients with temporomandibular joint dysfunction or myofascial pain (diagnosed using any diagnostic criteria).
â€“ Patients presenting with atypical facial pain, trigeminal neuralgia or other causes of facial pain
â€“ Patients pre- or post-surgical intervention, undergoing medical, psychological or physiotherapy.
â€“ Studies reporting only on quantitative or mixed outcomes
â€“ Studies using qualitative methods to explore and report on the patient experience
â€“ Studies reporting on the influence of specific interventions
â€“ Participants of any age
 View full size
Data collection and synthesis
Two reviewers (SC and OJ) independently screened titles and abstracts then analysed the remaining full articles according to the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. A third reviewer (AR) resolved discrepancies between reviewers. Case reports, in vitro studies, recruitment, full texts not available in English, review articles and systematic reviews were also excluded. Quantitative studies were not included as they do not provide the depth of experience afforded by interviews.

The articles were imported to NVivo software, and the data was synthesised. 6 Line-by-line coding of the identified full texts according to meaning and context was undertaken by SC. Subsequently authors (SC, OJ, AR, SR, KF) analysed the codes to generate higher-level themes. All authors agreed on the final over-arching themes through group discussion and reflection. This ensured triangulation of the data to avoid subjective interpretation of the findings.

Quality assessment
Two reviewers (SC and AR) independently undertook quality assessment. The Critical Appraisal Skills Programme checklist for qualitative studies 7 has been used to assess the quality of articles. This checklist comprises 10 questions to assess the three key sections (study validity, summary of results, and applicability). Studies were not excluded based on of quality, but rather acknowledged and discussed ( Appendix B ).

Results
Study selection
The literature search identified 424 records across the five databases excluding duplicates. Following screening of references a further 15 articles were identified. Of these 439 articles, 13 met the inclusion criteria for the review ( Figure 1 ).



 View full sizeOpen full size image
Figure 1
PRISMA flow diagram for study selection.
Study characteristics
Interviews were conducted in all studies, but sample population and analysis varied. Size of the sample ranged from 9 8 to 44 9 representing a total of 280 participants [ Table 2 ]. 891011121314151617181920 Diagnosis of TMD was made using RDC/TMD 21 or DC/TMD 22 however in four papers 8101112 clinical diagnosis was not made, and recruitment was by self-reported symptoms. Studies including patient-reported symptoms were included to enhance the depth of patient experience.

Table 2

Results of thematic synthesis
Two themes and six subthemes were identified from the 13 included studies ( Table 3 ). Two key themes emerged as the overarching lived experience from the studies: (1) Impact and (2) Coping. An array of subthemes relating to both themes were generated.

Table 3
Themes
Theme 1: Impact
1.1 Physical
1.2 Psychological
Theme 2: Coping
2.1 Understanding the disease
2.2 Experience of healthcare professionals
2.3 Seeking treatment
2.4 Adapting behaviours
 View full size
Theme 1: Impact
Due to the chronicity of the disorders and challenges it poses on daily activities the first theme presented is impact. Patientsâ€™ experience of TMD varies widely and so does its impact, illustrated by the following two subthemes.

Subtheme 1.1: Physical health
The severity of pain related to TMD varies; however, some patientsâ€™ pain is unrelenting, impacting their everyday functioning. â€œIt can get pretty bad. To the point where it interferes with my ability to think, if that makes sense. Itâ€™s just so painful that I . . . itâ€™s hard to think about things and I just want to kind of be left alone. â€ 9 Due to dysfunction of the jaw and restricted movement patients can find eating challenging. â€œI am avoiding certain things at times. Anything that takes a lot of chewing power, it almost frightens me to want to eat it, so Iâ€™ll go get something softer.â€ 13

TMD is commonly relapsing and remitting with individuals suffering from symptom â€˜flare-ups.â€™ This uncertainty leaves patients waiting for further flare-ups with a sense of dread. â€œ If there is a pattern I havenâ€™t been able to notice it. Foods that I eat comfortably one day, another day might cause my jaw to lock. So, no, I havenâ€™t been able to discern a pattern. â€ 9 Others have anxiety regarding their physical symptoms and catastrophise about a more serious pathology. â€œDeep down, I think, in the back of my mind I was thinking what is really going on, is it something more serious than I really thought. You know, because of it lasting for so long. â€ 14 Many worry that their symptoms will worsen with time and that the condition is progressive. â€œI mean, will it always be like this? Will it get worse and worse? â€ 8 The physical symptoms and behavioural changes can impact intimacy. â€œWe canâ€™t cuddle in a normal way, and if we want to fool around or hug each other, I canâ€™t because of the back of my neck. Kissing is impossible. I canâ€™t because of my jaw. So we just give each other small pecks. â€ 15

Subtheme 1.2: Psychological wellbeing
Low mood, irritability, and anxiety were frequent self-reported side effects of TMD: â€œI used to be a happier person. Now, Iâ€™m easily irritated. In the past, if something at school seemed a bit boring, I just stuck with it. I just donâ€™t have the energy now.â€ 15 The impact of symptoms often left patients feeling isolated, resulting in social anxiety for fear of pain or relapsing. â€œI think parents and parents-in-law were just fed-up of this woman that was always in pain. Always in the corner, you know, at a party taking painkillers and drinking water rather than having fun. â€ 16 Some participants understand the role of stress in the disorder and the perpetuating cycle that can occur. â€œ The more the more stressed I am, the more I grind, and the more TMJ pain I have. â€ 13

In addition to daily activities, sleep was also affected for several individuals. Instead of having challenges getting to sleep or disrupted sleep, patients described having â€œ vivid dreams â€ involving their jaw and teeth. 12 Others had their parafunctional habits punctuating their dreams. â€œI still have dreams where I might be grinding, and I kind of describe it like Iâ€™m dislocating my jaw in my dreams. â€ 13

A requirement for sick leave was commonly reported, impacting occupation, education, and finances. â€œA few months ago I was calling into work sick a lot â€¦ I feel stupid sometimes, feeling like I have to call in sick from jaw pain. Itâ€™s just one of those things I want to be able to try and push through.â€ 13 Others sought consultations and treatments, which had financial implications in the search for resolution. Some declared bankruptcy or sold their house to cover treatment costs. 11

Theme 2: Coping
Temporomandibular disorder can be a chronic condition that can affect patients for many years and significantly influence their everyday lives. Four subthemes present patientsâ€™ coping mechanisms.

Understanding the disease
Many patients encountered had a poor understanding of the aetiology of TMD and questioned possible triggers. One woman related her jaw problem to an ankle fracture, which changed her body posture. 17 Others questions the structural integrity of the joint suspecting an impossible sequence of events. â€œ For a time, it (the click) changed and it sounded really brittle, thatâ€™s when it scared me a bit. I was like, â€˜has the bone worn down to the point where itâ€™s really fragile and could break?â€™â€ 13

In contrast, others understood the chronic nature of TMD and felt at ease with the diagnosis. â€œMost people have a clicky knee or a clicky ankle, Iâ€™ve just got the clicky jaw.â€ 13 Patients often found relief in receiving a diagnosis after a lengthy search, and this itself acted as a coping mechanism. â€œ That did give me a lot more confidence because, one, he believes me; two, that I actually have a name to something. Because half the time when there's something that you think is wrong, and no one believes you, and then all of a sudden they say, â€˜yes, it's got a name.â€™ Well, you do feel better.â€ 18 Those with an understanding of TMD can often find acceptance and can move on with their life. â€œIn some way Iâ€™ve accepted that you arenâ€™t always at your best. You canâ€™t always feel so great. Itâ€™s just sometimes like this.â€ 17

Experience of healthcare professionals
TMD is a complex group of disorders with high levels of diagnostic uncertainty for health professionals. A lack of knowledge from some professionals often shapes a patientsâ€™ experience. â€œMy dentist knows that it hurts when I open my mouth, and that I cannot open my mouth widely. He never said anything about it. Probably, I also never discussed it explicitly with him. He never suggested any treatment.â€ 12 Others are unsure where to access care stating they have â€œ looked high and low. â€ 17 Patients are sent to different healthcare professionals, often feeling trapped without receiving adequate care. â€œAnd so I was in some intense pain . . . and it was so funny because as soon as I got to the doctors they tell me I should go to the dentist, and then as soon as I go to the dentist they tell me they canâ€™t do anything for me, I have to go back to the doctors.â€ During patientsâ€™ quest for care they could receive negative responses from healthcare professionals. â€œ Well, I felt terrible, especially when my GP [general medical practitioner] refused to refer me anywhere and told me I was a timewaster who was just imagining it. And, you know, not to bother him anymore.â€ 16

When patients successfully accessed care, there was a lack of continuity between health professionals, leading to further confusion. â€œI'd come in and I wouldn't be seeing my regular doctor, and I had to keep explaining myself, and on one occasion I was actually discharged from the hospital because the doctor that I normally see wasn't there.â€ 19 Patients received incorrect and unnecessary medical treatment from ill-informed professionals with no resolution for their TMD. â€œ They just kept looking at me teeth, they didnâ€™t say anything [about a diagnosis], just kept drilling into me [sic] teeth, injections and drilling me [sic] teeth all the time.â€ 14 The rationale behind some treatment was not fully explained to patients, preventing them from understanding its importance . â€œAnd then they tried to knock me out, put me under, and they tried to realign my jaw thinking it had been dislocated and it was the worst experience, I felt like my jaw was just going to snap because they were putting so much force.â€ 19

Seeking treatment
Many individuals seek treatment for TMD regardless of severity and struggle with self-management. â€œIf I have a physical complaint, most of the time I will go directly to the general practitioner. â€ 12 Even with a diagnosis, some patients question their symptoms and search for answers. â€œEven last night Iâ€™d be sitting there with the water and the painkillers. It hasnâ€™t gone awayâ€¦and I still think that maybeâ€¦because maybe I should have the teeth out. Maybe itâ€™s still a dental problem. So no I stillâ€¦I do, I do worry about it. And I worry about where itâ€™s going to go from here.â€ 14 Reassurance from fellow sufferers can provide relief from anxiety and make patients feel less alone in their symptoms. â€œI had such vague complaints; I did not have the idea that this could have to do with my jaws. But when I came into the waiting room, I saw another guy rubbing his temples. Then I thought: I am not the only one; Iâ€™m not some kind of nutcase. I am at the right place.â€ 12

Adapting behaviours
Patientsâ€™ report having to adapt their daily life to accommodate symptoms of TMD. â€œOn the days Iâ€™m in pain, I feel that I canâ€™t do certain things. I canâ€™t cope with being with my friends because I have a headache.â€ 15 Much of the management of TMD involves self-management techniques, and some patients feel unable to cope. Patients are aware that without self-management, their symptoms may not improve. â€œ Sometimes I give my jaw a massage and I do some exercises; I know that I can help myself.â€ 12 â€œ Iâ€™ve got to the point now where I think Iâ€™ve got to do it because I can only help myself now, itâ€™s not a case ofâ€¦I could come here for the next 12 months but unless I continue to help myself itâ€™s not going to get any better as well.â€ 14

Some individuals become accustomed to their symptoms and can continue with everyday activities. â€œAt first, I was concerned, but now I am just so used to the popping.â€ 8 Some described their jaw as â€œjust uncomfortableâ€ or â€œannoying â€, but â€œmanageable â€ with minimal impact on their daily life, 13 however, it is unclear if this correlates with severity of symptoms.

Discussion
The impact of TMD on patients has long been appreciated but this review amalgamated the literature using thematic synthesis to analyse the experience and unmet needs of TMD patients. The themes of impact and coping are vital to understand how to support patients optimally. There are positive experiences of findings relief in diagnosis and successful use of self-management techniques.

The coping mechanisms identified show how individuals are managing their symptoms. Some sufferers found relief in receiving a diagnosis and acceptance allowed them to move on with their lives. Acceptance of chronic conditions is known to improve symptoms and is a prerequisite for successful pain management. 23 Self-management techniques help to resolve symptoms; however, prompt interventions are required as these methods are most effective in early TMD. 24 There is poor adherence to home physiotherapy techniques, so continued encouragement is needed. 25 Another coping strategy was finding relief from fellow sufferers. This is common among chronic pain conditions, 26 and support groups should be considered as a treatment modality in TMD. This review identified that patients had varying abilities to adapt to their symptoms. However, coping ability was not assessed against the severity of symptoms or diagnosis within the TMD spectrum.

Healthcare professionals lack of TMD knowledge and diagnostic uncertainty lead to an array of unmet needs. When patient concerns are left unresolved, there is a search for answers, and healthcare-seeking behaviours are found. Research examining dentistsâ€™ experience in treating TMD indicates a prevailing sense of diagnostic uncertainty and a lack of awareness regarding effective interventions, 4 which parallels the experience reported by patients. Lack of knowledge can cause some to label these patients as timewasters, compounding existing adverse psychological health and reduced quality of life. 1 Temporomandibular disorder contributes to social anxiety and isolation stemming from ongoing symptoms, which are also observed in other chronic musculoskeletal conditions. 27 However, there is a contrasting patient group with TMD and other musculoskeletal disorders who actively face their symptoms and undertake daily activities despite them. 27

The impact of TMD on individuals is vast and covers physical and psychological aspects. Hopelessness, resignation, and social isolation can be found in these individuals and patients with chronic pain and non-specific orofacial pain suffered similar issues. 2829 Poor psychological wellbeing can worsen symptoms. 30 Evaluating psychological health should be a priority for diagnosis and targeted therapy considered as a first line treatment modality to improve quality of life. 31

Strengths and limitations
The studies included in this review varied significantly. Self-reported TMD was used in four studies 8101112 posing a risk of incorrect self-diagnosis, but the decision was to include these for depth of patient experience. Studies investigating orofacial pain were not included due to their broad scope; however, this has potentially excluded relevant findings related to TMD due to the frequent overlap of symptoms and management of TMD in facial pain clinics. Methods of data analysis varied between studies, and two articles did not detail their methodology. 911 Timespan of data was vast between 1994 11 to 2023 101920 however, patient experiences and challenges remained the same, indicating that care still needs to evolve to meet the unmet needs. The included studies contained varying discussion of role of bias with some avoiding interviewer/participant relationships and others having no mention of it. 89111213141516

Temporomandibular disorders encompass a broad spectrum of diagnoses, each with distinct characteristics. Patients are often viewed, and may perceive themselves, as a homogenous group. However, treating TMD as a single entity presents challenges, as individuals with different diagnoses have varying symptoms and concerns. In the reviewed articles, seven did not distinguish between diagnoses. 9101112 Two studies focused exclusively on patients with intra-articular pathology, 1318 while four specified participantsâ€™ diagnoses. 14161719 Among these, most patients exhibited both myalgia and joint pathology, yet none analysed their findings by diagnosis. Future research should address the unique experiences and concerns of each specific TMD diagnosis.

The strength of this review lies in the rigorous analysis. Themes and subthemes were derived through separate analyses, allowing for triangulation, and enhancing the credibility of the findings. This collaborative approach ensured a comprehensive and robust data exploration, improving reliability.

Direction of future research
Further research into patientsâ€™ TMD experiences and unmet needs is required. This review helps to identify issues that might populate a patient concerns inventory for TMD. Aspects relating to diet, social activities, sleep, psychological wellbeing, and intimacy should be included in a TMD PCI. A prompt list would help identify impact and specific coping mechanisms, assessing positive and negative behaviours that contribute to the disorders.

Conclusion
This systematic review provides an insight into the experience of individuals suffering from TMD. Despite the prevalence of TMD, relatively few qualitative studies were reported. The themes identified in this review of impact and coping underscore the importance of tailored support strategies for TMD patients. Further research is needed to deepen the understanding of patientsâ€™ experiences and address their needs effectively. The evidence shows the pressing need for improved diagnostic pathways and patient-centred care when managing TMD.

Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.

Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Ethical approval and patient permission not required as this is a systematic review.

Funding
None.

This systematic review synthesizes qualitative research on temporomandibular disorders (TMD) to illuminate patientsâ€™ lived experiences, challenges, and coping strategies. TMD, a multifactorial condition affecting the temporomandibular joint and associated structures, predominantly impacts women aged 20 to 40 years and is exacerbated by factors such as stress, trauma, and anatomical variations. Despite diagnostic and treatment advances, managing TMD remains challenging due to its diverse symptom presentation and conflicting interventions.

The review followed a protocol registered with PROSPERO (ID: CRD42023473091) and adhered to PRISMA guidelines. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and the Cochrane Library, with 13 studies meeting the inclusion criteria. These studies, incorporating a total of 280 participants, used interviews and qualitative methods to capture the depth of patient experiences.

The Impact theme encompasses physical aspectsâ€”such as chronic pain, impaired jaw function affecting eating and intimacy, and physical limitationsâ€”as well as psychological issues, including anxiety, low mood, social isolation, and financial strain due to treatment costs and sick leave. The Coping theme outlines patientsâ€™ efforts to understand their condition, navigate complex healthcare systems often characterized by diagnostic uncertainty, actively seek treatment, and adopt self-management strategies.

The review highlights significant unmet needs, emphasizing the necessity for improved diagnostic pathways, enhanced patient-centered care, and support strategies including early intervention and peer support. This systematic review synthesizes qualitative studies to explore the lived experiences of patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD), focusing on the condition's impact and coping mechanisms. TMD, a multifactorial condition affecting the jaw joint and muscles, significantly impacts patients' quality of life, particularly women aged 20-40. The review analyzed 13 studies involving 280 participants, identifying two overarching themes: "Impact" and "Coping."

The "Impact" theme highlighted the physical and psychological toll of TMD. Patients reported chronic pain, difficulty eating, and anxiety about symptom progression, leading to social isolation, sleep disturbances, and financial strain due to lost work and treatment costs. The "Coping" theme revealed strategies such as seeking diagnoses, adapting behaviors, and relying on self-management techniques. The review underscores the need for improved diagnostic pathways, patient-centered care, and psychological support for TMD patients.
