Quality assessment of included study in terms of risk of bias.
Open table in a new tab
Results
A literature search on PubMed, Google Scholar, and Scopus yielded 121 results while additional studies were also included from the reference list of an accepted systematic review. From a total of 118 research articles, 34 were included after screening and exclusion. The selection process was based on PRISMA guidelines7 as elaborated in Figure 1. As shown in Table 1, all the selected papers were not randomised and had a high risk of bias. The detailed characteristics of the 34 studies are given in Supplemental Table 2 (online only) (1 systematic review, 9 prospective studies, 1 pilot study, 3 clinical studies, 1 cross-sectional study, 4 case series, and 15 case reports). The follow-up periods varied from 1 month to 12 years. The total sample size of all the studies was 360. Thirteen studies included children only, five included adults only, while the remaining 16 included both.1â€“6,9â€“36

Figure viewer
Fig. 1 Selection process of studies based on PRISMA guidelines.
Surgical intervention involving mandibular advancement alone was reported in one case report, two case series, one cross-sectional study, and one prospective study, whereas intervention involving release of TMJ ankylosis alone was reported in only one case report. Interventions involving both mandibular advancement and release of TMJ ankylosis were reported in the remaining 28 studies, in which mandibular advancement was done via distraction osteogenesis (DO) in 25. In studies that did not use DO, mandibular advancement was achieved via bilateral inverse L osteotomy of ramus and iliac bone grafting (n = 1), and a combination of bilateral Epker osteotomy and bilateral vertical osteotomy at the symphyseal region anterior to the mental foramen (n = 1). Among the studies that reported different protocols for surgical intervention involving both the release of TMJ ankylosis and mandibular advancement via DO, six reported simultaneous arthroplasty and DO (SAD), 12 reported pre-athroplasty DO (PrAD), and three post-athroplasty DO (PAD). One clinical study discussed the use of PrAD and PAD, while one systematic review compared outcomes between surgical protocols involving SAD, PrAD, and PAD. Other additional procedures for mandibular advancement such as genioplasty were also reported. The variation in the sequence and combination of arthroplasty and DO is illustrated in Figure 2.

Figure viewer
Fig. 2 Variation of sequence and combination of arthroplasty and distraction osteogenesis in TMJ ankylosis with micrognathia and OSA. PrAD: Pre-arthroplastic DO; PAD: Post-arthroplastic DO; SAD: Simultaneous arthroplasty DO.
In terms of TMJ ankylosis, the most common surgical intervention was interpositional gap arthroplasty (11 studies), other surgical options being gap arthroplasty (4 studies), costochondral grafts (CCG) (1 study), transport DO (1 study), removal of fibrous adhesion (1 study), and arthroplasty with disc repositioning (1 study). Seven studies reported more than one approach, while three did not mention the exact type of procedure for the release of ankylosis. Many authors also performed coronoidectomy in addition to release of ankylosis to optimise mouth opening.
One case report described a case with follow up from 2 - 19 years of age in which DO and bilateral sagittal split osteotomy (BSSO) were used for mandibular advancement, and a combination of gap arthroplasty (GA), interpositional gap arthroplasty (IGA), coronoidectomy and, eventually, total joint prosthesis, were used for the management of TMJ ankylosis.
Mouth opening
The primary outcome for the treatment of TMJ ankylosis was the change in mouth opening, which was objectively measured in 24 of 29 articles that reported release of ankylosis. Most surgical management achieved a significant gain in mouth opening, with most of the patients achieving functional mouth opening of more than 25 mm after treatment.
Reankylosis
The incidence of reankylosis was evaluated in 16 of 29 studies that reported release of TMJ ankylosis. Reankylosis was reported in 12 subjects in two case reports, one prospective study, and one clinical study. Four subjects were treated with SAD using either GA (n = 3) or IGA (n = 1), while the remaining eight underwent PAD, treated either with GA (n = 1) or IGA (n = 7). The reason for reankylosis was reported to be poor compliance with, or intolerance of, mouth opening exercises after surgery. Similarly, the systematic review by Albert and Muthusekhar concluded that reankylosis was reported more in PAD followed by SAD, with none in PrAD. HYPERLINK "SPS:refid::bib1" 1
Mandibular advancement
In terms of the treatment for micrognathia or retrognathia, the distance of mandibular advancement was measured as an outcome for the different surgical strategies used. The amount of advancement achieved by authors using DO (6â€“34 mm) was more than that in studies that reported mandibular advancement without DO (10â€“15 mm). Meanwhile, in their systematic review, Albert and Muthusekhar reported that change in mandibular length occurred sooner in patients treated with PrAD and SAD than in those in whom PAD was indicated due to a delay in DO after arthroplasty. HYPERLINK "SPS:refid::bib1" 1
Apnoea-hypopnoea index (AHI)
Fifteen studies reported the AHI as the treatment outcome. For studies that described the release of TMJ ankylosis and DO as the treatment protocol, a post-intervention outcome of no OSA (AHI < 5) to mild OSA (AHI between 5 and 15) was reported in almost all cases treated by PrAD, whereas in cases treated by SAD and PAD a post-intervention AHI in the mild OSA category (AHI between 5 and 15) was reported. In one study that treated triad patients with a preoperative AHI as high as 163, the PrAD approach managed to reduce it to between 0 and 18.1. Studies using DO alone for the treatment of triad patients reported slightly less optimum outcomes in terms of AHI, with post-intervention readings between 0.5 and 28.6. Treatment with a combination of IGA and Epker osteotomy also reported a post-surgical AHI reduction from 38 to 0.
Oxygen saturation
Of the five studies reporting lowest arterial oxygen saturation, SAD provided the most optimum reading (98.2%) followed by PrAD (2 studies reporting lowest oxygen saturation of 93% and between 68% and 94.6%) and PAD (2 studies with lowest oxygen saturation of 81% and 92.9%). Six studies that evaluated OSA in terms of mean oxygen saturation used PrAD as their surgical strategy of choice (a range of post-intervention readings between 80% and 98.4% was achieved), while the other study reported post-intervention readings of 94% to 96% after surgical intervention involving DO only. The author who reported the lowest post-intervention mean oxygen saturation of 80% also treated the subject with the lowest pre-intervention reading of 55%.
Posterior airway space (PAS)
Studies with measurements of PAS involved the use of PrAD (5 studies), DO only (1 study), ankylosis release and genioplasty (1 study), SAD (1 study), and bilateral inverse L osteotomy of ramus and iliac bone grafting (1 study), all of which were able to achieve PAS of between 7 mm and 15 mm. Similar improvements in OSA symptoms for subjects in the PrAD and SAD groups were noted by Albert and Muthusekhar in their systematic review.1 However, in contrast to the findings of the present review, the same systematic review reported worsening polysomnographic data among subjects in the PAD group.
Discussion
Based on current literature, there is a well-established link between OSA and mandibular deformity secondary to TMJ ankylosis.1â€“5 Polysomnography and CT scans therefore need to be performed in patients with TMJ ankylosis to assess the airway and to plan treatment. The AHI is used to grade the severity of OSA where, in the paediatric population 1â€“4.9 events/hour is mild, 5â€“9.9 events/hour is moderate, and more than 10 events/hour severe. Most clinical presentations can be observed by parents during sleep. They include snoring, paradoxical breathing, gasping, restless sleep, frequent awakening, respiratory pauses, diaphoresis, and enuresis. Daytime presentation of OSA in children differs from that in adults in whom neurobehavioural sequelae (rather than daytime somnolence) are more often present. These clinical features are thought to be the result of chronic exposure to intermittent hypoxemia and sleep deprivation, and can fall into two main categories: behavioural (aggression, impulsivity, and hyperactivity) and neurocognitive (deficits in attention, executive function, and language).37 Cardiac workup is necessary prior to surgical management especially in patients with long-standing, severe OSA to rule out problems such as pulmonary and systemic hypertension as well as right ventricular hypertrophy.37,38 Poor growth and failure to thrive due to increased baseline calorific expenditure for breathing effort and reduced growth hormone secretion due to fragmented sleep can also be seen in this group of patients.38
A recent systematic review by Albert and Muthusekhar in 2021 provided a comprehensive overview of the surgical outcome of different treatment sequences involving DO for the management of patients with TMJ ankylosis and micrognathia.1 Of the 10 studies included, only six reported parameters for the assessment of OSA. The scope of the review also did not include mandibular advancement using methods other than DO or triad patients who were treated only with DO without release of TMJ ankylosis. The present review has aimed to add to previous systematic reviews in terms of functional outcomes with more emphasis on changes in OSA parameters, as well as the inclusion of methods other than TMJ ankylosis and DO for the comparison of treatment outcomes.
In the management of the triad of TMJ ankylosis, micrognathia, and OSA in growing patients, the ultimate goal of surgical treatment is to allow advancement of the hypoplastic mandible and widening of the obstructed oropharyngeal airway, and to ensure mobility of the condyle. Andrade et al discussed five surgical options for the treatment of TMJ ankylosis and micrognathia: release of TMJ ankylosis alone, release of TMJ ankylosis with reconstruction using a CCG, simultaneous release of TMJ ankylosis and mandibular distraction, two-stage surgery involving release of TMJ ankylosis followed by mandibular distraction, and two-stage surgery involving mandibular distraction followed by release of TMJ ankylosis.2
Option one involves release of TMJ ankylosis only. Based on the present narrative review, most surgical procedures reported in the literature, including interpositional gap arthroplasty, gap arthroplasty, CCG, transport DO, removal of fibrous adhesion, and arthroplasty with disc repositioning, result in adequate mouth opening of at least 25 mm.1â€“4,6,16,18,21,22,24,26,27,30,32,35,36 Nevertheless, this option is more suitable for patients with isolated TMJ ankylosis without micrognathia or OSA. When treatment for micrognathia is required, options two to five are more appropriate, as they allow lengthening of the mandible with growth. The choice of the most suitable approach will depend on the OSA status of the patient.
Option two comprises release of TMJ ankylosis followed by correction of micrognathia using a CCG, which is believed to possess growth potential. Alternatives to CCG include autogenous bone grafts from the coronoid process, tibial or clavicular bone, sternoclavicular joint, iliac crest, metatarsal bone, or metatarsophalangeal articulation.39,40 However, this approach does not provide an immediate solution to the respiratory issues caused by OSA and thus is not the preferred surgical treatment for triad patients.2 Furthermore, the surgical outcome of CCG has been reported to be unpredictable, with problems such as overgrowth, absent or suboptimal growth, ankylosis of the TMJ following reconstruction, and graft resorption or necrosis.41â€“43
Surgical treatments that combine release of TMJ ankylosis with mandibular advancement via DO (options 3, 4, and 5) have shown advantages over the use of CCG, including shortened surgery time and length of stay, lower risk of relapse, concurrent lengthening of both hard and soft tissues,40,43 and lack of donor-site morbidity.40,43,44 Disadvantages of DO are related to the cost of distraction devices, as well as the need for the device to remain in place throughout the distraction and consolidation period.40 Nevertheless, the controlled direction and amount of bony lengthening offered by DO 40,43 makes it a more ideal option for the treatment of patients with respiratory issues secondary to OSA.
To solve both the issues of TMJ ankylosis and micrognathia in a single operation, option 3 is a tempting approach for the oral and maxillofacial surgeon. Indeed, many case series and case reports have shown successful outcomes using this option for the management of TMJ ankylosis and hypoplastic mandible.18,21,22,35,36 Despite successful outcomes, however, several concerns may still arise when using this approach to treat triad patients with bilateral TMJ ankylosis. Firstly, the need for aggressive mouth opening exercises after the release of TMJ ankylosis may result in constant movement and stretching of the distraction site, causing fibrous union or pseudoarthrosis. Secondly, the difficulty in predicting the mandibular position after condylectomy or release of TMJ ankylosis, and the need for continuous active physical therapy, contribute to the challenge of establishing occlusal stability after simultaneous bilateral release of TMJ ankylosis and mandibular DO. For these reasons, many authors propose the use of a two-stage surgery (options 4 and 5) if the patient requires it.2,45
Proponents of the release of TMJ ankylosis followed by mandibular DO (option 4) believe that it is better to stabilise the mandible after the release of ankylosis before deciding on the position and vector of the mandibular distraction devices. Kwon et al reported success in the management of patients with this approach.45 Andrade et al reported a series of 15 cases managed with two-stage surgery, with their initial protocol being the release of ankylosis followed by mandibular DO.2 The study found that in patients with severe OSA, forced mouth opening tended to trigger choking episodes, bradycardia, and desaturation, which the authors attributed to obstruction of the posterior airway space and trigeminocardiac reflex. These symptoms often lead to non-compliance with jaw physiotherapy and reankylosis. Staged surgery involving mandibular DO followed by release of ankylosis is therefore suggested for patients with severe OSA.2 A summary of the treatment strategy from this systematic review is further illustrated in Figure 3, which shows a proposed decision flow chart for the appropriate surgical management of patients with TMJ ankylosis. Nevertheless, this review must be interpreted with some caution, as it is unfortunately impossible to draw a reliable conclusion due to the low level of literature evidence, high risk of bias, and limited sample size.

Figure viewer
Fig. 3 Proposed decision flow chart for choosing the appropriate surgical strategy for patients with TMJ ankylosis.
This study acknowledges that TMJ ankylosis is a complex disease with many possible sequelae and associated presentations, including micrognathia and OSA, which potentially require multiple staged operations to be planned over extended periods. This systematic review has a limitation as it was not able to comprehensively determine the degree of TMJ ankylosis. The diversity and nature of tissue ankylosis would ideally require a case-based approach. Further research initiatives in this field are recommended to identify the optimum intervention that can be tailored to each specific condition. In addition, other surgical interventions such as fat tissue grafts, and a combination of orthognathic surgery and TMJ prostheses, must not be excluded.
Perioperative assessment and management of systemic disorders related to OSA, including airway management, are important aspects that are best approached via a multi-disciplinary approach. This systematic review shows that the diversity and nature of TMJ ankylosis would ideally require a case-based surgical strategy. Even though PrAD, which is a favoured option due to the ability to lengthen the mandible, helps alleviate respiratory issues caused by OSA, simultaneous release of TMJ ankylosis and mandibular DO show promising outcomes, but may pose challenges such as maintaining occlusal stability and managing postoperative complications. For severe OSA cases, staged surgery may be necessary to optimise outcomes. In conclusion, effective case-specific management of TMJ ankylosis, micrognathia, and OSA in growing patients requires careful consideration of the surgical options that promote mandibular advancement and airway improvement. A multidisciplinary approach is crucial for managing these complex cases effectively, and further research is needed to refine the surgical techniques and improve outcomes.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Funding
No funding was received for this study.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patientsâ€™ permission
Ethics approval and patient consent not required.

Title: UK OMFS consultants and trainees strongly support the recommendations of the 2008 Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB) Review of Training in OMFS. The time for delivering them is now
Author: Sharma, Divya; Douglas, James; Begley, Anne; Magennis, Patrick; Koppel, David
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: When the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board?s (PMETB) Review of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) Training was published in 2008 it contained five recommendations about OMFS training. As yet, none of these recommendations has been delivered. An online survey was designed to assess awareness of the PMETB review and the current views of OMFS trainees and consultants about its recommendations. Replies were invited using email and social media (WhatsApp, Twitter, and Facebook). As a result of using social media no denominator for the response rate was possible. A total of 304 responses were received, eight of which were anonymous. There was strong support for all the OMFS-specific recommendations: 1: the OMFS specialty should remain a dual medical and dental degree specialty (255, 84%); 2: OMFS training should be shortened (283, 93%); 3: OMFS training should start at the beginning of the second degree (203, 67%); 4: there should be a single medical regulator (General Medical Council) for OMFS (258, 85%); and 6: the need for a second Foundation Year should be removed (260, 86%). Other suggestions about improving OMFS training were also made by participants in the survey. There remains strong support within the specialty for the recommendations of the review. This support is present across consultants, specialty trainees, and those aiming for OMFS specialty training. Some of the original legislative obstructions to delivery of the recommendations have been removed by Brexit creating a unique opportunity for them to be delivered.
Body:
Introduction
The 2008 Review of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) Training1 was, and is, the most extensive and expensive review of OMFS training in the world. It was jointly chaired by Peter Rubin, chair of the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Body (PMETB) and Barry Cockcroft, Chief Dental Officer of England. The politics around the review have been discussed.2â€“4 This paper will look at the specialtyâ€™s current views on its five OMFS-specific recommendations.
Method
An online survey was created to assess awareness of the PMETB review and the current views of OMFS trainees and consultants in the context of its recommendations. Trainees at all levels and consultants/specialists were contacted using email and social media (WhatsApp, Twitter, and Facebook). Use of social media made a denominator impossible to calculate. To encourage participation a prize draw was offered. Analysis was undertaken on WinstatÂ®.
Results
Response rate
A total of 304 responses were received, eight of which were anonymous. Of those responding, 124 (41%) were consultants, 66 (22%) specialty trainees (STs), and 114 pre-specialty trainees (made up of 27 (9%) pre-second-degree studies, 61 (20%) second-degree students, and 26 (9%) post-second degree).
Defining the response rate is not possible because distribution included social media. For consultants the General Medical Councilâ€™s OMFS specialist list in January 2023 was used as the denominator. With 503 active OMFS specialists on the list, 124 consultants are 25%. For STs, of whom there are approximately 150, the response rate was 44%. Calculating a response rate for other groups was not possible.
Reviewing the first degree of those responding, 248 were â€˜dentistry firstâ€™ (82%) and 48 â€˜medicine firstâ€™ (16%). A total of 111 (90%) consultants were â€˜dentistry-firstâ€™ and 12 (10%) â€˜medicine-firstâ€™, similar proportions to the first degrees across the consultant body.5 For STs, 50 (76%) were â€˜dentistry-firstâ€™ and 16 (24%) â€˜medicine-firstâ€™, similar proportions to all UK STs (Table 1).2
Which recommendation(s) do you support?        No. (%)
Recommendation 1: There should be no change to the current statutory requirement for those training in OMFS to obtain primary qualifications in both medicine and dentistry        255 (84)
Recommendation 2: Discussions should take place with medical and dental schools and the regulators to explore ways of streamlining OMFS training        283 (93)
Recommendation 3: Specialist OMFS training should begin at the start of the second degree course        203 (67)
Recommendation 4: Those on the specialist register in OMFS need be registered only with the GMC        258 (85)
Recommendation 5: OMFS who can show F2 competencies should be able to skip F2. This does not alter the requirement to complete F1, which remains compulsory        258 (86)
Table 1
Response to the question: Which PMETB recommendations do you support?
Open table in a new tab
Gender
Of those responding, 229 (75%) were male and 67 female (22%). Within the groups, 113 (91%) consultants were male, 10 (8%) female, and 1 (1%) unknown. For STs, 51 (77%) were male and 15 (23%) female. Seventeen (65%) post-second-degree trainees were male, 7 (27%) female, and 2 (8%) unknown, whilst 35 (57%) second-degree students were male, 25 (41%) female, and one (2%) unknown. Finally, 13 (48%) pre-second-degree trainees were male, 10 (37%) female, and 4 (15%) unknown. Gender distribution was similar to that across these groups as a whole.2
Support for PMETB recommendations by those responding (Table 1)
â€œRecommendation 1: The need for dual qualification - There should be no change to the current statutory requirement for those training in OMFS to obtain primary qualifications in both medicine and dentistry.â€
This was supported by 255 (84%). Within trainee subgroups, 53 (80%) STs, 23 (88%) post-second-degree, 52 (85%) second-degree, and 21 (78%) pre-second-degree trainees supported this recommendation.
Considering the first degrees of those replying, 213 (86%) of those studying dentistry first supported this recommendation compared with 34 (71%) of those who were medicine-first, a difference that was statistically significant using a chi-squared test (0.01). There was no gender difference in the support for dual-degree OMFS.
â€œRecommendation 2: The duration of training - Discussions should take place with medical and dental schools and the regulators to explore ways of streamlining the education and training of those dentists or doctors who wish to pursue a career in OMFS. Any reduction in the length of training leading to a primary qualification must be compatible with the European Professional Qualifications Directive 2005/36â€.
This was supported by 283 (93%). The support did not vary significantly with first degree, gender, or stage of OMFS training.
â€œRecommendation 3: The training pathway: when should training begin? - Since OMFS is unique in requiring two primary qualifications, we recommend that all those responsible for training in the specialty explore the feasibility of beginning specialist OMFS training at the start of the second-degree course.â€
This was supported by 203 (67%). Consultants were most in favour (n = 93, 75%) and pre-second-degree trainees least in favour (n = 8, 30%). There was a statistically significant difference (p = 0.03) between first degrees, with dentistry-first supporting strongly (70% n = 173) compared with medicine-first respondents (54% n = 26). There was no gender difference for this recommendation.
â€œRecommendation 4: Registration - Those on the specialist register in OMFS need be registered only with the GMC.â€
This was strongly supported with 258 (85%) in favour. There were small variations within trainee subgroups and genders but these were not statistically significant.
â€œRecommendation 5: The relationship between Oral and Maxillofacial and Oral Surgery: there should be a separate review of the specialty of Oral Surgery.â€
The Oral Surgery Review was published in 20126 making this the one recommendation of the review that has been delivered.
â€œRecommendation 6: Foundation programme â€“ Dually qualified individuals who can demonstrate to the PMETB that they meet foundation year 2 (F2) competencies have the option to move directly into competition for specialty training programmes without completing F2. This does not alter the requirement to complete F1, which remains compulsory. The PMETB notes that the Department of Health for England intend to publish a review of the foundation programme later this year, and this may be subject to some change.â€
This had the support of 260 (86%). The Review of Foundation Training was published in 2010 and did not recommend any changes in foundation training for OMFS trainees.7
Awareness of the PMETB review
The review was published in 2008 and included visits to OMFS units, evidence collection from a wide range of stakeholders, and the associated political lobbying which took place during the preceding two years. Overall, 136 (45%) of those responding said they were aware of the PMETB review prior to receiving the survey, 138 (45%) said they were unaware and, 28 (9%) were not sure.
Of 124 consultants responding to this question, 89 (71%) were aware of the report, 22 (18%) were not aware, and 13 (10%) ticked â€˜not sureâ€™. Of the 178 trainees responding, 47 (26%) were aware of the review, 116 (65%) were not aware, and 15 (8%) unsure. There were small differences between each trainee subgroup, but these were not statistically significant. There was no difference between male and females responding.
All those trainees who registered their interest in OMFS with BAOMS between 2010 and 2020 were sent the PMETB report.8 Some of the differences in knowledge of it may be explained by this.
Select the most important PMETB recommendation
Responses to this question are summarised in Table 2.
Which recommendation is the most important?        No. (%)
Recommendation 1: There should be no change to the current statutory requirement for those training in OMFS to obtain primary qualifications in both medicine and dentistry        29 (10)
Recommendation 2: Discussions should take place with medical and dental schools and the regulators to explore ways of streamlining OMFS training        73 (24)
Recommendation 3: Specialist OMFS training should begin at the start of the second degree course        91 (30)
Recommendation 4: Those on the specialist register in OMFS need be registered only with the GMC        33 (11)
Recommendation 5: The relationship between Oral and Maxillofacial and Oral Surgery: There should be a separate review of the specialty of Oral Surgery        11 (4)
Recommendation 6: OMFS who can show F2 competencies should be able to skip F2. This does not alter the requirement to complete F1, which remains compulsory        44 (14)
I don't know which is the most important recommendation - I should read more about the report        16 (5)
Blank        7 (2)
Table 2
Response to: Please choose which recommendation you feel is the most important.
Open table in a new tab
Of those who replied to this question, 91 (30%) chose Recommendation 3: Specialist OMFS training should begin at the start of the second degree course, and 73 (24%) chose Recommendation 2: Discussions should take place with medical and dental schools and the regulators to explore ways of streamlining OMFS training. The other priorities are listed in Table 2.
Options to change OMFS training that could be within the control of the specialty
In the context of the failure of all stakeholders to deliver on any of the PMETB recommendations specific to OMFS, options were given that could be within the remit of the specialty to address. Free text was also offered. Of those replying, 102 (34%) chose the option to Formalise existing â€˜shadowâ€™ programmes (like the BAOMS Mentoring and Support Programme8) to demonstrate that â€˜Run-Though-Maxâ€™ is possible, including national annual reviews of competency (ARCPs) for this group. The next largest group (n = 79, 26%) chose The creation of regional OMFS clinical fellows (with local appointment and national benchmarking akin to National Institute for Health and Care Research Academic Clinical Fellow and Academic Clinical Fellow posts - NIHR ACF/ACLs also known as Walport posts). Of those replying, 55 (18%) chose nothing to be done, not sure, or left the answer blank.
Next step for specialty / BAOMS
When those responding were asked to choose what should be the next step for the specialty, 83 (41%) chose â€˜Lobby for when UK law is changed to remove references to EU directives to enable integration of the second degree into OMFS trainingâ€™. The next two options with similar numbers were to â€˜Focus on the most important recommendation and set a target for its deliveryâ€™ chosen by 55 (27%), and â€˜Design and deliver a strategy to deliver on all recommendations with a specific targetâ€™ chosen by 49 (24%). â€˜Nothing â€“ recommendations are no longer relevantâ€™ was chosen by 16 (8%).
Of those not expressing an opinion, 83 said they did not know and would need to read the report before deciding, and 18 left the answer blank.
Discussion
The PMETB review represented significant and detailed external scrutiny of OMFS training in the United Kingdom. As a dual-degree medical specialty, OMFS was seen as an â€˜outlierâ€™. The focus of the reviewâ€™s co-chair, the Chief Dental Officer England, was the nature of the hospital dental specialty of Oral Surgery. The first two hospitals that the reviewers planned to visit as part of a review of OMFS training (Swindon and Lancaster) did not have any OMFS trainees. When the review team visited OMFS units and met patients in Glasgow, London, Sunderland, Brighton, and Salisbury, as well as Swindon and Lancaster, they understood why OMFS was a dual-degree specialty.
Recommendation 1: OMFS is a dual-degree specialty.
This was strongly supported at the time by the specialty and its patients. Vocal subgroups inside and outside the specialty question this â€˜unique selling pointâ€™.3,9â€“11 Each time the question is asked the specialty as a whole responds to support OMFS as a dual-degree specialty.10 Across Europe, the majority of nations (n = 21) have dual-degree OMFS, including eight nations which have changed or are changing their specialty toward dual-degree OMFS and away from single-medical-degree OMFS with dental training but no dental degree.12,13 Even in the eight nations that do not require a dental degree, many OMFS surgeons are dually qualified because of the advantages this gives them in their clinical practice.
Recommendation 2: Shortening training
There is no evidence that any of the previous actions to shorten surgical training have worked.14 OMFS trainees joining the specialist list at similar ages to other surgical specialties reflects poorly on them (due to delay in CCT) rather than well on OMFS.15
Recommendation 3: Training should start at the beginning of the second degree
Previous attempts to create â€˜Run-Through Maxâ€™, by incorporating the second degree into specialty training led by David Koppel and Patrick Magennis, were unsuccessful. The General Medical Council (GMC) considered that European law prevented this even though it was explained to them that the German medical authorities allow doctors to acquire a dental degree during their OMFS training.13 Dentistry-first trainees would need special arrangements for GMC oversight of training in the medical specialty of OMFS in the period before their final year when provisional GMC registration is possible.
Brexit could also allow a change in UK legislation from the current wording which requires OMFS surgeons' dental qualification to be â€˜registrableâ€™ by the General Dental Council to their dental qualification to be â€˜recognisedâ€™ by the ENIC (European Network of Information Centres in the European Region) and NARIC (National Academic Recognition Information Centres in the European Union).16 This change would allow overseas dentists to train in the UK without needing the overseas registration examination (ORE). There has been a softening of the GDC's approach to non-registerable dental qualifications with the creation of provisional registration as well as temporary registration26.
Issues with shortened medical and dental courses, which were erroneously considered to be against EU law,17 have also been eliminated by Brexit.
Recommendation 4: OMFS should have a single regulator â€“ the General Medical Council
In 2008 less than a handful of OMFS consultants had let their GDC registration lapse. In 2023, almost half of all consultants are solely on the medical register.18 Rationalising the regulation of OMFS with a Memorandum of Understanding between the GMC and GDC would be a significant advance for the specialty and would further clarify what the GDC defines as a â€˜medical taskâ€™.19
Recommendation 6: Removing the need for Foundation Year 2 for OMFS trainees
Between 2010 and 2013, trainees who had passed their MRCS exam were able to enter specialty training without completing Foundation Year 2 (FY2) training or Core Surgical Training. This shortcut, avoiding FY2, was recommended by the PMETB and supported by â€˜Modernising Medical Careersâ€™ but stopped by the GMC based on EU regulations.20 The involved trainees successfully completed training with no detriment or delay21 and Brexit now introduces an option to change foundation training for OMFS trainees.
Other important issues post-dating the PMETB review
Student fees
Student fees have changed the financial consequences of dual-degree training. Most doctors will never pay off their first student loan,22 effectively paying 6% graduate tax for the remainder of their career. As rules mean that remaining debt is written off at the age of 65 or after 25â€“30 years (depending on which student loan â€˜planâ€™ one is on) this creates a massive life-long debt with significant emotional impact.23
National recruitment
National recruitment started for OMFS in 2010. The process leaves some jobs unfilled when appointable applicants do not want to move home. Evidence-based options previously published recommend linking second-degree trainees formally into training programmes. There is currently support within the specialty to create â€˜OMFS Run-Through-Maxâ€™ posts with NIHR ACF style regional recruitment and national bench-marking.27,20
BAOMS Mentoring and Support Programme (MSP)
This started in 2010 with support from the Severn Deanery and has had the highest conversion rate to STs of any programme.24
Conclusion
Hundreds of OMFS consultants, trainees, and patients contributed to the original review. For depth and breadth of consideration, nothing before or since has been similar.
Like all surgical specialties, OMFS is under pressure for both recruitment, retention, and managing an aging workforce.25 It is the responsibility of those currently leading the specialty to do their best under the current circumstances to support it now and plan for its future. To quote the title of an editorial from BJOMS only a few years ago â€œThe future of OMFS lies in creating pathways to implement the PMETB recommendations and inspiring our trainees. Enough time has been spent debating, we need to deliver!â€3
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
None needed.

Title: United Kingdom oral and maxillofacial surgeons support changes to current specialty recruitment process, which could include ‘Walport’ style local selection and national benchmarking
Author: Sharma, Divya; Douglas, James; Begley, Anne; Hutchison, Iain; Magennis, Patrick
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Recruitment to oral and maxillofacial Surgical (OMFS) specialty training was centralised in 2010. The ?flexibility? for OMFS to respond to specialty specific recruitment issues is reducing and many Specialty Trainees? (ST) posts are left unfilled. The National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) appointment process designed to address the problem of recruiting and appointing academic surgeons with local selection with national benchmarking has worked. Using a database of all UK OMFS consultants/trainees, an electronic questionnaire was shared by e-mail, WhatsApp, and other social media. Of 306 replies, 125 (41%) were Consultants/post-certificate of completion training (CCT) individuals, 66 (22%) ST, 61 (20%) second degree students, 27 (9%) pre-second degree, 26 (9%) dual degree pre-ST trainees, and one did not indicate their status. A total of 249 (76%) studied dentistry first and 230 (75%) were male. Of those replying, 147 (48%) had no direct experience of national selection. 120 (39%) had experience as a candidate, 20 (7%) as a selector only, 17 (6%) as a candidate and selector, and two did not record their experience. Of 250 expressing an opinion, 156 (62%) supported local selection with 140 (56%) supporting local selection and national benchmarking, which is a process used for research training posts by the NIHR. Geographical continuity was most important for 78% of pre-second-degree trainees, 45% of STs, and 54% of second-degree students. A total of 57 respondents completed free text comments. There is support for changes in OMFS ST selection including creating OMFS posts which include Foundation and second-degree training in NIHR style locally recruited nationally benchmarked posts.
Body:
Introduction
The duration of oral and maxillofacial surgery (OMFS) training and its lack of continuity prior to specialty training (ST) raises unique problems. Previous publications have highlighted the attrition points1â€“3 and repeated geographical relocation is frequently cited as a problem by trainees.2
In 2008, the most extensive and expensive review of OMFS training undertaken by the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB)4 recommended that specialty training should start with the second degree. All previous attempts to deliver this recommendation have failed. We propose it may be time to create a pathway for regions which already have all the components needed to deliver the PMETB recommendations to do so. The key elements of â€˜OMFS Run-Through Maxâ€™ include OMFS selected second degree places, potential for OMFS foundation, ST1 or other surgical posts, which would allow the trainee to acquire Certificate of Requirements for Entry into Higher Specialty Training (CREHST), and OMFS ST3 posts.
â€˜Local recruitment and national benchmarkingâ€™ have been proven already for academic posts. In 2005, the Walport Report5 and the creation of the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR)6 led to nationally funded academic â€˜Walportâ€™ posts - Academic Clinical Fellows (ACF) and Academic Clinical Lecturers (ACL). ACFs and ACLs are locally appointed and then â€˜benchmarkedâ€™ at the national ST selection process. They have proved a solution to the problem of academic recruitment.7
Once ACFs/ACLs were defined, training rotations and universities worked together to generate posts and appoint to them. â€˜OMFS Run Through Maxâ€™ posts would require cooperation from universities, foundation schools, schools of surgery and employing Trusts/Lead Employers. The specific recruitment method for ACFs/ACLs was not defined. Applicants simply had to reach the same benchmark as their non-academic ST colleagues in the national selection process either before or after their ACF/ACL appointment.
OMFS specialty recruitment has been centralised since 2010. Whilst ST1 recruitment is competitive with a near 100% fill rate, the fill rates at ST3 level are much lower, with many posts rejected by appointable candidates.8,9 Many rejections were based on the location of the posts offered.2,10,11
The aim of this study was to ascertain attitudes towards the current recruitment process and views about potential routes to deliver on the PMETB recommendations, including creating a locally appointed nationally benchmarked variant on â€˜Run-Through-Maxâ€™.
Method
In autumn 2022 an online survey was designed on FormdeskÂ® to assess the opinion of OMFS consultants and trainees about the selection process into specialty training and the possibility of local â€˜OMFS Run-Through-Maxâ€™ NIHR style Clinical Fellow posts. Invitations were shared using social media, direct e-mails, and personal communication, which made the denominator difficult to establish. To encourage participation, those who completed the questionnaire were offered entry into a prize draw.
The data were downloaded from FormDesk into Microsoft Excel Â© and analysed using WinstatÂ©.
Recruitment data for Competition Ratios12 and Fill Rates13 for OMFS ST1 and ST3 were downloaded from specialty application data websites.
Results
When the survey closed, 306 participants had entered data in which eight did not include personal contact details. Participant breakdown by grade showed replies from 125 consultants (41%), 66 specialty trainees (22%) and 114 trainees aiming for specialty training, with one respondent whose status could not be identified. Of the 114 pre-ST trainees, 26 (9%) had completed two degrees and were either in foundation or core training, 61 (20%) were enrolled in second degree studies, and 27 (9%) were considering applying for a second degree. Of those whose first degree was known, 249 (81%) studied dentistry first and of all replying 75% (n = 230) were male where gender was reported.
Experience of national recruitment
Almost half (n = 147, 48%) of respondents had no experience of national recruitment (52 consultants). Older consultants responding would have been appointed into specialty training by local processes. and those pre-ST responding would not yet have experienced the selection process. Of the 157 (52%) with experience of the process, 120 (39% of all replying) had experience as a candidate only, 20 (7%) as a selector only and 17 (6%) experience as both candidate and selectors.
Views on local/regional recruitment vs national selection
Of 293 expressing an opinion on which form of selection they would consider most appropriate for OMFS specialty training, 155 (53%) preferred a local or regional process, 94 (32%) national selection and 44 (15%) did not express a preference either way. This distribution of preferences was similar across the different OMFS tiers except for Specialty Trainees who were evenly split and dual degree pre-ST trainees who preferred national selection (Table 1).

Further analysis of the 155 responders who supported local selection showed they were relatively evenly split between those who wanted local selection at ST1/ST3 with national benchmarking (n = 67, 43%), and those who wanted earlier selection during second degree training with national ARCP and later ST1/ST3 benchmarking 72 (46%). A minority of responders advocated local selection only (n = 16, 10%).
Of the 94 who supported national selection, the majority (62) wanted those appointed to have a wider window to be appointed i.e. to enable appointable candidates to take up posts which become available between recruitment rounds. The remaining 32 (34%) felt the current system was satisfactory.
Of the 29 with experience as a selector as part of national recruitment, 19 (66%) supported local selection. Of the 137 responders with no experience of national selection, 78 (57%) favoured local selection. Of the 126 whose only experience was as a candidate, 57 (45%) favoured local selection and 59 (47%) national selection.
Reasoning
The trainers supporting local/regional selection specified a wish to be more involved in trainee selection, which is currently limited to the relatively small group involved in the national recruitment process. Comments included a need for improved communication with regional Training Programme Directors (TPDs), especially when posts are unfilled. The lack of involvement of local faculty in the process lead to some trainers expressing frustration with a process in which trainees are â€˜imposedâ€™ upon them.
From the trainee perspective, geographical continuity was cited as the most important factor by that phase in life (Table 2). In comparison to other surgical specialties, personal commitments of OMFS trainees to location may be greater than other surgical specialties due to increased age. Many expressed their disappointment about the lack of contact with local OMFS units during and after their second degrees. Geographic security earlier in training was cited as an important factor to progress professionally through fostering strong relationships with local units.14

Routes to improve the current national selection process
Those who supported national selection specified fairness and openness as some of the advantages over local selection, and, that if a local/regional process was adopted, national benchmarking of the candidates would be important to avoid the worst aspects of the â€˜old systemâ€™. Comments in favour of national recruitment included avoidance of unfair advantage and selection bias.
When respondents were asked to preference how to improve OMFS selection (Table 3), geographical continuity was most popular (61% of responders). Obtaining a training contract during second degree was second highest (n = 159, 60%) on total choices. Involvement of local faculty in candidate selection for that rotation was second in the first preferences (n = 48) but fourth (n = 117) when all the choices were combined. Closer support and assessment during second degree studies was ranked third in first choices (n = 35) and overall (n = 151).

Poor quality of candidates received from national selection was an option chosen by trainers/consultants and although the numbers are small, it is an important concern to acknowledge.
Factors within the control of the specialty
A total of 245 responders expressed opinions on factors which are within control of the specialty without direct involvement of other stakeholders. Of these, 102 (41%) chose to formalise existing â€˜shadowâ€™ programmes such as the British Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons Mentoring and Support Programme (BAOMS MSP)15 to demonstrate that â€˜OMFS Run-though-Max is possible including national ARCPs for this group.
A smaller proportion of 79 (32%) chose to create Regional OMFS Clinical Fellows (with local appointment and national benchmarking like NIHR ACF/ACLs), leaving 68 (27%) who selected to widen the time window during which successful candidates at national selection can be appointed to a post which becomes vacant.
Discussion
The introduction of an OMFS national selection process followed the pan-specialty national recruitment calamity which was the Medical Training Application System (MTAS)16 and the Tooke Report of the independent inquiry into MTAS in 2008.14 When national selection was introduced for OMFS in 2010, under the supervision of the Modernising Medical Careers (MMC) team, it was much more autonomous than it is now.
For the first three rounds, possession of the MRCS was sufficient to demonstrate acquisition of Core Surgical knowledge, skills and understanding which meant some â€˜dentistry firstâ€™ individuals entered ST3 from Foundation Training including some at the end of Foundation Year 1 (pre-registration year) FY1.17 In 2011, the General Medical Council stopped this approach.18 Local OMFS recruitment processes were suspended whilst a national process was organised. At the same time, the Kingâ€™s Dental Programme for Medical Graduates (DPMG)19 was opened, which meant for those whose surgical career was halted by MTAS (because they had more than 24 monthsâ€™ experience in their preferred specialty), switching to OMFS meant that the first seven rounds of OMFS ST3 national selection were competitive, and most candidates seemed to achieve their first choice posts.20
As time has passed, autonomy of the OMFS specialty within national recruitment has eroded. Two changes, which have had a direct negative impact on OMFS, have been the rules around timing of passing MRCS exam and use of the Multi-Specialty Recruitment Assessment (MSRA) for shortlisting. The former has prevented some OMFS candidates entering selection and delayed their appointment by 12 months. The latter impacted on all applicants but especially medicine first trainees who might be more than five years from their Foundation Training, having completed their dental degree and dental foundation training. From the start of OMFS national recruitment, OMFS has adopted a â€˜no shortlisting outâ€™ policy for our dual degree applicants. OMFS needs to regain some autonomy. One size does not fit all.21
There is evidence that supporting trainees during pre-ST training is effective. In 2010, shortly after national selection to OMFS started, the OMFS Mentoring and Support Programme (MSP) for pre-ST OMFS trainees was created.15,22,23 Of the 250 trainees in the MSP who subsequently became eligible to apply for specialty training, over 98% have been successful. This contrasts with the 50% or higher drop-out rate for second degree students aiming for OMFS showing the effectiveness of the programme. A formal â€˜OMFS Run-Through-Maxâ€™, as recommended by the 2008 PMETB Review of Training14,11 should be at least as effective as the informal MSP.
The published competition ratios for OMFS Specialty Training are summarised in Tables 4 and 5.12,13,24,9,10,21 A recent paper highlighted that approximately one third of appointable candidates at ST1, but for whom there were not enough posts, never reappeared for ST3 recruitment rounds.8,5 Approximately one-third of ST3 posts have gone unfilled.8,12,13,5,9,10 Trainers who have unfilled training posts, and/or have participated in the national selection process have expressed frustration when appointable candidates decline their posts. Successful trainees who cannot accept any of the posts initially offered, could be offered unfilled posts across a longer time window.

As time has passed, our ability to understand the specialtyâ€™s own recruitment has been limited by the lack of data provided by Severn Local Education Training Board (LETB). Lack of transparency is adding to the feeling of crisis in the specialty.1
Conclusion
The application ratios for OMFS ST3 recruitment tell a sorry tale. ST1 recruitment data demonstrates there are dual degree trainees who are hungry to pursue higher training in OMFS. We are letting these trainees down.
There is strong support for the PMETB recommendations in the specialty.26 Failure to deliver on the PMETB recommendations has persisted despite unanimous support from our specialty association.25 Dissatisfaction with the current centralised selection process and evidence that there are enough trainers and trainees within OMFS who would be willing to try NIHR style local recruitment and national benchmarking may present an opportunity to finally try implementing recommendations made 15 years ago. What these posts are called and the specifics of local selection are less important than creating a route to appoint earlier than ST to â€˜OMFS Run-Through-Maxâ€™.
Creating this atypical route helped to address the crisis in academic medicine and dentistry. The crisis in OMFS recruitment matches or exceeds the crisis that provoked the Walport Report. If central funding were to be made available, the posts would follow.
If it proves impossible to persuade all the medical training stakeholders to create OMFS Run-Through-Max posts, then benchmarking before or during a candidateâ€™s second degree and giving strong recognition of this within the ST1 and ST3 person specifications could be a useful step forward. Recognition of the BAOMS MSP within the person specifications did encourage OMFS trainees to use this option during their pre-ST studies and training. Formalising existing support programmes with ARCPs at regional or national levels would improve this support and generate strong evidence to enhance specialty traineesâ€™ applications.
We make three suggestions.
A formal research project should be developed to monitor and understand OMFS specialty recruitment and all those entering OMFS ST1 and ST3 recruitment should be consented to participate in the study. We need to understand what does and does not work.
Pre-ST OMFS trainees should have the option to benefit from a national annual review of their progress and any existing local/regional support should be formalised as much as possible.
The offer of centrally funded â€˜Walportâ€™-like NIHR style local selection with national benchmarking to â€˜Run-Through-Maxâ€™ posts including pre-ST training would stimulate the creation of pre-ST â€˜OMFSâ€™ posts. This would include those just embarking on or already enrolled on second degrees to those in second degree studies including OMFS specific Foundation programmes and CREHST posts. A pilot should be part of a formal review programme so that if successful it can be extended.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Funding
No funding.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
None needed.

Title: Use of Integra® on avascular tissue
Author: Ria, Sama; Chegini, Soudeh; Ozbek, Leyla; Nigar, Ezra; Shorafa, Mohammad
Journal: British Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
Abstract: Integra? (Integra LifeSciences) is a well-known dermal regeneration template used in partial and full-thickness wound reconstruction. It can be applied directly on to vascular tissue to create a bed for a skin graft, which is often placed in a second surgery. We present our experience of its novel use in oral and maxillofacial surgery patients, using it directly on bone and cartilage (avascular tissue) without further skin grafting. Patients who required full-thickness excision of lesions down to bone or cartilage and who were treated using Integra? were included. After scalp or ear lesion resection, the collagenous dermal layer of Integra? was placed directly on to bone or cartilage and, along with its outer silicone epidermal layer, secured to the defect with absorbable sutures and a bolster dressing. The wounds were kept dry for 14 days, at which point the dressing and silicone were removed and patients continued regular wound care. Seventeen patients were included, 15 of whom had squamous cell carcinoma. One was lost to follow up. The rest achieved complete healing of the defect. Histology showed epidermis developing on the Integra? surface and at one year, the appearance of normal scarred skin. This novel approach could redefine the uses of Integra?, avoiding the need for free-flap surgery or skin grafting when reconstructing large defects. Further resection of close margins or recurrence is easier after reconstruction using dermal regeneration material than after reconstruction with a local or free flap.
Body:
Introduction
Surgery to reconstruct skin following the removal of a lesion, for example skin cancer, traditionally involves removing skin from a different area and transplanting it at the location of the defect. This complicated procedure requires hospital admission, and in the elderly it has a significant risk of complications. Laboratory-created dermal regeneration templates are designed to reduce the thickness of the skin needed for transplantation or avoid the need for it completely. The material is a fibrous meshwork that helps to stimulate normal growth of skin. This study reports the novel use of a dermal regeneration template called IntegraÂ® (Integra LifeSciences), which is applied directly on to bone in head lesions without the use of skin transplantation. To our knowledge this has not been reported before and is contrary to how the product is designed to be used.
Sixteen patients were followed up after use of this new technique and all achieved complete healing. We therefore conclude that the technique could be suitable for certain groups such as elderly patients with multiple chronic conditions.
IntegraÂ® is a dermal regeneration template (DRT) for use in the reconstruction of partial and full-thickness wounds.1 It is composed of two layers. The inner layer is a porous fibre matrix of cross-linked collagen and glycosaminoglycan, which stimulates cell migration from surrounding host tissue into the dermal layer. There is also a thin outer silicone layer that acts as a temporary epidermal substitute to prevent bacterial entry and control fluid loss.2,3
According to the manufacturer, the prerequisites of IntegraÂ® include use on vascular tissue, achievement of haemostasis, and a flat and uniform wound bed. Small scalp defects are most often managed by primary closure, but larger defects often require skin grafting or flap reconstruction. Skin grafts are contraindicated for direct use on to full-thickness defects. While skin grafts carry a high success rate, they are not without risk. Complications include donor site morbidity, contraction, contour deficit, infection, and necrosis.4 Free flaps present a challenge in elderly patients who have much comorbidity and who often have reduced tolerability. Elderly patients with multiple skin lesions and widespread skin damage can have ill-defined lesions, making it difficult to achieve clear margins. There is also the risk of recurrence; flap reconstructions make further resections challenging due to loss of the original orientation of the surgical margin.5 DRTs such as IntegraÂ® are a viable alternative.6,7
IntegraÂ® has been routinely used over vascular layers (such as pericranium) so that only an epidermal skin graft is needed, leaving the dermal layer intact at the donor site.6 The manufacturer advises the reconstruction of defects extending to a vascular bed with IntegraÂ® followed by a skin graft. The epidermal silicone layer is then removed, and a thin skin graft placed on to the IntegraÂ® dermal layer either immediately or within three weeks postoperatively.8â€“11 The dermal layer is gradually resorbed over two to three weeks, and replaced by natural protein produced by the skin.
In this paper, we present a series of clinical and histological findings of cases in which IntegraÂ® was placed directly on to avascular tissue without a subsequent skin graft, contrary to usual practice.
Material and methods
Patient selection and data collection
We identified a total of 15 patients over a period of four years, who underwent reconstruction of full-thickness, soft tissue defects greater than 5 x 5 cm with direct placement of IntegraÂ®. Those without autogenous skin grafting were included. Patients were identified using operating theatre prosthesis usage logbooks. Demographic, operative, histological, and follow-up data were collected retrospectively using medical records.
Reconstructive protocol
Procedures were carried out in a theatre setting. Lesions were prepared with a chlorhexidine or iodine-based solution, and edges were marked and then anaesthetised using local anaesthetic infiltration. Resections were performed with margins taken in accordance with the British Association of Dermatologistsâ€™ guidelines.12 Scalp lesions were excised down to bone or cartilage and debrided. Haemostasis was achieved by electrocautery. A sheet of IntegraÂ® was cut to fit the size of the defect. Larger defects required multiple sheets attached together with absorbable sutures. The collagenous dermal layer of IntegraÂ® was placed directly on to the bony or cartilaginous defect and, along with its outer silicone epidermal layer, secured on to the defect with absorbable sutures. This was then covered with an iodine-soaked bolster dressing and surgical staples. Procedures were performed as day-case surgeries.
Follow up
Patients were asked to keep the dressing and wound clean and dry. They were reviewed in an outpatient dressing clinic between 10 and 21 days postoperatively, and removal of the IntegraÂ® silicone epidermal layer was considered. The IntegraÂ® was then dressed with a BetadineÂ®-based dressing covered by a secondary atraumatic dressing. Wounds were often found to be exudative and these were dressed with absorbent dressings. The colour of the wound was monitored for signs of vascularisation. Regular dressing care continued in accordance with the local hospital protocol until complete healing was achieved.
Results
Between June 2014 and August 2017, 17 patients were identified. Three were female. The median (range) age was 83 (76â€“101) years. After histological assessment of the excised lesions, one patient had a pleomorphic dermal sarcoma, one had an atypical fibroxanthoma and 15 had squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The median (range) dressing follow up by the nurse was 94 (31â€“239) days. Patients were seen postoperatively on average 11 times in the dressing clinic (median (range) follow-up time 230 (11â€“995) days).
One patient died at five months postoperatively due to progression of SCC. All other patients showed complete healing of the reconstructed area during the follow-up period. The only complications were localised infections that required oral antibiotics in two patients. No patient required further reconstruction with a skin graft.
Figure 1 shows one of the patientâ€™s defects following SCC excision and immediate reconstruction with IntegraÂ®. Figure 2 shows the healing process following reconstruction with IntegraÂ® in a different patient at four weeks and six months.

Figure viewer
Fig. 1 Photographs of the immediate postoperative appearance following IntegraÂ® reconstruction on scalp vertex (left) and the excised lesion (right).

Figure viewer
Fig. 2 Photographs of the scalp vertex following lesion excision and IntegraÂ® reconstruction at four weeks (left) and six months (right).
Two patients required further biopsy at four weeks and one year following reconstruction to investigate for recurrence. Histological examination of this tissue enabled study of the healing process. Figure 3 shows histological examination of packaged IntegraÂ®, revealing a loose network of collagen.

Figure viewer
Fig. 3 Histology of the dermal layer of Integra showing a meshwork of collagen composed of a lattice of thick and thin collagen fibres. The ground substance filling the mesh has washed out during processing.
Figure 4 shows the histology at four weeks, where a clear interface between skin and IntegraÂ® can be seen, as well as evidence of chronic inflammation and oedema. Figure 5 shows the histology at one year, where the tissue appears as normal scarred skin. The only remaining evidence of IntegraÂ® reconstruction is chronic perivascular inflammation and fibrosis in the dermis. A few eosinophils are also visible. The dermis shows dense collagenisation in keeping with scar tissue. Interestingly, there was the appearance of incidental necrotising palisaded granulomas in both cases, as seen in Figure 6. This is a noteworthy feature as it can be interpreted as an infection in the absence of a surgical history.

Figure viewer
Fig. 4 Histological appearance of a specimen taken four weeks postoperatively showing epidermis beginning to grow over IntegraÂ®. Integra collagen fibres are seen within the dermis, with fibroblasts from surrounding skin growing into this collagen framework.

Figure viewer
Fig. 5 Histological appearance of a specimen taken one year postoperatively showing dermal scarring and perivascular chronic inflammation.

Figure viewer
Fig. 6 Histological appearance of a specimen taken at four weeks postoperatively, showing a necrotising palisaded granuloma in association with IntegraÂ®.
Discussion
IntegraÂ® was initially intended for use on burn injuries, but is now accepted as a DRT for oncology and trauma cases. In the context of reconstruction, however, most studies report its use on vascular tissue which is then grafted by autogenous epidermis, as per the manufacturerâ€™s recommendations. To our knowledge, the placement of IntegraÂ® directly on to bone without further skin grafting has not previously been described.
Data from other units have shown the application of IntegraÂ® directly on to bone following burring of the calvarium to achieve adequate bleeding.13 It is not our practice to burr the calvarium before placing the IntegraÂ®, and we have not seen treatment fail when this has not been done. Given the histological evidence of the ingrowth of epidermis from the peripheries over the IntegraÂ®, it would be logical to avoid excessive bipolar haemostasis of the margins, especially of the epidermis layer. Further research is needed to quantify the distance to which the epidermis can grow over the IntegraÂ®, as well as the speed of growth. This could guide the choice of reconstruction method.
The repair of scalp defects can be challenging, especially in the elderly population, usually because of the nature of the disease, multimorbidity, and tolerance. This paper demonstrates the successful application of IntegraÂ® DRT on avascular bone and cartilage without the need for skin grafting. Both cosmetic and functional outcomes were acceptable in all patients. Histopathological examination proved that IntegraÂ® can successfully mature on to avascular tissue, with histological appearances indistinguishable from normal, albeit scarred, skin after four weeks.
Artificial dermis is beneficial because of the reduction in patient morbidity, procedure complexity, and operating time. Its ease of application and ready availability support its use as a grafting material. Cosmetic outcomes with artificial dermis have also shown reductions in contracture, scarring, and colour differences when compared with skin grafts.14,15
Additionally, as demonstrated by our cases, the use of artificial dermis preserves orientation of the surgical margin, which is a significant advantage from an oncological point of view.6
Free-flap reconstruction is a lengthy general anaesthetic procedure, which commonly requires at least overnight admission in a high dependency unit, often followed by 10 to 14 days of inpatient stay. Conversely, DRTs such as IntegraÂ®, which can be placed under a local anaesthetic during a day-case procedure, saves health services significant resources, and outweighs the cost of running nurse-led dressing clinics and the IntegraÂ® template (around Â£400 ($530 USD) for 5 Ã— 5 cm).
We have had widespread success with this technique, but we recognise that our patient cohort presented with primary skin cancer. The use of IntegraÂ® on post-radiotherapy skin or skin treated with topical immunomodulators requires further investigation. Histological assessment has shown that epithelialisation is dependent on the ingrowth of epidermis from the peripheries. Presumably, healthy surrounding epidermis is a prerequisite.
In our retrospective review of 17 patients, we found successful application of IntegraÂ® on avascular tissue without the need for postoperative skin grafting. Histopathological examination showed excellent healing with dermal fibrosis and epidermal regeneration over the defect, proving that IntegraÂ® can be used on its own, and placed directly on avascular tissue while still maturing to skin. These interesting findings offer alternative management for head and neck defects, as well as remarkably redefining the uses of IntegraÂ®.
Conflict of interest
We have no conflicts of interest.
Ethics statement/confirmation of patient permission
Ethics approval not applicable. Patientsâ€™ permission obtained.
